Avocado: The pulpy fruit of Persea gratissima, a tree of tropical America. It is about the size and shape of a large pear; -- called also avocado pear, alligator pear, midshipman's butter.
Acerbity: Sourness of taste, with bitterness and astringency, like that of unripe fruit.
Anisocoria: Inequality of the pupils of the eye.
Analogous: Having analogy; corresponding to something else; bearing some resemblance or proportion; -- often followed by to.
Astrography: The art of describing or delineating the stars; a description or mapping of the heavens.
Adatis: A fine cotton cloth of India.
Antisepalous: Standing before a sepal, or calyx leaf.
Asininity: The quality of being asinine; stupidity combined with obstinacy.
Apocrisiary: A delegate or deputy; especially, the pope's nuncio or legate at Constantinople.
Atrocious: Extremely heinous; full of enormous wickedness; as, atrocious guilt or deeds.
Artesian: Of or pertaining to Artois (anciently called Artesium), in France.
Acorn-shell: One of the sessile cirripeds; a barnacle of the genus Balanus. See Barnacle.
Atlantean: Of or pertaining to the isle Atlantis, which the ancients allege was sunk, and overwhelmed by the ocean.
Alliterative: Pertaining to, or characterized by, alliteration; as, alliterative poetry.
Acquit: To discharge, as a claim or debt; to clear off; to pay off; to requite.
Archelogy: The science of, or a treatise on, first principles.
Aright: Rightly; correctly; in a right way or form; without mistake or crime; as, to worship God aright.
Alkali soil: Any one of various soils found in arid and semiarid regions, containing an unusual amount of soluble mineral salts which effloresce in the form of a powder or crust (usually white) in dry weather following rains or irrigation. The basis of these salts is mainly soda with a smaller amount of potash, and usually a little lime and  magnesia. Two main classes of alkali are commonly distinguished: black alkali, which may be any alkaline carbonate, but which practically consists of sodium carbonate (sal soda), which is highly corrosive and destructive to vegetation; and white alkali, characterized by the presence of sodium sulphate (Glauber's salt), which is less injurious to vegetation. Black alkali is so called because water containing it dissolves humus, forming a dark-colored solution which, when it collects in puddles and evaporates, produces characteristic black spots.
Aluminate: A compound formed from the hydrate of aluminium by the substitution of a metal for the hydrogen.
Accipiter: A genus of rapacious birds; one of the Accipitres or Raptores.
athar: essential oil or perfume obtained from flowers.
Ant cow: Any aphid from which ants obtain honeydew.  The plural form is ant cattle.
anthropogenetic: of or pertaining to anthropogenesis; caused by mankind or by humans.
Ambrein: A fragrant substance which is the chief constituent of ambergris.
Amphipod: Of or pertaining to the Amphipoda.
Abrogative: Tending or designed to abrogate; as, an abrogative law.
Arbuscular: Of or pertaining to a dwarf tree; shrublike.
Alternative: An offer of two things, one of which may be chosen, but not both; a choice between two things, so that if one is taken, the other must be left.
absiemens: A unit of conductance equal to 109 mhos; -- the inverse of the abohm.
Aminol: A colorless liquid prepared from herring brine and containing amines, used as a local antiseptic.
Ambrotype: A picture taken on a plate of prepared glass, in which the lights are represented in silver, and the shades are produced by a dark background visible through the unsilvered portions of the glass.
airball: A throw at the basket that completely misses, not even hitting the rim.  Compare swoosh and nothing but net.
Aspersed: Having an indefinite number of small charges scattered or strewed over the surface.
Antefix: An ornament fixed upon a frieze.
Accompany: To associate in a company; to keep company.
Arteriology: That part of anatomy which treats of arteries.
Appulsion: A driving or striking against; an appulse.
Antipodean: Pertaining to the antipodes, or the opposite side of the world; antipodal.
A\u00ebrial sickness: A sickness felt by aëronauts due to high speed of flights and rapidity in changing altitudes, combining some symptoms of mountain sickness and some of seasickness.  The nauseous symptoms similar to seasickness experienced by passengers in pressurized aircraft is called air sickness.
Alkermes: A compound cordial, in the form of a confection, deriving its name from the kermes insect, its principal ingredient.
Adoor: At the door; of the door; as, out adoors.
Acology: Materia medica; the science of remedies.
90: one more than eighty-nine and one less than ninety-one; denoting a quantity consisting of ninety items or units; -- representing the number ninety as Arabic numerals
Accadian: Pertaining to a race supposed to have lived in Babylonia before the Assyrian conquest.
Ailment: Indisposition; morbid affection of the body; -- not applied ordinarily to acute diseases.
Agouta: A small insectivorous mammal (Solenodon paradoxus), allied to the moles, found only in Haiti.
Acquaintedness: State of being acquainted; degree of acquaintance.
Agouti: A rodent of the genus Dasyprocta, about the size of a rabbit, peculiar to South America and the West Indies. The most common species is the Dasyprocta agouti.
Aurilave: An instrument for cleansing the ear, consisting of a small piece of sponge on an ivory or bone handle.
Adventitious: Added extrinsically; not essentially inherent; accidental or causal; additional; supervenient; foreign.
Anaglyptography: The art of copying works in relief, or of engraving as to give the subject an embossed or raised appearance; -- used in representing coins, bas-reliefs, etc.
Aborticide: The act of destroying a fetus in the womb; feticide.
Anecdotist: One who relates or collects anecdotes.
Adiantum: A genus of ferns, the leaves of which shed water; maidenhair. Also, the black maidenhair, a species of spleenwort.
amatungulu: a very large closely branched South African shrub (Carissa grandiflora) of the dogbane family having forked bright green spines, white flowers, shiny leaves, and red berries.  Also called natal plum.
azotemia: the accumulation of an abnormally large amount of nitrogen-containing waste products, such as urea, in the blood; uremia.
Anatomy: The art of dissecting, or artificially separating the different parts of any organized body, to discover their situation, structure, and economy; dissection.
Alsace: a region of northeastern France famous for its wines.
Autobiographic: Pertaining to, or containing, autobiography; as, an autobiographical sketch.
A: An expletive, void of sense, to fill up the meter
Abhorrence: Extreme hatred or detestation; the feeling of utter dislike.
Addax: One of the largest African antelopes (Hippotragusnasomaculatus or Oryx nasomaculatus).
Albification: The act or process of making white.
Aldol: A colorless liquid, C4H8O2, obtained by condensation of two molecules of acetaldehyde: CH3CHO + CH3CHO = H3CH(OH)CH2CO; also, any of various derivatives of this. The same reaction has been applied, under the name of aldol condensation, to the production of many compounds.
Aloud: With a loud voice, or great noise; loudly; audibly.
Assertor: One who asserts or avers; one who maintains or vindicates a claim or a right; an affirmer, supporter, or vindicator; a defender; an asserter.
Argumentative: Consisting of, or characterized by, argument; containing a process of reasoning; as, an argumentative discourse.
assemblywoman: a female member of a legislative body called an assembly.
Adaunt: To daunt; to subdue; to mitigate.
Air sickness: A vomiting or nauseous feeling similar to seasickness experienced by passengers in aircraft; -- it is caused by motion and distinguished from the effects of low air pressure, as it may also occur in the pressurized cabins of large aircraft.
18th: coming next after the seventeenth in a series
Another: One more, in addition to a former number; a second or additional one, similar in likeness or in effect.
Authorial: Of or pertaining to an author.
Aggroupment: Arrangement in a group or in groups; grouping.
aircraftman: a noncommissioned officer in the British Royal Air Force.
Angiomonospermous: Producing one seed only in a seed pod.
AAAS: the American Association for the Advancement of Science, an organization with headquarters in Washington, D.C.  Its goal is to advance the physical and social sciences, and it publishes a weekly journal Science, with original research articles as well as reviews and commentary.
Alphabet: To designate by the letters of the alphabet; to arrange alphabetically.
Aurelian: An amateur collector and breeder of insects, esp. of butterflies and moths; a lepidopterist.
Alcaid: A commander of a castle or fortress among the Spaniards, Portuguese, and Moors.
Alcaic: Pertaining to Alcæus, a lyric poet of Mitylene, about 6000 b. c.
Anabaptistic: Relating or attributed to the Anabaptists, or their doctrines.
Alphabetically: In an alphabetic manner; in the customary order of the letters.
aralia: any of various plants of the genus Aralia; often aromatic plants having compound leaves and small umbellate flowers.
Anoplura: A group of insects which includes the lice.
Articulately: After the manner, or in the form, of a joint.
Antipsoric: Of use in curing the itch.
Anti-federalist: One of party opposed to a federative government; -- applied particularly to the party which opposed the adoption of the constitution of the United States.
Antitoxin: A substance (sometimes the product of a specific micro-organism and sometimes naturally present in the blood or tissues of an animal), capable of producing immunity from certain diseases, or of counteracting the poisonous effects of pathogenic bacteria.
anchusa: any of various Old World herbs of the genus Anchusa having one-sided clusters of trumpet-shaped flowers.
Absquatulate: To take one's self off; to decamp.
Alterableness: The quality of being alterable; variableness; alterability.
Anchor space: In the balk-line game, any of eight spaces, 7 inches by 31/2, lying along a cushion and bisected transversely by a balk line. Object balls in an anchor space are treated as in balk.
Affection: The act of affecting or acting upon; the state of being affected.
armoured: provided with protective covering; -- used of animals.  Opposite of unarmored.
Antisplenetic: Good as a remedy against disease of the spleen.
armourer: an enlisted man responsible for the upkeep of small arms and machine guns etc.
Atherine: A small marine fish of the family Atherinidæ, having a silvery stripe along the sides. The European species (Atherina presbyter) is used as food. The American species (Menidia notata) is called silversides and sand smelt. See Silversides.
Arenulous: Full of fine sand; like sand.
Asafetida: The fetid gum resin or inspissated juice of a large umbelliferous plant (Ferula asafœtida) of Persia and the East Indies. It is used in medicine as an antispasmodic.
Aspen: Of or pertaining to the aspen, or resembling it; made of aspen wood.
Arch\u00e6ology: The science or study of antiquities, esp. prehistoric antiquities, such as the remains of buildings or monuments of an early epoch, inscriptions, implements, and other relics, written manuscripts, etc.
Amphistylic: Having the mandibular arch articulated with the hyoid arch and the cranium, as in the cestraciont sharks; -- said of a skull.
Aleurone: An albuminoid substance which occurs in minute grains (“protein granules”) in maturing seeds and tubers; -- supposed to be a modification of protoplasm.
Asper: A Turkish money of account (formerly a coin), of little value; the 120th part of a piaster.
Alderman: A senior or superior; a person of rank or dignity.
Almagest: The celebrated work of Ptolemy of Alexandria, which contains nearly all that is known of the astronomical observations and theories of the ancients. The name was extended to other similar works.
Accelerograph: An apparatus for studying the combustion of powder in guns, etc.
Adopt: To take by choice into relationship, as, child, heir, friend, citizen, etc.; esp. to take voluntarily (a child of other parents) to be in the place of, or as, one's own child.
Abortion: The act of giving premature birth; particularly, the expulsion of the human fetus prematurely, or before it is capable of sustaining life; miscarriage.
1-hitter: a baseball game in which one team's pitchers allow the opposing team only one hit.
Author: To occasion; to originate.
Acatalepsy: Incomprehensibility of things; the doctrine held by the ancient Skeptic philosophers, that human knowledge never amounts to certainty, but only to probability.
avaram: an evergreen Indian shrub (Senna auriculata or Cassia auriculata) with vivid yellow flowers whose bark is used in tanning; it is sometimes placed in the genus Cassia.
Acervative: Heaped up; tending to heap up.
Anchor-hold: The hold or grip of an anchor, or that to which it holds.
Acontia: Threadlike defensive organs, composed largely of nettling cells (cnidæ), thrown out of the mouth or special pores of certain Actiniæ when irritated.
airplane propeller: a propeller designed for propelling airplanes.
Antenicene: Of or in the Christian church or era, anterior to the first council of Nice, held a. d. 325; as, antenicene faith.
Addressograph: a printer that automatically prints addresses on letters for mailing.
Acclivous: Sloping upward; rising as a hillside; -- opposed to declivous.
Annulment: The act of annulling; abolition; invalidation.
Arrowworm: A peculiar transparent worm of the genus Sagitta, living at the surface of the sea. See Sagitta.
Alsobia: a genus of tropical American herbs sometimes included in genus Episcia.
Arendator: In some provinces of Russia, one who farms the rents or revenues.
Anteversion: A displacement of an organ, esp. of the uterus, in such manner that its whole axis is directed further forward than usual.
Aggregation: The act of aggregating, or the state of being aggregated; collection into a mass or sum; a collection of particulars; an aggregate.
Alkalimetry: The art or process of ascertaining the strength of alkalies, or the quantity present in alkaline mixtures.
Anaglyptics: The art of carving in low relief, embossing, etc.
Althing: The national assembly or parliament of Iceland. See Thing, n., 8.
Antimagistrical: Opposed to the office or authority of magistrates.
Atmospheric: Of or pertaining to the atmosphere; of the nature of, or resembling, the atmosphere; as, atmospheric air; the atmospheric envelope of the earth.
Ablactation: The weaning of a child from the breast, or of young beasts from their dam.
Aplacental: Belonging to the Aplacentata; without placenta.
A\u00ebroscope: An apparatus designed for collecting spores, germs, bacteria, etc., suspended in the air.
Alongside: Along or by the side; side by side with; -- often with of; as, bring the boat alongside; alongside of him; alongside of the tree.
A\u00ebroscopy: The observation of the state and variations of the atmosphere.
Ara: A name of the great blue and yellow macaw (Ara ararauna), native of South America.
Angioneurosis: Any disorder of the vasomotor system; neurosis of a blood vessel.
Arse: The buttocks, or hind part of an animal; the posteriors; the fundament; the bottom.
Automobile: a self-propelled vehicle used for transporting passengers, suitable for use on a street or roadway. Many diferent models of automobiles have beenbuilt and sold commercially, possessing varied features such as a retractable roof (in a convertible), different braking systems, different propulsion systems, and varied styling.  Most models have four wheels but some have been built with three wheels.  Automobiles are usually propelled by internal combustion engines (using volatile inflammable liquids, as gasoline or petrol, alcohol, naphtha, etc.), and sometimes by steam engines, or electric motors. The power of the driving motor varies from under 50 H. P. for earlier models to over 200 H. P. larger models or high-performance sports or racing cars. An automobile is commonly called a car or an auto, and generally in British usage, motor cars.
Atmiatry: Treatment of disease by vapors or gases, as by inhalation.
Ammodyte: One of a genus of fishes; the sand eel.
Abligate: To tie up so as to hinder from.
Affirmance: Confirmation; ratification; confirmation of a voidable act.
Alcazar: A fortress; also, a royal palace.
Ass: A quadruped of the genus Equus (Equus asinus), smaller than the horse, and having a peculiarly harsh bray and long ears.  The tame or domestic ass is patient, slow, and sure-footed, and has become the type of obstinacy and stupidity.  There are several species of wild asses which are swift-footed.
Asp: A small, hooded, poisonous serpent of Egypt and adjacent countries, whose bite is often fatal. It is the Naja haje. The name is also applied to other poisonous serpents, esp. to Vipera aspis of southern Europe. See Haje.
60th: coming next after the fifty-ninth in a series
Ataman: A hetman, or chief of the Cossacks.
Asa: An ancient name of a gum.
Acceptably: In an acceptable manner; in a manner to please or give satisfaction.
Assamese: Of or pertaining to Assam, a province of British India, or to its inhabitants.
Anhele: To pant; to be breathlessly anxious or eager (for).
Assyriologist: One versed in Assyriology; a student of Assyrian archæology.
Alterative: A medicine or treatment which gradually induces a change, and restores healthy functions without sensible evacuations.
adventitia: the membranous outer covering of an organ or blood vessel.
antitrust: opposed to trusts, monopolies, or other large combinations of business or capital which threaten fair competition; designed to protect trade and commerce from unfair business practices; -- of laws and regulations.
Alula: A false or bastard wing. See under Bastard.
Autonomasy: The use of a word of common or general signification for the name of a particular thing; as, “He has gone to town,” for, “He has gone to London.”
Absorptiveness: The quality of being absorptive; absorptive power.
Aglaonema: a genus of Indo-Malayan climbing herbs having thick fleshy oblong leaves and naked unisexual flowers: Chinese evergreen.
Acroamatic: Communicated orally; oral; -- applied to the esoteric teachings of Aristotle, those intended for his genuine disciples, in distinction from his exoteric doctrines, which were adapted to outsiders or the public generally. Hence: Abstruse; profound.
Anthericum: a genus of Old World (mainly African) perennial herbs; sometimes placed in family Asphodelaceae.
Apodiformes: an oreer of birds including the swifts and hummingbirds.
Amenable: Easy to be led; governable, as a woman by her husband.
Anilinism: A disease due to inhaling the poisonous fumes present in the manufacture of aniline.
Alchemy: An imaginary art which aimed to transmute the baser metals into gold, to find the panacea, or universal remedy for diseases, etc. It led the way to modern chemistry.
Atmidometer: An instrument for measuring the evaporation from water, ice, or snow.
Arrhythmic: Being without rhythm or regularity, as the pulse.
Averroist: One of a sect of peripatetic philosophers, who appeared in Italy before the restoration of learning; so denominated from Averroes, or Averrhoes, a celebrated Arabian philosopher. He held the doctrine of monopsychism.
Ammonium: A compound radical, NH4, having the chemical relations of a strongly basic element like the alkali metals.
Avellane: In the form of four unhusked filberts; as, an avellane cross.
Agronomist: One versed in agronomy; a student of agronomy.
Account: To render or receive an account or relation of particulars; as, an officer must account with or to the treasurer for money received.
Abelmosk: An evergreen shrub (Abelmoschus moschatus -- formerly Hibiscus moschatus), of the East and West Indies and Northern Africa, whose musky seeds are used in perfumery and to flavor coffee; -- sometimes called musk mallow.  The seeds produce ambrette-seed oil.
Amend: To grow better by rectifying something wrong in manners or morals; to improve.
Ancestral: Of, pertaining to, derived from, or possessed by, an ancestor or ancestors; as, an ancestral estate.
altogether: nakedness; -- used mostly in the phrase “in the altogether”.
Ament: A species of inflorescence; a catkin.
Archierey: The higher order of clergy in Russia, including metropolitans, archbishops, and bishops.
Ablet: A small fresh-water fish (Leuciscus alburnus); the bleak.
Ariose: Characterized by melody, as distinguished from harmony.
Asphyxial: Of or relating to asphyxia; as, asphyxial phenomena.
Academism: The doctrines of the Academic philosophy.
Adverb: A word used to modify the sense of a verb, participle, adjective, or other adverb, and usually placed near it; as, he writes well; paper extremely white.
Asystolism: The state or symptoms characteristic of asystole.
Advert: To turn the mind or attention; to refer; to take heed or notice; -- with to; as, he adverted to what was said.
Anaglyph: Any sculptured, chased, or embossed ornament worked in low relief, as a cameo.
Alamode: A thin, black silk for hoods, scarfs, etc.; -- often called simply mode.
Annotator: A writer of annotations; a commentator.
Albyn: Scotland; esp. the Highlands of Scotland.
Aspirin: A white crystalline compound, acetyl salicylic acid (CH3.CO.O.C6H4.CO.OH) widely used as a drug for relief of pain and alleviation of fever.  It has analgesic, antipyretic, and antiinflammatory properties, and is one of a class of agents called non-steroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).  The name was originally a trade name, but has become the preferred name for the substance.  It is actually a prodrug, liberating salicylic acid, the ultimate pharmacologically active agent, in the intestines. It is more effective when taken orally than is salicylic acid, because it dissolves more readily.
Assiento: A contract or convention between Spain and other powers for furnishing negro slaves for the Spanish dominions in America, esp. the contract made with Great Britain in 1713.
Aggry: Applied to a kind of variegated glass beads of ancient manufacture; as, aggry beads are found in Ashantee and Fantee in Africa.
Atonic: A word that has no accent.
Ascension: The act of ascending; a rising; ascent.
Aretaics: The ethical theory which excludes all relations between virtue and happiness; the science of virtue; -- contrasted with eudemonics.
aerodynamic drag: the resistance caused by a gas to the motion of a solid body moving through it.  Studied in aerodynamics.
Ascaridae: a natural family of large roundworms parasitic in intestines of vertebrates.
Apostrophize: To use the rhetorical figure called apostrophe.
Accorporate: To unite; to attach; to incorporate.
Authorize: To clothe with authority, warrant, or legal power; to give a right to act; to empower; as, to authorize commissioners to settle a boundary.
abranchious: having no gills; -- same as abranchiate.
Alleviation: The act of alleviating; a lightening of weight or severity; mitigation; relief.
Archangelic: Of or pertaining to archangels; of the nature of, or resembling, an archangel.
Aspartic: Pertaining to, or derived, asparagine; as, aspartic acid.
Ant\u00e6an: Pertaining to Antæus, a giant athlete slain by Hercules.
Atheromatous: Of, pertaining to, or having the nature of, atheroma.
Apomecometer: An instrument for measuring the height of objects.
30th: coming next after the twenty-ninth in a series
Apartment: A room in a building; a division in a house, separated from others by partitions.
Agrimony: A genus of plants of the Rose family.
Amnicolist: One who lives near a river.
Armature: Armor; whatever is worn or used for the protection and defense of the body, esp. the protective outfit of some animals and plants.
Adventism: any Christian religion that believes the second coming of Christ is imminent.
Apologetic: Defending by words or arguments; said or written in defense, or by way of apology; regretfully excusing; as, an apologetic essay.
antipartticle: A fundamental particle which has the same mass as one of the common fundamental particles, but which has an opposite charge, and for which certain other of the properties (e. g. baryon number, strangeness) may be opposite to that of the normal particle.  The antiparticle to an electron is called a positron; the antiparticle to a proton is called an antiproton; the antiparticle to a neutron is called an antineutron.  When a particle and its corresponding antiparticle collide, they typically annihilate each other with the production of large quantities of energy, usually in the form of radiation.  The interaction of a proton and antiproton cause annihilation with production of mesons.
Adventist: One of a religious body, embracing several branches, who look for the proximate personal coming of Christ; -- called also Second Adventists.
Acute: To give an acute sound to; as, he acutes his rising inflection too much.
Apposite: Very applicable; well adapted; suitable or fit; relevant; pat; -- followed by to; as, this argument is very apposite to the case.
Allogamy: Fertilization of the pistil of a plant by pollen from another of the same species; cross-fertilization.
Alcanna: An oriental shrub (Lawsonia inermis) from which henna is obtained.
Appraisement: The act of setting the value; valuation by an appraiser; estimation of worth.
Arnaut: An inhabitant of Albania and neighboring mountainous regions, specif. one serving as a soldier in the Turkish army.
Agitation: The act of agitating, or the state of being agitated; the state of being moved with violence, or with irregular action; commotion; as, the sea after a storm is in agitation.
Alecost: The plant costmary, which was formerly much used for flavoring ale.
Accommodator: He who, or that which, accommodates.
alderfly: Any of numerous dark-colored neuropterous insects of the genus Sialis or allied genera. They have predaceous aquatic larvæ, which are used for bait.
Al segno: A direction for the performer to return and recommence from the sign &unr_;.
Abundant: Fully sufficient; plentiful; in copious supply; -- followed by in, rarely by with.
armband: a band worn around arm as identification or to indicate mourning.
Alestake: A stake or pole projecting from, or set up before, an alehouse, as a sign; an alepole. At the end was commonly suspended a garland, a bunch of leaves, or a “bush.”
Axiomatically: By the use of axioms; in the form of an axiom.
Ambreic: Of or pertaining to ambrein; -- said of a certain acid produced by digesting ambrein in nitric acid.
Amelioration: The act of ameliorating, or the state of being ameliorated; making or becoming better; improvement; melioration.
Abortively: In an abortive or untimely manner; immaturely; fruitlessly.
Atokous: Producing only asexual individuals, as the eggs of certain annelids.
Assessment: The act of assessing; the act of determining an amount to be paid; as, an assessment of damages, or of taxes; an assessment of the members of a club.
Autophoby: Fear of one's self; fear of being egotistical.
Ablaqueation: The act or process of laying bare the roots of trees to expose them to the air and water.
Affront\u00e9: Face to face, or front to front; facing.
Attacca: Attack at once; -- a direction at the end of a movement to show that the next is to follow immediately, without any pause.
Antisepsis: Prevention of sepsis by excluding or destroying microorganisms.
Audibility: The quality of being audible; power of being heard; audible capacity.
Anticipate: To be before in doing; to do or take before another; to preclude or prevent by prior action.
Angelet: A small gold coin formerly current in England; a half angel.
Adducent: Bringing together or towards a given point; -- a word applied to those muscles of the body which pull one part towards another. Opposed to abducent.
Alfet: A caldron of boiling water into which an accused person plunged his forearm as a test of innocence or guilt.
Anubis: An Egyptian deity, the conductor of departed spirits to judgment, represented by a human figure with the head of a jackal, dog or fox.
Antiperiodic: A remedy possessing the property of preventing the return of periodic paroxysms, or exacerbations, of disease, as in intermittent fevers.
Abolitionism: The principles or measures of abolitionists.
Appellative: A common name, in distinction from a proper name. A common name, or appellative, stands for a whole class, genus, or species of beings, or for universal ideas. Thus, tree is the name of all plants of a particular class; plant and vegetable are names of things that grow out of the earth. A proper name, on the other hand, stands for a single thing; as, Rome, Washington, Lake Erie.
Abolitionist: A person who favors the abolition of any institution, especially negro slavery.
Acinaceous: Containing seeds or stones of grapes, or grains like them.
Advancing surface: The first of two or more surfaces arranged in tandem; -- contr. with following surface, which is the rear surface.
autobahn: an expressway or superhighway in a German-speaking country.
aerospace: of or pertaining to aerospace in either sense.
Asperser: One who asperses; especially, one who vilifies another.
Apathist: One who is destitute of feeling.
Aquapuncture: The introduction of water subcutaneously for the relief of pain.
Agistment: Formerly, the taking and feeding of other men's cattle in the king's forests.
Aisled: Furnished with an aisle or aisles.
Augmentation: The act or process of augmenting, or making larger, by addition, expansion, or dilation; increase.
Accommodableness: The quality or condition of being accommodable.
Apart: Separately, in regard to space or company; in a state of separation as to place; aside.
All Fools Day: The first day of April, a day on which sportive impositions are practiced.
Asterioidea: A class of Echinodermata including the true starfishes. The rays vary in number and always have ambulacral grooves below. The body is star-shaped or pentagonal.
Alveated: Formed or vaulted like a beehive.
Am\u0153b\u00e6um: A poem in which persons are represented at speaking alternately; as the third and seventh eclogues of Virgil.
Addendum: A thing to be added; an appendix or addition.
Alosa: the genus comprising the most common varieties of shad.  It replaces the older term Clupea.  See also shad.
Ad valorem: A term used to denote a duty or charge laid upon goods, at a certain rate per cent upon their value, as stated in their invoice, -- in opposition to a specific sum upon a given quantity or number; as, an ad valorem duty of twenty per cent.
Antipyresis: The condition or state of being free from fever.
Alose: The European shad (Alosa alosa formerly Clupea alosa); -- called also allice shad or allis shad. The name is sometimes applied to the American shad (Alosa sapidissima formerly Clupea sapidissima). See Shad.
Angelology: A discourse on angels, or a body of doctrines in regard to angels.
Agaric: A fungus of the genus Agaricus, of many species, of which the common mushroom is an example.
Aper\u00e7u: A first view or glance, or the perception or estimation so obtained; an immediate apprehension or insight, appreciative rather than analytic.
angiopteris: a highly variable species (Angiopteris evecta) of very large primitive ferns of the Pacific tropical areas with high rainfall.
Astrophysical: Pertaining to the physics of astronomical science.
Abashment: The state of being abashed; confusion from shame.
Astigmatic: Affected with, or pertaining to, astigmatism; as, astigmatic eyes; also, remedying astigmatism; as, astigmatic lenses.
Abyss: A bottomless or unfathomed depth, gulf, or chasm; hence, any deep, immeasurable, and, specifically, hell, or the bottomless pit.
Attraction sphere: The central mass of the aster in mitotic cell division; centrosphere.
Amphiprostyle: Doubly prostyle; having columns at each end, but not at the sides.
Aversation: A turning from with dislike; aversion.
Application: The act of applying or laying on, in a literal sense; as, the application of emollients to a diseased limb.
Accusatory: Pertaining to, or containing, an accusation; as, an accusatory libel.
Asiatic: Of or pertaining to Asia or to its inhabitants.
Abba: Father; religious superior; -- in the Syriac, Coptic, and Ethiopic churches, a title given to the bishops, and by the bishops to the patriarch.
arctiid: a stout-bodied broad-winged moth with conspicuously striped or spotted wings; larvae are hairy caterpillars.
Abaction: Stealing cattle on a large scale.
Armenia: a country in the Caucasus, formerly a part of the Soviet Union.
Abranchiata: A group of annelids, so called because the species composing it have no special organs of respiration.
Acidulous: Slightly sour; sub-acid; sourish; as, an acidulous tincture.
Accorder: One who accords, assents, or concedes.
Acidifiable: Capable of being acidified, or converted into an acid.
Agalactia: Failure of the due secretion of milk after childbirth.
Arrearage: That which remains unpaid and overdue, after payment of a part; arrears.
Aneurism: A soft, pulsating, hollow tumor, containing blood, arising from the preternatural dilation or rupture of the coats of an artery.
Amber: To scent or flavor with ambergris; as, ambered wine.
Appreciatingly: In an appreciating manner; with appreciation.
autotomize: cause a body part to undergo autotomy.
Auditorship: The office or function of auditor.
Atazir: The influence of a star upon other stars or upon men.
Acrolith: A statue whose extremities are of stone, the trunk being generally of wood.
Aconite: The herb wolfsbane, or monkshood; -- applied to any plant of the genus Aconitum (tribe Hellebore), all the species of which are poisonous.
Anemorphilous: Fertilized by the agency of the wind; -- said of plants in which the pollen is carried to the stigma by the wind; wind-Fertilized.
Anorthic: Having unequal oblique axes; as, anorthic crystals.
Auctionary: Of or pertaining to an auction or an auctioneer.
Awful: Oppressing with fear or horror; appalling; terrible; as, an awful scene.
Avowant: The defendant in replevin, who avows the distress of the goods, and justifies the taking.
arboresque: resembling a tree in form and branching structure.
Antechapel: The outer part of the west end of a collegiate or other chapel.
Arch\u00e6ography: A description of, or a treatise on, antiquity or antiquities.
Arist: 3d sing. pres. of Arise, for ariseth.
Anarthropodous: Having no jointed legs; pertaining to Anarthropoda.
Adrogation: A kind of adoption in ancient Rome. See Arrogation.
Aut\u0153cious: Passing through all its stages on one host, as certain parasitic fungi; -- contrasted with heterœcious.
Accountability: The state of being accountable; liability to be called on to render an account; the obligation to bear the consequences for failure to perform as expected; accountableness.
Attenuant: Making thin, as fluids; diluting; rendering less dense and viscid; diluent.
Affectionate: Having affection or warm regard; loving; fond; as, an affectionate brother.
Amblygon: An obtuse-angled figure, esp. and obtuse-angled triangle.
Averted: Turned away, esp. as an expression of feeling; also, offended; unpropitious.
acetaminophen: a white crystalline compound (HO.C6H4.NH.CO.CH3) used as an analgesic and also as an antipyretic. It has molecular weight 151.16.  It is the active ingredient in the commercial analgesics Tylenol and Datril.
Averter: One who, or that which, averts.
azidothymidine: an antiviral drug, (C10H13N5O4) used in the treatment of AIDS.  It has the generic name of zidovudine.
Afflicting: Grievously painful; distressing; afflictive; as, an afflicting event. -- Af*flict"ing*ly, adv.
Acrogenous: Increasing by growth from the extremity; as, an acrogenous plant.
apiculturist: a farmer who keeps bees for their honey.
Anthropomorphology: The application to God of terms descriptive of human beings.
Atlantides: The Pleiades or seven stars, fabled to have been the daughters of Atlas.
Amess: Amice, a hood or cape. See 2d Amice.
Antivenin: The serum of blood rendered antitoxic to a venom by repeated injections of small doses of the venom; also, the component of such a serum which is antitoxic to the venom.
Alfalfa: The lucern (Medicago sativa), a leguminous plant having bluish purple cloverlike flowers, and cultivated for fodder; -- so called in California, Texas, etc.
Ameiurus: the type genus of the Ameiuridae: bullhead catfishes.
Anhelation: Short and rapid breathing; a panting; asthma.
Angina: Any inflammatory affection of the throat or faces, as the quinsy, malignant sore throat, croup, etc., especially such as tends to produce suffocation, choking, or shortness of breath.
Auditive: Of or pertaining to hearing; auditory.
activated: treated with aeration and bacteria to aid decomposition; -- of sewage
Acumen: Quickness of perception or discernment; penetration of mind; the faculty of nice discrimination.
Alligate: To tie; to unite by some tie.
Artisan: One who professes and practices some liberal art; an artist.
Apostrophe: A figure of speech by which the orator or writer suddenly breaks off from the previous method of his discourse, and addresses, in the second person, some person or thing, absent or present; as, Milton's apostrophe to Light at the beginning of the third book of “Paradise Lost.”
Anagrammatic: Pertaining to, containing, or making, an anagram.
airdrome: an airfield equipped with control tower and hangers as well as accommodations for passengers and cargo.
Adornment: An adorning; an ornament; a decoration.
Appointer: One who appoints, or executes a power of appointment.
Accosted: Supported on both sides by other charges; also, side by side.
atavistic: displaying characteristics of a previous cultural era or of a previous ancestral form; displaying atavism
\u00c6thrioscope: An instrument consisting in part of a differential thermometer. It is used for measuring changes of temperature produced by different conditions of the sky, as when clear or clouded.
Anatomize: To dissect; to cut in pieces, as an animal vegetable body, for the purpose of displaying or examining the structure and use of the several parts.
ameba: naked freshwater or marine or parasitic protozoa that form temporary pseudopods for feeding and locomotion.  Same as amoeba.
Acutorsion: The twisting of an artery with a needle to arrest hemorrhage.
Avoidable: Capable of being vacated; liable to be annulled or made invalid; voidable.
Agnatic: Pertaining to descent by the male line of ancestors.
Aristotype: Orig., a printing-out process using paper coated with silver chloride in gelatin; now, any such process using silver salts in either collodion or gelatin; also, a print so made.
Atheling: An Anglo-Saxon prince or nobleman; esp., the heir apparent or a prince of the royal family.
Acaulescent: Having no stem or caulis, or only a very short one concealed in the ground.
Alkarsin: A spontaneously inflammable liquid, having a repulsive odor, and consisting of cacodyl and its oxidation products; -- called also Cadel's fuming liquid.
Amylose: One of the starch group (C6H10O5)n of the carbohydrates; as, starch, arabin, dextrin, cellulose, etc.
Avesta: The Zoroastrian scriptures; the sacred text of Zoroastrianism. See Zend-Avesta.
American sign language: a sign language, used in the United States mostly by the deaf or for communication with the deaf, in which gestures made with the hands symbolize words, alphabetical letters, or ideas, permitting rapid communication in the absence of speech.
Aplomb: Assurance of manner or of action; self-possession.
Ant\u0153ci: Those who live under the same meridian, but on opposite parallels of latitude, north and south of the equator.
Analogical: Founded on, or of the nature of, analogy; expressing or implying analogy.
Afford: To give forth; to supply, yield, or produce as the natural result, fruit, or issue; as, grapes afford wine; olives afford oil; the earth affords fruit; the sea affords an abundant supply of fish.
Autumnal: Of, belonging to, or peculiar to, autumn; as, an autumnal tint; produced or gathered in autumn; as, autumnal fruits; flowering in autumn; as, an autumnal plant.
Affinal: Related by marriage; from the same source.
Anthesis: The period or state of full expansion in a flower.
all-powerful: having full power over all aspects of a situation.
Avouchment: The act of avouching; positive declaration.
autogyro: an aircraft that is supported in flight by unpowered rotating horizontal wings (or blades); forward propulsion is provided by a conventional propeller.
Animalism: The state, activity, or enjoyment of animals; mere animal life without intellectual or moral qualities or objectives; preoccupation with sensual, physical, or carnal pleasures.
Astringency: The quality of being astringent; the power of contracting the parts of the body; that quality in medicines or other substances which causes contraction of the organic textures; as, the astringency of tannin.
Alexandrine: A kind of verse consisting in English of twelve syllables.
Aliner: One who adjusts things to a line or lines or brings them into line.
Associated: Joined as a companion; brought into association; accompanying; combined.
Albite: A mineral of the feldspar family, triclinic in crystallization, and in composition a silicate of alumina and soda. It is a common constituent of granite and of various igneous rocks. See Feldspar.
atrioventricular: relating to or affecting the atria and ventricles of the heart.
alstroemeria: any of various South American plants of the genus Alstroemeria valued for their handsome umbels of beautiful flowers.
Aggrandizer: One who aggrandizes, or makes great.
Auletic: Of or pertaining to a pipe (flute) or piper.
Abbey: A monastery or society of persons of either sex, secluded from the world and devoted to religion and celibacy; also, the monastic building or buildings.
Atonement: Reconciliation; restoration of friendly relations; agreement; concord.
Agonizingly: With extreme anguish or desperate struggles.
Accountancy: The art or employment of an accountant.
Agavaceae: a natural family of chiefly tropical and xerophytic plants: includes Dracenaceae (Dracaenaceae); comprises plants that in some classifications are divided between the Amaryllidaceae and the Liliaceae.
auto-changer: an automatic device on a record player that causes new records to be played without manual intervention.
August: The eighth month of the year, containing thirty-one days.
Anglo-Saxonism: A characteristic of the Anglo-Saxon race; especially, a word or an idiom of the Anglo-Saxon tongue.
Altar: A raised structure (as a square or oblong erection of stone or wood) on which sacrifices are offered or incense burned to a deity.
Araneae: an order of arthropods constituting the spiders.
\u00c6olian: Of or pertaining to Æolia or Æolis, in Asia Minor, colonized by the Greeks, or to its inhabitants; æolic; as, the Æolian dialect.
Abreuvoir: The joint or interstice between stones, to be filled with mortar.
Attempter: One who attempts; one who essays anything.
Apprehensible: Capable of being apprehended or conceived.
At one: In concord or friendship; in agreement (with each other); as, to be, bring, make, or set, at one, i. e., to be or bring in or to a state of agreement or reconciliation.
Absumption: Act of wasting away; a consuming; extinction.
Arrowwood: A shrub (Viburnum dentatum) growing in damp woods and thickets; -- so called from the long, straight, slender shoots.  Also, any of several other similar small trees whose straight shoots were used for making arrows.
Abiogenesis: The supposed origination of living organisms from lifeless matter; such genesis as does not involve the action of living parents; spontaneous generation; -- called also abiogeny, and opposed to biogenesis.
Ante-: A Latin preposition and prefix; akin to Gr. 'anti`, Skr. anti, Goth. and-, anda- (only in comp.), AS. and-, ond-, (only in comp.: cf. Answer, Along), G. ant-, ent- (in comp.). The Latin ante is generally used in the sense of before, in regard to position, order, or time, and the Gr. 'anti` in that of opposite, or in the place of.
Acipenseridae: The natural family of fish including the sturgeons.
Angleworm: A earthworm of the genus Lumbricus, frequently used by anglers for bait. See Earthworm.
Abracadabra: A mystical word or collocation of letters written as in the figure. Worn on an amulet it was supposed to ward off fever. At present the word is used chiefly in jest to denote something without meaning; jargon.
Avoider: The person who carries anything away, or the vessel in which things are carried away.
Anilic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, anil; indigotic; -- applied to an acid formed by the action of nitric acid on indigo.
Anadromous: Ascending rivers from the sea, at certain seasons, for breeding, as the salmon, shad, etc.
Adapid: extinct small mostly diurnal lower primates that fed on leaves and fruit; abundant in North America and Europe 30 to 50 million years ago; their descendents probably include the lemurs and lorises; some authorities consider them ancestral to anthropoids but others consider them only cousins.
Aground: On the ground; stranded; -- a nautical term applied to a ship when its bottom lodges on the ground.
Accessorily: In the manner of an accessory; auxiliary.
Appurtenance: That which belongs to something else; an adjunct; an appendage; an accessory; something annexed to another thing more worthy; in common parlance and legal acceptation, something belonging to another thing as principal, and which passes as incident to it, as a right of way, or other easement to land; a right of common to pasture, an outhouse, barn, garden, or orchard, to a house or messuage. In a strict legal sense, land can never pass as an appurtenance to land.
Antibubonic: Good or used against bubonic plague; as, antibubonic serum, obtained from immunized horses; antibubonic vaccine, a sterilized bouillon culture of the plague bacillus; antibubonic measures.
Armamentary: An armory; a magazine or arsenal.
Anamnestic: Aiding the memory; as, anamnestic remedies.
Adumbrant: Giving a faint shadow, or slight resemblance; shadowing forth.
atar: essential oil or perfume obtained from flowers.
Atramental: Of or pertaining to ink; inky; black, like ink; as, atramental galls; atramentous spots.
Anthropologic: Pertaining to anthropology; belonging to the nature of man.
apothecial: of or pertaining to the apothecium.
Angular: A bone in the base of the lower jaw of many birds, reptiles, and fishes.
Anaptychus: One of a pair of shelly plates found in some cephalopods, as the ammonites.
Acanthocephalous: Having a spiny head, as one of the Acanthocephala.
Attention: The act or state of attending or heeding; the application of the mind to any object of sense, representation, or thought; notice; exclusive or special consideration; earnest consideration, thought, or regard; obedient or affectionate heed; the supposed power or faculty of attending.
archeologist: an anthropologist who studies prehistoric people and their culture.
Androspore: A spore of some algæ, which has male functions.
Adoration: The act of playing honor to a divine being; the worship paid to God; the act of addressing as a god.
Alternat: A usage, among diplomats, of rotation in precedence among representatives of equal rank, sometimes determined by lot and at other times in regular order. The practice obtains in the signing of treaties and conventions between nations.
Anomaliped: One of a group of perching birds, having the middle toe more or less united to the outer and inner ones.
Authotype: A type or block containing a facsimile of an autograph.
Advisability: The quality of being advisable; advisableness.
Assish: Resembling an ass; asinine; stupid or obstinate.
adobe-lily: a California herb (Fritillaria pluriflora) with pinkish purple flowers.
attentiveness: the quality of paying careful attention; attentiveness to detail.
Appose: To put questions to; to examine; to try. [Obs.] See Pose.
Acerb: Sour, bitter, and harsh to the taste, as unripe fruit; sharp and harsh.
Alvine: Of, from, in, or pertaining to, the belly or the intestines; as, alvine discharges; alvine concretions.
Aboard: On board of; as, to go aboard a ship.
arriving: directed or moving inward or toward a center; as, arriving trains.
Antimetathesis: An antithesis in which the members are repeated in inverse order.
Araucaria: A genus of tall conifers of the pine family. The species are confined mostly to South America and Australia. The wood cells differ from those of other in having the dots in their lateral surfaces in two or three rows, and the dots of contiguous rows alternating. The seeds are edible.
Apprehend: To think, believe, or be of opinion; to understand; to suppose.
Algologist: One learned about algæ; a student of algology.
Anticipatory: Forecasting; of the nature of anticipation.
Amboyna pine: The resiniferous tree Agathis Dammara, of the Moluccas.
Asteraceae: a family of plants with heads composed of many florets, including the aster; daisy; dandelion; goldenrod; marigold; lettuces; ragweed; sunflower; thistle; zinnia.
Approachability: The quality of being approachable; approachableness.
Alicyclic: pertaining to compounds that have a ring in the structure, but are not aromatic, as cyclohexane or cyclohexene. Compare aliphatic and aromatic.
Adventual: Relating to the season of advent.
Agamous: Having no visible sexual organs; asexual.
Aquatint: A kind of etching in which spaces are bitten by the use of aqua fortis, by which an effect is produced resembling a drawing in water colors or India ink; also, the engraving produced by this method.
Abactor: One who steals and drives away cattle or beasts by herds or droves.
-ancy: A suffix expressing more strongly than -ance the idea of quality or state; as, constancy, buoyancy, infancy.
Anserated: Having the extremities terminate in the heads of eagles, lions, etc.; as, an anserated cross.
Apostolic: A member of one of certain ascetic sects which at various times professed to imitate the practice of the apostles.
Antholite: A fossil plant, like a petrified flower.
An\u00e6sthetize: To render insensible by an anæsthetic.
Adjudgment: The act of adjudging; judicial decision; adjudication.
Article: To agree by articles; to stipulate; to bargain; to covenant.
Abietite: A substance resembling mannite, found in the needles of the common silver fir of Europe (Abies pectinata).
Anecdotage: Anecdotes collectively; a collection of anecdotes.
Asphalt: To cover with asphalt; as, to asphalt a roof; asphalted streets.
Abstracted: Separated or disconnected; withdrawn; removed; apart.
Air-slacked: Slacked, or pulverized, by exposure to the air; as, air-slacked lime.
Abstracter: One who abstracts, or makes an abstract.
Attractability: The quality or fact of being attractable.
Austronesia: the area comprising the islands of central and S Pacific (Indonesia and Melanesia and Micronesia and Polynesia).
Anosmia: Loss of the sense of smell.
autocoid: any physiologically active internal secretion, especially one of uncertain classification.
Admixtion: A mingling of different things; admixture.
Arbor: A tree, as distinguished from a shrub.
Ash-fire: A low fire used in chemical operations.
Algonquian: Pertaining to or designating the most extensive of the linguistic families of North American Indians, their territory formerly including practically all of Canada east of the 115th meridian and south of Hudson's Bay and the part of the United States east of the Mississippi and north of Tennessee and Virginia, with the exception of the territory occupied by the northern Iroquoian tribes. There are nearly 100,000 Indians of the Algonquian tribes, of which the strongest are the Ojibwas (Chippewas), Ottawas, Crees, Algonquins, Micmacs, and Blackfeet.
Aliquot: An aliquot part of a number or quantity is one which will divide it without a remainder; thus, 5 is an aliquot part of 15. Opposed to aliquant.
2: denoting a quantity consisting of one more than one; one plus one more; -- representing the number two as an Arabic numeral
Amice: A hood, or cape with a hood, made of lined with gray fur, formerly worn by the clergy; -- written also amess, amyss, and almuce.
Anglo-: A combining form meaning the same as English; or English and, or English conjoined with; as, Anglo-Turkish treaty, Anglo-German, Anglo-Irish.
affirmative action: a policy of making active efforts to improve the employment or educational opportunities available to members of minority groups or women; -- achieved by employers or schools by using various techniques, but excluding the use of simple quotas or outright discrimination against white males.
Anthropoglot: An animal which has a tongue resembling that of man, as the parrot.
Africanize: To place under the domination of Africans or negroes.
Additament: An addition, or a thing added.
arui: a wild sheep (Ammotragus lervia) of northern Africa, having a thick mane on the throat, chest, and forelegs; -- also called the aoudad and Barbary sheep.
Austrocedrus: a genus having but one species; formerly included in genus Libocedrus.
Alb: A vestment of white linen, reaching to the feet, an enveloping the person; -- in the Roman Catholic church, worn by those in holy orders when officiating at mass. It was formerly worn, at least by clerics, in daily life.
animalisation: an act that makes people cruel or lacking normal human qualities.
alocasia: any plant of the genus Alocasia having large showy basal leaves and boat-shaped spathe and reddish berries.
Abstractively: In a abstract manner; separately; in or by itself.
Arboreal: Of or pertaining to a tree, or to trees; of nature of trees.
Aforesaid: Said before, or in a preceding part; already described or identified.
Anox\u00e6mia: An abnormal condition due to deficient aëration of the blood, as in balloon sickness, mountain sickness.
Anisometropia: Unequal refractive power in the two eyes.
Aleatory: Depending on some uncertain contingency; as, an aleatory contract.
Annul: To reduce to nothing; to obliterate.
Annumerate: To add on; to count in.
avaritia: A reprehensible acquisitiveness; insatiable desire for wealth (personified as one of the deadly sins); avarice; greed.
Anker: A liquid measure in various countries of Europe. The Dutch anker, formerly also used in England, contained about 10 of the old wine gallons, or 81/2 imperial gallons.
Anthodium: The inflorescence of a compound flower in which many florets are gathered into a involucrate head.
Auditorium: The part of a church, theater, or other public building, assigned to the audience.
Archaize: To make appear archaic or antique.
Aphotic region: A depth of water so great that only those organisms can exist that do not assimilate.
Amplifier: One who or that which amplifies.
Adelphous: Having coalescent or clustered filaments; -- said of stamens; as, adelphous stamens. Usually in composition; as, monadelphous.
Anthropid\u00e6: The group that includes man only.
archy: A suffix properly meaning a rule, ruling, as in monarchy, the rule of one only. Cf. -arch.
Anaclastic: Produced by the refraction of light, as seen through water; as, anaclastic curves.
Attrition: The act of rubbing together; friction; the act of wearing by friction, or by rubbing substances together; abrasion.
Array: To place or dispose in order, as troops for battle; to marshal.
Asperity: Roughness of surface; unevenness; -- opposed to smoothness.
Ascent: The act of rising; motion upward; rise; a mounting upward; as, he made a tedious ascent; the ascent of vapors from the earth.
accented: having the main stress of a word; -- used of syllables
Attemperament: A tempering, or mixing in due proportion.
Autopathic: Dependent upon, or due or relating to, the structure and characteristics of the diseased organism; endopathic; as, an autopathic disease; an autopathic theory of diseases.
Asparaginous: Pertaining or allied to, or resembling, asparagus; having shoots which are eaten like asparagus; as, asparaginous vegetables.
Artlessness: The quality of being artless, or void of art or guile; simplicity; sincerity.
Arciform: Having the form of an arch; curved.
Adit: An entrance or passage. Specifically: The nearly horizontal opening by which a mine is entered, or by which water and ores are carried away; -- called also drift and tunnel.
Arnicin: An active principle of Arnica montana. It is a bitter resin.
Adhortatory: Containing counsel or warning; hortatory; advisory.
Andira: small genus of evergreen trees of tropical America and West Africa.
Asura: An enemy of the gods, esp. one of a race of demons and giants.
Athletism: The state or practice of an athlete; the characteristics of an athlete.
Archiepiscopality: The station or dignity of an archbishop; archiepiscopacy.
Assets: Property of a deceased person, subject by law to the payment of his debts and legacies; -- called assets because sufficient to render the executor or administrator liable to the creditors and legatees, so far as such goods or estate may extend.
Ablegate: A representative of the pope charged with important commissions in foreign countries, one of his duties being to bring to a newly named cardinal his insignia of office.
Agraphia: The absence or loss of the power of expressing ideas by written signs. It is one form of aphasia.
Alfenide: An alloy of nickel and silver electroplated with silver.
Admiralty: The office or jurisdiction of an admiral.
Abyssal: Belonging to, or resembling, an abyss; unfathomable.
Arundelian: Pertaining to an Earl of Arundel; as, Arundel or Arundelian marbles, marbles from ancient Greece, bought by the Earl of Arundel in 1624.
Afghanistani: a native or inhabitant of Afghanistan.
16th: coming next after the fifteenth in a series
Azole: Any of a large class of compounds characterized by a five-membered ring which contains an atom of nitrogen and at least one other noncarbon atom (nitrogen, oxygen, sulphur). The prefixes furo-, thio, and pyrro- are used to distinguish three subclasses of azoles, which may be regarded as derived respectively from furfuran, thiophene, and pyrrol by replacement of the CH group by nitrogen; as, furo-monazole. Names exactly analogous to those for the azines are also used; as, oxazole, diazole, etc.
Alcoholometric: Relating to the alcoholometer or alcoholometry.
Abatable: Capable of being abated; as, an abatable writ or nuisance.
Asbestine: Of or pertaining to asbestus, or partaking of its nature; incombustible; asbestic.
archaeornis: an extinct primitive toothed bird with a long feathered tail and three free clawed digits on each wing.
Aleutians: an archipelago in the North Pacific extending southwest from Alaska.
Amylometer: Instrument for determining the amount of starch in a substance.
Armory: A place where arms and instruments of war are deposited for safe keeping.
Anti-American: Opposed to the Americans, their aims, or interests, or to the genius of American institutions.
Alterability: The quality of being alterable; alterableness.
Apprize: To appraise; to value; to appreciate.
Acoumeter: An instrument for measuring the acuteness of the sense of hearing.
After-wit: Wisdom or perception that comes after it can be of use.
Awn: The bristle or beard of barley, oats, grasses, etc., or any similar bristlelike appendage; arista.
Anorthite: A mineral of the feldspar family, commonly occurring in small glassy crystals, also a constituent of some igneous rocks. It is a lime feldspar. See Feldspar.
alkalosis: abnormally high alkalinity in the blood and other body fluids.
Arapaima: A large fresh-water food fish of South America.
Atter: Poison; venom; corrupt matter from a sore.
Accumbency: The state of being accumbent or reclining.
Ash Wednesday: The first day of Lent; -- so called from a custom in the Roman Catholic church of putting ashes, on that day, upon the foreheads of penitents.
Accommodate: Suitable; fit; adapted; as, means accommodate to end.
Acrid: Sharp and harsh, or bitter and not, to the taste; pungent; as, acrid salts.
Amativeness: The faculty supposed to influence sexual desire; propensity to love.
Arkose: A sandstone derived from the disintegration of granite or gneiss, and characterized by feldspar fragments.
amateurishness: Behavior that demonstrates a lack of professional competency.
Arrow grass: An herbaceous grasslike plant (Triglochin palustre, and other species) with pods opening so as to suggest barbed arrowheads.
Acroclinium: a genus of herbs and shrubs of Australia and Southern Africa, with an everlasting flower; most species are usually placed in genus Helipterum.
Amphic\u0153lian: Having both ends concave; biconcave; -- said of vertebræ.
Animadversal: The faculty of perceiving; a percipient.
Aleppo grass: One of the cultivated forms of Andropogon Halepensis (syn. Sorghum Halepense). See Andropogon, below.
A\u00ebrate: To combine or charge with gas; usually with carbonic acid gas, formerly called fixed air.
Agonism: Contention for a prize; a contest.
Acorn cup: The involucre or cup in which the acorn is fixed.
Anaglyptographic: Of or pertaining to anaglyptography; as, anaglyptographic engraving.
Ancipital: Two-edged instead of round; -- said of certain flattened stems, as those of blue grass, and rarely also of leaves.
Accension: The act of kindling or the state of being kindled; ignition.
Angelhood: The state of being an angel; angelic nature.
Autophagy: The feeding of the body upon itself, as in fasting; nutrition by consumption of one's own tissues.
Adjuster: One who, or that which, adjusts.
Autophagi: Birds which are able to run about and obtain their own food as soon as hatched.
Album: A white tablet on which anything was inscribed, as a list of names, etc.
Accurse: To devote to destruction; to imprecate misery or evil upon; to curse; to execrate; to anathematize.
Archimandrite: A chief of a monastery, corresponding to abbot in the Roman Catholic church.
Apheliotropic: Turning away from the sun; -- said of leaves, etc.
Aggravating: Making worse or more heinous; as, aggravating circumstances.
Airy: Consisting of air; as, an airy substance; the airy parts of bodies.
Admiral: A naval officer of the highest rank; a naval officer of high rank, of which there are different grades. The chief gradations in rank are admiral, vice admiral, and rear admiral. The admiral is the commander in chief of a fleet or of fleets.
Anglo-Catholic: A member of the Church of England who contends for its catholic character; more specifically, a High Churchman.
Archipterygium: The primitive form of fin, like that of Ceratodus.
Apocrypha: Something, as a writing, that is of doubtful authorship or authority; -- formerly used also adjectively.
Acanthocarpous: Having the fruit covered with spines.
Apartment house: A building comprising a number of lving units (apartments{4}) designed for separate housekeeping tenements, but having conveniences, such as heat, light, elevator service, etc., furnished in common; contrasted to a detached dwelling.  Sometimes distinguished in the United States from a flat house, in which each living unit comprises one entire floor, whereas in an apartment house a floor may be partitioned into any number of apartments{4}.
Apair: To impair or become impaired; to injure.
Arose: The past or preterit tense of Arise.
Acetification: The act of making acetous or sour; the process of converting, or of becoming converted, into vinegar.
amphiprostylar: having columns at both ends but not on the sides.
anointment: The act of anointing, or state of being anointed; also, an ointment.
Anatifa: An animal of the barnacle tribe, of the genus Lepas, having a fleshy stem or peduncle; a goose barnacle. See Cirripedia.
aneurin: same as thiamin; a B vitamin (vitamin B1) that prevents beriberi.
-ably: A suffix composed of -able and the adverbial suffix -ly; as, favorably.
-able: An adjective suffix now usually in a passive sense; able to be; fit to be; expressing capacity or worthiness in a passive sense; as, movable, able to be moved; amendable, able to be amended; blamable, fit to be blamed; salable.
Absorbability: The state or quality of being absorbable.
Apolar: Having no radiating processes; -- applied particularly to certain nerve cells.
Acceleration: The act of accelerating, or the state of being accelerated; increase of motion or action; as, a falling body moves toward the earth with an acceleration of velocity; -- opposed to retardation.
Anticivism: Opposition to the body politic of citizens.
Antipathetic: Having a natural contrariety, or constitutional aversion, to a thing; characterized by antipathy; -- often followed by to.
Ancestor: One from whom a person is descended, whether on the father's or mother's side, at any distance of time; a progenitor; a fore father.
Aurin: A red coloring matter derived from phenol; -- called also, in commerce, yellow corallin.
Advice: An opinion recommended or offered, as worthy to be followed; counsel.
Approver: A bailiff or steward; an agent.
archesporial: of or pertaining to an archespore.
Athleticism: The practice of engaging in athletic games; athletism.
Anonymous: Nameless; of unknown name; also, of unknown or unavowed authorship; as, an anonymous benefactor; an anonymous pamphlet or letter.
alarmism: the act of giving, or tendency to give, needless warnings.
Annotation: A note, added by way of comment, or explanation; -- usually in the plural; as, annotations on ancient authors, or on a word or a passage.
Artemisia: A genus of plants including the plants called mugwort, southernwood, and wormwood. Of these Artemisia absinthium, or common wormwood, is well known, and Artemisia tridentata is the sage brush of the Rocky Mountain region.
Affiche: A written or printed notice to be posted, as on a wall; a poster; a placard.
Adjournment: The act of adjourning; the putting off till another day or time specified, or without day.
Aptness: Fitness; suitableness; appropriateness; as, the aptness of things to their end.
Aunt: The sister of one's father or mother; -- correlative to nephew or niece. Also applied to an uncle's wife.
Amplitude: State of being ample; extent of surface or space; largeness of dimensions; size.
Asceticism: The condition, practice, or mode of life, of ascetics.
Annexment: The act of annexing, or the thing annexed; appendage.
Altaian: Of or pertaining to the Altai, a mountain chain in Central Asia.
Arrantly: Notoriously, in an ill sense; infamously; impudently; shamefully.
Artillery: Munitions of war; implements for warfare, as slings, bows, and arrows.
Anticous: Facing toward the axis of the flower, as in the introrse anthers of the water lily.
Abrogate: To annul by an authoritative act; to abolish by the authority of the maker or his successor; to repeal; -- applied to the repeal of laws, decrees, ordinances, the abolition of customs, etc.
Appellee: The defendant in an appeal; -- opposed to appellant.
Alkalescent: Tending to the properties of an alkali; slightly alkaline.
Axunge: Fat; grease; esp. the fat of pigs or geese;
Allomorphism: The property which constitutes an allomorph; the change involved in becoming an allomorph.
Astyllen: A small dam to prevent free passage of water in an adit or level.
23rd: coming next after the twenty-second in a series
Ascaphidae: a natural family containing only one species of frog: the tailed frog.
Areometry: The art or process of measuring the specific gravity of fluids.
Apron man: A man who wears an apron; a laboring man; a mechanic.
Aeolian: a member of one of the four divisions of the prehistoric Greeks.
Authorless: Without an author; without authority; anonymous.
Arthropoda: A large division of Articulata, embracing all those that have jointed legs. It includes Insects, Arachnida, Pychnogonida, and Crustacea.
Attractor: One who, or that which, attracts.
Antisabbatarian: One of a sect which opposes the observance of the Christian Sabbath.
ace: to get a grade of "A"; as, to ace an exam.
Almagra: A fine, deep red ocher, somewhat purplish, found in Spain. It is the sil atticum of the ancients. Under the name of Indian red it is used for polishing glass and silver.
\u00c6gicrania: Sculptured ornaments, used in classical architecture, representing rams' heads or skulls.
Actinostome: The mouth or anterior opening of a cœlenterate animal.
Advancement: The act of advancing, or the state of being advanced; progression; improvement; furtherance; promotion to a higher place or dignity; as, the advancement of learning.
accumulated: brought together into a group or crowd
Apitpat: With quick beating or palpitation; pitapat.
Air poise: An instrument to measure the weight of air.
An t: An it, that is, and it or if it. See An, conj.
Alternately: In reciprocal succession; succeeding by turns; in alternate order.
Alphitomancy: Divination by means of barley meal.
Alcyonium: A genus of fleshy Alcyonaria, its polyps somewhat resembling flowers with eight fringed rays. The term was also formerly used for certain species of sponges.
Anthobranchia: A division of nudibranchiate Mollusca, in which the gills form a wreath or cluster upon the posterior part of the back. See Nudibranchiata, and Doris.
Agnation: Consanguinity by a line of males only, as distinguished from cognation.
amenia: absence or suppression of normal menstrual flow.
araneidal: relating to or resembling a spider.
Alternating current: A current which periodically changes or reverses its direction of flow, especially an electric current that reverses direction sinusoidally, as is used for most domestic and industrial power requirements.  Contrasted with direct curent.
Apagogic: Proving indirectly, by showing the absurdity, or impossibility of the contrary.
articulatio: the point of connection between two bones or elements of a skeleton especially if the articulatio allows motion.
A\u00ebriality: The state of being aërial; unsubstantiality.
Atheneum: A temple of Athene, at Athens, in which scholars and poets were accustomed to read their works and instruct students.
accoutered: provided with necessary articles of equipment for a specialized purpose especially military; as, troops accoutered for battle
Anatiferous: Producing ducks; -- applied to Anatifæ, under the absurd notion of their turning into ducks or geese. See Barnacle.
Acephali: A fabulous people reported by ancient writers to have heads.
Acephala: That division of the Mollusca which includes the bivalve shells, like the clams and oysters; -- so called because they have no evident head. Formerly the group included the Tunicata, Brachiopoda, and sometimes the Bryozoa. See Mollusca.
Apollinarian: A follower of Apollinaris, Bishop of Laodicea in the fourth century, who denied the proper humanity of Christ.
aplacophoran: one of the aplacophora;  a deep-water wormlike mollusk lacking calcareous plates on the body but having fine limy spicules on the covering mantle.
Astringent: A medicine or other substance that produces contraction in the soft organic textures, and checks discharges of blood, mucus, etc.
Antistrophic: Of or pertaining to an antistrophe.
Atlantic: Of or pertaining to Mt. Atlas in Libya, and hence applied to the ocean which lies between Europe and Africa on the east and America on the west; as, the Atlantic Ocean (called also the Atlantic); the Atlantic basin; the Atlantic telegraph.
\u00c6sthetic: Of or Pertaining to æsthetics; versed in æsthetics; as, æsthetic studies, emotions, ideas, persons, etc.
Amputate: To prune or lop off, as branches or tendrils.
Aldermanry: The district or ward of an alderman.
Autopsorin: That which is given under the doctrine of administering a patient's own virus.
Alteration: The act of altering or making different.
Alem: The imperial standard of the Turkish Empire.
Alee: On or toward the lee, or the side away from the wind; the opposite of aweather. The helm of a ship is alee when pressed close to the lee side.
Acrania: Partial or total absence of the skull.
Audile: One whose thoughts take the form of mental sounds or of internal discourse rather than of visual or motor images.
atonicity: lack of normal muscular tension or tonus.
airbed: A sack or mattress inflated with air, and used as a bed.
Absorbing: Swallowing, engrossing; as, an absorbing pursuit.
Alouatta: One of the several species of howling monkeys of South America. See Howler{2}.
Agnostic: One who professes ignorance, or denies that we have any knowledge, save of phenomena; one who supports agnosticism, neither affirming nor denying the existence of a personal Deity, a future life, etc.
Arthropomata: One of the orders of Branchiopoda. See Branchiopoda.
Apothegmatize: To utter apothegms, or short and sententious sayings.
Actualize: To make actual; to realize in action.
Ad hominem: A phrase applied to an appeal or argument addressed to the principles, interests, or passions of a man.
After-note: One of the small notes occur on the unaccented parts of the measure, taking their time from the preceding note.
Abdicate: To relinquish or renounce a throne, or other high office or dignity.
Alterity: The state or quality of being other; a being otherwise.
Assagai: A spear used by tribes in South Africa as a missile and for stabbing, a kind of light javelin.
Axle box: A bushing in the hub of a wheel, through which the axle passes.
Artsman: A man skilled in an art or in arts.
Anachronistic: Erroneous in date; containing an anachronism.
Ambages: A circuit; a winding. Hence: Circuitous way or proceeding; quibble; circumlocution; indirect mode of speech.
Advisable: Proper to be advised or to be done; expedient; prudent.
17th: coming next after the sixteenth in a series
Altimeter: An instrument for taking altitudes, as a quadrant, sextant, etc.
Associable: Capable of being associated or joined.
Attractivity: The quality or degree of attractive power.
Areolar: Pertaining to, or like, an areola; filled with interstices or areolæ.
Argean: Pertaining to the ship Argo. See Argo.
ASCII: the American Standard Code for Information Interchange, a code consisting of a set of 128 7-bit combinations used in digital computers internally, for display purposes, and for exchanging data between computers.  It is very widely used, but because of the limited number of characters encoded must be supplemented or replaced by other codes for encoding special symbols or words in languages other than English.  Also used attributively; -- as, an ASCII file.
antibiotic: of or pertaining to an antibiotic.
A\u00ebrobus: An aëroplane or airship designed to carry passengers. Now called a passenger plane or commercial airliner.
Ambilevous: Left-handed on both sides; clumsy; -- opposed to ambidexter.
Affectional: Of or pertaining to the affections; as, affectional impulses; an affectional nature.
Acclimatize: To inure or habituate to a climate different from that which is natural; to adapt to the peculiarities of a foreign or strange climate; said of man, the inferior animals, or plants.
Aphid: One of the genus Aphis; an aphidian.
Apprehensively: In an apprehensive manner; with apprehension of danger.
Alalia: Inability to utter articulate sounds, due either to paralysis of the larynx or to that form of aphasia, called motor, or ataxis, aphasia, due to loss of control of the muscles of speech.
Aphis: A genus of insects belonging to the order Hemiptera and family Aphidæ, including numerous species known as plant lice and green flies.
Atlas powder: A blasting powder or dynamite composed of nitroglycerin, wood fiber, sodium nitrate, and magnesium carbonate.
Alpha rays: Rays of relatively low penetrating power emitted by radium and other radioactive substances, and shown to consist of positively charged alpha particles (helium nuclei) having enormous velocities but small masses. They are slightly deflected by a strong magnetic or electric field.  Compare beta ray and gamma ray.  Because the rays penetrate only a small distance in dense matter such as living tissue, small pellets of radioactive substances emitting alpha rays have been used to cause local destruction of tissue, as in cancer therapy.
Abuse: Improper treatment or use; application to a wrong or bad purpose; misuse; as, an abuse of our natural powers; an abuse of civil rights, or of privileges or advantages; an abuse of language.
Anthracitic: Of, pertaining to, or like, anthracite; as, anthracitic formations.
Albumenize: To cover or saturate with albumen; to coat or treat with an albuminous solution; as, to albumenize paper.
Armeria: a genus of shrubby or herbaceous low-growing evergreen perennials.
Anthropomorphous: Having the figure of, or resemblance to, a man; as, an anthropomorphous plant.
Arabesqued: Ornamented in the style of arabesques.
-ard: The termination of many English words; as, coward, reynard, drunkard, mostly from the French, in which language this ending is of German origin, being orig. the same word as English hard. It usually has the sense of one who has to a high or excessive degree the quality expressed by the root; as, braggart, sluggard.
Aepyorniformes: huge extinct flightless birds: elephant birds.
Asilus: A genus of large and voracious two-winged flies, including the bee killer and robber fly.
Affray: The act of suddenly disturbing any one; an assault or attack.
Arrogant: Making, or having the disposition to make, exorbitant claims of rank or estimation; giving one's self an undue degree of importance; assuming; haughty; -- applied to persons.
Alsatian: An inhabitant of Alsatia or Alsace in Germany, or of Alsatia or White Friars (a resort of debtors and criminals) in London.
amarelle: any of several varieties of cultivated sour cherry trees of the species Prunus cerasus bearing fruit with colorless juice, e.g. Prunus cerasus caproniana.
Astarte: A genus of bivalve mollusks, common on the coasts of America and Europe.
Auf: A changeling or elf child, -- that is, one left by fairies; a deformed or foolish child; a simpleton; an oaf.
Alfione: An edible marine fish of California (Rhacochilus toxotes).
Adosculation: Impregnation by external contact, without intromission.
Agastric: Having to stomach, or distinct digestive canal, as the tapeworm.
Aphthoid: Of the nature of aphthæ; resembling thrush.
Armadillo: Any edentate animal if the family Dasypidæ, peculiar to America. The body and head are incased in an armor composed of small bony plates. The armadillos burrow in the earth, seldom going abroad except at night. When attacked, they curl up into a ball, presenting the armor on all sides. Their flesh is good food. There are several species, one of which (the peba) is found as far north as Texas. See Peba, Poyou, Tatouay.
archives: a collection of records especially about an institution.
automate: make automatic; to change [a process] so that it is mostly automatic; to substitute machinery for human labor in an activity.
6: one more than five; denoting a quantity consisting of six items or units; -- representing the number six as an Arabic numeral
Agminate: Grouped together; as, the agminated glands of Peyer in the small intestine.
Apodeme: One of the processes of the shell which project inwards and unite with one another, in the thorax of many Crustacea.
actinomycin D: The most well-known of the actinomycins (C62H86N12O16), a class of antibiotics which act by binding to DNA and inhibiting synthesis of RNA; they act agains gram-positive bacteria and many eukaryotic organisma.  Actinomycin D has been used in human medicine to treat certain tumors.
Apostematous: Pertaining to, or partaking of the nature of, an aposteme.
Algebraize: To perform by algebra; to reduce to algebraic form.
Arcuate: Bent or curved in the form of a bow.
Ave Maria: A salutation and prayer to the Virgin Mary, as mother of God; -- used in the Roman Catholic church.
Agitato: Sung or played in a restless, hurried, and spasmodic manner.
