Aphemia: Loss of the power of speaking, while retaining the power of writing; -- a disorder of cerebral origin.
Amaryllidaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, an order of plants differing from the lily family chiefly in having the ovary below the petals. The narcissus and daffodil are members of this family.
Anarchy: Absence of government; the state of society where there is no law or supreme power; a state of lawlessness; political confusion.
Arcual: Of or pertaining to an arc.
Approbate: To express approbation of; to approve; to sanction officially.
antagonists: muscles having opposite effects; the contraction of one neutralizes the contraction of the other.
Agamogenetic: Reproducing or produced without sexual union.
Apogamy: The formation of a bud in place of a fertilized ovule or oöspore.
Aquamarine: A transparent, pale green variety of beryl, used as a gem. See Beryl.
Amygdalaceous: Akin to, or derived from, the almond.
Acropolis: The upper part, or the citadel, of a Grecian city; especially, the citadel of Athens.
Anthroposcopy: The art of discovering or judging of a man's character, passions. and inclinations from a study of his visible features.
anti-abortionist: a person who is opposed to legal voluntary abortion.
Astriction: The act of binding; restriction; also, obligation.
Abdomen: The belly, or that part of the body between the thorax and the pelvis. Also, the cavity of the belly, which is lined by the peritoneum, and contains the stomach, bowels, and other viscera. In man, often restricted to the part between the diaphragm and the commencement of the pelvis, the remainder being called the pelvic cavity.
Apsis: One of the two points of an orbit, as of a planet or satellite, which are at the greatest and least distance from the central body, corresponding to the aphelion and perihelion of a planet, or to the apogee and perigee of the moon. The more distant is called the higher apsis; the other, the lower apsis; and the line joining them, the line of apsides.
automotive: of or pertaining to the automobile.
Amphistomous: Having a sucker at each extremity, as certain entozoa, by means of which they adhere.
A\u00ebrification: The act of combining air with another substance, or the state of being filled with air.
Allhallow eve: The evening before Allhallows. See Halloween.
Attorneyism: The practice or peculiar cleverness of attorneys.
Accomplishment: The act of accomplishing; entire performance; completion; fulfillment; as, the accomplishment of an enterprise, of a prophecy, etc.
Acajou: The cashew tree; also, its fruit. See Cashew.
Argentic: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, silver; -- said of certain compounds of silver in which this metal has its lowest proportion; as, argentic chloride.
Acidific: Producing acidity; converting into an acid.
Anisic: Of or derived from anise; as, anisic acid; anisic alcohol.
Anxiousness: The quality of being anxious; great solicitude; anxiety.
Assailant: One who, or that which, assails, attacks, or assaults; an assailer.
Albula: a genus of fish, the type and sole genus of the family Albulidae.
Atriplex: a genus of plants of the goosefoot family (Chenopodiaceae); its members include species called orach and saltbush.
Abreast: Side by side, with breasts in a line; as, “Two men could hardly walk abreast.”
Astroscope: An old astronomical instrument, formed of two cones, on whose surface the constellations were delineated.
Advocation: The act of advocating or pleading; plea; advocacy.
Androgyny: Union of both sexes in one individual; hermaphroditism.
Alter: To become, in some respects, different; to vary; to change; as, the weather alters almost daily; rocks or minerals alter by exposure.
Adventurously: In an adventurous manner; venturesomely; boldly; daringly.
Artless: Wanting art, knowledge, or skill; ignorant; unskillful.
Africander: One born in Africa, the offspring of a white father and a “colored” mother. Also, and now commonly in Southern Africa, a native born of European settlers.
Alabastrine: Of, pertaining to, or like, alabaster; as alabastrine limbs.
Arduousness: The quality of being arduous; difficulty of execution.
Anyhow: In any way or manner whatever; at any rate; in any event.
Atheroid: Shaped like an ear of grain.
Amuletic: Of or pertaining to an amulet; operating as a charm.
Amber room: A room formerly in the Czar's Summer Palace in Russia, which was richly decorated with walls and fixtures made from amber.  The amber was removed by occupying German troops during the Second World War and has, as of 1997, never been recovered.  The room is being recreated from old photographs by Russian artisans.
Anagogics: Mystical interpretations or studies, esp. of the Scriptures.
Altercate: To contend in words; to dispute with zeal, heat, or anger; to wrangle.
ash-pan: a receptacle fitted beneath the grate in which ashes collect and are removed.
Aftercrop: A second crop or harvest in the same year.
Astrogeny: The creation or evolution of the stars or the heavens.
Authority: Legal or rightful power; a right to command or to act; power exercised buy a person in virtue of his office or trust; dominion; jurisdiction; authorization; as, the authority of a prince over subjects, and of parents over children; the authority of a court.
Avidity: Greediness; strong appetite; eagerness; intenseness of desire; as, to eat with avidity.
Aplastic anemia: an anemia characterized by substantial reduction or cessation of production of red blood cells and hemoglobin by the bone marrow.
Applicative: Capable of being applied or used; applying; applicatory; practical.
Aptote: A noun which has no distinction of cases; an indeclinable noun.
Analysis of variance: a statistical technique by which the results of an observation or experiment are analyzed to determine the relative contributions of the different possible causative factors or variables to the outcome.  Abbreviated ANOVA.
Assument: A patch; an addition; a piece put on.
Attenuation: The act or process of making slender, or the state of being slender; emaciation.
Arrentation: A letting or renting, esp. a license to inclose land in a forest with a low hedge and a ditch, under a yearly rent.
Apothesis: A place on the south side of the chancel in the primitive churches, furnished with shelves, for books, vestments, etc.
Acanthopterygian: Belonging to the order of fishes having spinose fins, as the perch.
Arrant: Notoriously or preëminently bad; thorough or downright, in a bad sense; shameless; unmitigated; as, an arrant rogue or coward.
Acoustics: The science of sounds, teaching their nature, phenomena, and laws.
Auld: Old; as, Auld Reekie (old smoky), i. e., Edinburgh.
Antipodal: Pertaining to the antipodes; situated on the opposite side of the globe.
airway: a duct that provides ventilation, as in mines.
Allonym: The name of another person assumed by the author of a work.
Animadversion: The act or power of perceiving or taking notice; direct or simple perception.
Assoilzie: To absolve; to acquit by sentence of court.
Arachnologist: One who is versed in, or studies, arachnology.
Alguazil: An inferior officer of justice in Spain; a warrant officer; a constable.
Agave: A genus of plants (order Amaryllidaceæ) of which the chief species is the maguey or century plant (Agave Americana), wrongly called Aloe. It is from ten to seventy years, according to climate, in attaining maturity, when it produces a gigantic flower stem, sometimes forty feet in height, and perishes. The fermented juice is the pulque of the Mexicans; distilled, it yields mescal. A strong thread and a tough paper are made from the leaves, and the wood has many uses.
Acrospore: A spore borne at the extremity of the cells of fructification in fungi.
Armadillidiidae: a family comrising the pill bugs.
Apocryphalist: One who believes in, or defends, the Apocrypha.
Argillo-calcareous: Consisting of, or containing, clay and calcareous earth.
Appetible: Desirable; capable or worthy of being the object of desire.
Autoradiography: the process of producing an autoradiogram by exposing photographic film to a radioactive substance in close proximity to the film.
adulterating: making impure or corrupt by virtue of extraneous origin; -- of impurities.
Aflame: In flames; glowing with light or passion; ablaze.
Agist: To take to graze or pasture, at a certain sum; -- used originally of the feeding of cattle in the king's forests, and collecting the money for the same.
Appropriateness: The state or quality of being appropriate; peculiar fitness.
Alienor: One who alienates or transfers property to another.
Amorphous: Having no determinate form; of irregular; shapeless.
Alethoscope: An instrument for viewing pictures by means of a lens, so as to present them in their natural proportions and relations.
Alla breve: With one breve, or four minims, to measure, and sung faster like four crotchets; in quick common time; -- indicated in the time signature by &unr_;.
Ashlar: Hewn or squared stone; also, masonry made of squared or hewn stone.
Arianrod: a goddess famous for her beauty; the mother of Dylan.
assembly line: A line of machinery, tools, and workers on which objects to be manufactured are moved from one post to the next, where different workers perform different steps in the manufacturing process; called also production line.  The objects to be manufactured usually move on a form of conveyor belt, which does not necessarily move only in a straight line, but may continue around the factory area for some distance.
anacoluthia: an abrupt change within a sentence from one syntactic structure to another.
Adjure: To charge, bind, or command, solemnly, as if under oath, or under the penalty of a curse; to appeal to in the most solemn or impressive manner; to entreat earnestly.
Abridgment: The act of abridging, or the state of being abridged; diminution; lessening; reduction or deprivation; as, an abridgment of pleasures or of expenses.
Accountable ness: The quality or state of being accountable; accountability.
aplitic: of or pertaining to an aplite.
Aphelion: That point of a planet's or comet's orbit which is most distant from the sun, the opposite point being the perihelion.
Adeem: To revoke, as a legacy, grant, etc., or to satisfy it by some other gift.
Anxietude: The state of being anxious; anxiety.
Apronful: The quantity an apron can hold.
Adduct: To draw towards a common center or a middle line.
Alcoholometry: The process or method of ascertaining the proportion of pure alcohol which spirituous liquors contain.
Adduce: To bring forward or offer, as an argument, passage, or consideration which bears on a statement or case; to cite; to allege.
aas: a loose sleeveless outer garment made from aba cloth; worn by Arabs.
Alexander: a European herb (Smyrnium olusatrum) somewhat resembling celery widely naturalized in Britain coastal regions and often cultivated as a potherb.
\u00c6tiological: Pertaining to ætiology; assigning a cause.
Air pocket: A local region in the atmosphere having a downward movement and offering less than normal support for the sustaining surfaces of a flying machine, causing an airplane to drop suddenly.  Same as air hole.
Alizarin: A coloring principle, C14H6O2(OH)2, found in madder, and now produced artificially as an an orange-red crystalline compound from anthracene. It is used in making red pigments (such as the Turkish reds), and in dyeing.
Astonish: To stun; to render senseless, as by a blow.
Arrhizal: Destitute of a true root, as a parasitical plant.
Alburnous: Of or pertaining to alburnum; of the alburnum; as, alburnous substances.
Acockbill: Hanging at the cathead, ready to let go, as an anchor.
Aphtha: One of the whitish specks called aphthæ.
Alkalimeter: An instrument to ascertain the strength of alkalies, or the quantity of alkali in a mixture.
Argolic: Pertaining to Argolis, a district in the Peloponnesus.
Awry: Turned or twisted toward one side; not in a straight or true direction, or position; out of the right course; distorted; obliquely; asquint; with oblique vision; as, to glance awry.
Axinomancy: A species of divination, by means of an ax or hatchet.
Alleviate: To lighten or lessen the force or weight of.
Alligation: The act of tying together or attaching by some bond, or the state of being attached.
Aspidobranchia: A group of Gastropoda, with limpetlike shells, including the abalone shells and keyhole limpets.
Anlace: A broad dagger formerly worn at the girdle.
Assembler: One who assembles a number of individuals; also, one of a number assembled.
Ameliorate: To grow better; to meliorate; as, wine ameliorates by age.
Anathematize: To pronounce an anathema against; to curse. Hence: To condemn publicly as something accursed.
Amigo: A friend; -- a Spanish term applied in the Philippine Islands to friendly natives.
Accomplish: To complete, as time or distance.
Awning: A rooflike cover, usually of canvas, extended over or before any place as a shelter from the sun, rain, or wind.
Antaphrodisiac: Capable of blunting the venereal appetite.
Anemograph: An instrument for measuring and recording the direction and force of the wind.
Astragal: A convex molding of rounded surface, generally from half to three quarters of a circle.
Aldermanly: Pertaining to, or like, an alderman.
Amidol: A salt of a diamino phenol, C6H3(OH)(NH2)2, used as a developer.
Antonomasia: The use of some epithet or the name of some office, dignity, or the like, instead of the proper name of the person; as when his majesty is used for a king, or when, instead of Aristotle, we say, the philosopher; or, conversely, the use of a proper name instead of an appellative, as when a wise man is called a Solomon, or an eminent orator a Cicero.
Attagas: A species of sand grouse (Syrrghaptes Pallasii) found in Asia and rarely in southern Europe.
Acephalocystic: Pertaining to, or resembling, the acephalocysts.
Abalienate: To transfer the title of from one to another; to alienate.
Altissimo: The part or notes situated above F in alt.
Astrophotography: The application of photography to the delineation of the sun, moon, and stars.
Alga: A kind of seaweed; pl. the class of cellular cryptogamic plants which includes the black, red, and green seaweeds, as kelp, dulse, sea lettuce, also marine and fresh water confervæ, etc.  The algae are primitive chlorophyll-containing mainly aquatic eukaryotic organisms lacking true stems and roots and leaves.
Acromion: The outer extremity of the shoulder blade.
Anemosis: A condition in the wood of some trees in which the rings are separated, as some suppose, by the action of high winds upon the trunk; wind shake.
Adnascent: Growing to or on something else.
Autocracy: Independent or self-derived power; absolute or controlling authority; supremacy.
Abstractedly: In an abstracted manner; separately; with absence of mind.
Alike: In the same manner, form, or degree; in common; equally; as, we are all alike concerned in religion.
Agnus castus: A species of Vitex (Vitex agnus castus); the chaste tree.
Aurochs: The European bison (Bison bonasus, or Bison Europæus), once widely distributed, but now nearly extinct, except where protected in the Lithuanian forests, and perhaps in the Caucasus. It is distinct from the Urus of Cæsar, with which it has often been confused.
Asclepiad: A choriambic verse, first used by the Greek poet Asclepias, consisting of four feet, viz., a spondee, two choriambi, and an iambus.
Asclepias: A genus of plants including the milkweed, swallowwort, and some other species having medicinal properties.
Allopathist: One who practices allopathy; one who professes allopathy.
Acrocomia: a genus of Central and South American feather palms.
Aristotelia: a small genus of shrubs or small trees of Australia and New Zealand and West South America.
Aristotelic: Pertaining to Aristotle or to his philosophy.
Alcarraza: A vessel of porous earthenware, used for cooling liquids by evaporation from the exterior surface.
Anguilliformes: an order of elongate fishes with pelvic fins and girdle absent or reduced.
Ayme: The utterance of the ejaculation “Ay me !” [Obs.] See Ay, interj.
Air cooling: In devices generating heat, such as gasoline-engine motor vehicles, the cooling of the device by increasing its radiating surface by means of ribs or radiators, and placing it so that it is exposed to a current of air. Cf. Water cooling.
androus: A terminal combining form: Having a stamen or stamens; staminate; as, monandrous, with one stamen; polyandrous, with many stamens.
Abovedeck: On deck; and hence, like aboveboard, without artifice.
15th: coming next after the fourteenth in a series
A\u00ebronautics: The science or art of ascending and sailing in the air, as by means of a balloon; aërial navigation; ballooning.
Adessenarian: One who held the real presence of Christ's body in the eucharist, but not by transubstantiation.
Against: Abreast; opposite to; facing; towards; as, against the mouth of a river; -- in this sense often preceded by over.
Adhibit: To admit, as a person or thing; to take in.
Airsick: Affected with air sickness or aërial sickness; feeling nauseous due to riding in an airplane.
Apparatus: Things provided as means to some end.
Abasia: Inability to coördinate muscular actions properly in walking.
Asterophyllite: A fossil plant from the coal formations of Europe and America, now regarded as the branchlets and foliage of calamites.
Ascribe: To attribute, impute, or refer, as to a cause; as, his death was ascribed to a poison; to ascribe an effect to the right cause; to ascribe such a book to such an author.
Acupressure: A mode of arresting hemorrhage resulting from wounds or surgical operations, by passing under the divided vessel a needle, the ends of which are left exposed externally on the cutaneous surface.
Adoptive: Pertaining to adoption; made or acquired by adoption; fitted to adopt; as, an adoptive father, an child; an adoptive language.
Artlessly: In an artless manner; without art, skill, or guile; unaffectedly.
Alcoholization: The act of reducing a substance to a fine or impalpable powder.
Acumination: A sharpening; termination in a sharp point; a tapering point.
Abnegate: To deny and reject; to abjure.
Acetone: A volatile liquid consisting of three parts of carbon, six of hydrogen, and one of oxygen; pyroacetic spirit, -- obtained by the distillation of certain acetates, or by the destructive distillation of citric acid, starch, sugar, or gum, with quicklime.
Aslope: Slopingly; aslant; declining from an upright direction; sloping.
Asparagaceae: one of many families or subfamilies into which some classification systems subdivide the Liliaceae: includes genera Asparagus and sometimes Ruscus.
Air shaft: A passage, usually vertical, for admitting fresh air into a mine or a tunnel.
Amphimacer: A foot of three syllables, the middle one short and the others long, as in cāst&unr_;tās.
Almond furnace: A kind of furnace used in refining, to separate the metal from cinders and other foreign matter.
Arsenite: A salt formed by the union of arsenious acid with a base.
Analogically: In an analogical sense; in accordance with analogy; by way of similitude.
Amyl alcohol: Any of eight isomeric liquid alcohols (C5H11.OH), transparent, colorless liquids. It is the hydroxide of amyl. Also called amylic alcohol.   The amyl alcohol obtained from fusel oil is mostly isoamyl alcohol  (3-methyl-1-butanol or 1-hydroxy-3-methylbutane), with some sec-amyl alcohol (2-methyl-1-butanol or 2-pentanol), and has a characteristic peculiar odor. Other than n-amyl alcohol (also called 1-pentanol) the other isomeric pentanols are not usually refered to as amyl alcohol.  The amyl alcohol mixture in fusel oil forms a colorless liquid with a peculiar cough-exciting odor and burning taste. It is used as a source of amyl compounds, such as amyl acetate, amyl nitrite, etc.
Anteflexion: A displacement forward of an organ, esp. the uterus, in such manner that its axis is bent upon itself.
Audita querela: A writ which lies for a party against whom judgment is recovered, but to whom good matter of discharge has subsequently accrued which could not have been availed of to prevent such judgment.
Abruptly: In an abrupt manner; without giving notice, or without the usual forms; suddenly.
Abscess: A collection of pus or purulent matter in any tissue or organ of the body, the result of a morbid process.
30: one more than twenty-nine; three times ten; denoting a quantity consisting of thirty items or units; -- representing the number thirty as an Arabic numeral
atonality: the absence of a key; alternative to the diatonic system.
Apeak: In a vertical line. The anchor in apeak, when the cable has been sufficiently hove in to bring the ship over it, and the ship is them said to be hove apeak.
Aliturgical: Applied to those days when the holy sacrifice is not offered.
A 1: A registry mark given by underwriters (as at Lloyd's) to ships in first-class condition. Inferior grades are indicated by A 2 and A 3.
Anemopsis: a genus consisting of one species: the yerba mansa.
Associate: A companion; one frequently in company with another, implying intimacy or equality; a mate; a fellow.
Acetarious: Used in salads; as, acetarious plants.
Ambiguous: Doubtful or uncertain, particularly in respect to signification; capable of being understood in either of two or more possible senses; equivocal; as, an ambiguous course; an ambiguous expression.
Arminian: One who holds the tenets of Arminius, a Dutch divine (b. 1560, d. 1609).
Adjuration: The act of adjuring; a solemn charging on oath, or under the penalty of a curse; an earnest appeal.
Actinal: Pertaining to the part of a radiate animal which contains the mouth.
Affordment: Anything given as a help; bestowal.
Aldermanlike: Like or suited to an alderman.
Astringe: To bind fast; to constrict; to contract; to cause parts to draw together; to compress.
allergenic: of or pertaining to allergens or allergenicity.
Acceptable: Capable, worthy, or sure of being accepted or received with pleasure; pleasing to a receiver; gratifying; agreeable; welcome; as, an acceptable present, one acceptable to us.
Arrogate: To assume, or claim as one's own, unduly, proudly, or presumptuously; to make undue claims to, from vanity or baseless pretensions to right or merit; as, the pope arrogated dominion over kings.
Arrestment: The arrest of a person, or the seizure of his effects; esp., a process by which money or movables in the possession of a third party are attached.
Auld lang syne: A Scottish phrase used in recalling recollections of times long since past.
Altitudinal: Of or pertaining to height; as, altitudinal measurements.
Ambulacral: Of or pertaining to ambulacra; avenuelike; as, the ambulacral ossicles, plates, spines, and suckers of echinoderms.
Actinophone: An apparatus for the production of sound by the action of the actinic, or ultraviolet, rays.
anklets: socks that reach just above the ankle.
Abutilon: A genus of malvaceous plants of many species, found in the torrid and temperate zones of both continents; -- called also Indian mallow.
Auxetic: Pertaining to, or containing, auxesis; amplifying.
Accendible: Capable of being inflamed or kindled; combustible; inflammable.
Anthropogeography: The science of the human species as to geographical distribution and environment. Broadly, it includes industrial, commercial, and political geography, and that part of ethnology which deals with distribution and physical environment.
Amidships: In the middle of a ship, with regard to her length, and sometimes also her breadth.
Aplodontia: the type genus of the family Aplodontiidae, comprising the mountain beavers.
Acosmism: A denial of the existence of the universe as distinct from God.
Alanine: one of the natural amino acids found combined in the proteins of most living tissues.  It can be isolated as a white crystalline base, C3H7NO2.  The natural form is the L-configuration.
Anisol: Methyl phenyl ether, C6H5.O.CH3, got by distilling anisic acid or by the action of methide on potassium phenolate.
Anagoge: An elevation of mind to things celestial.
Acosmist: One who denies the existence of the universe, or of a universe as distinct from God.
Agatize: To convert into agate; to make resemble agate.
Accursed: Doomed to destruction or misery; cursed; hence, bad enough to be under the curse; execrable; detestable; exceedingly hateful; -- as, an accursed deed.
Antilopine: Of or relating to the antelope.
Aint: A contraction for are not and am not; also used for is not. [Colloq. or illiterate speech]. See An't.
Ainu: One of a peculiar race found primarily in Hokkaido, in the northern part of the empire of Japan, the Kurile Islands, and nearby.  They are believed to be the native inhabitants of the Japanese islands. The Ainus are stout and short, with hairy bodies.  Also called Aino and hairy Ainu.
Abetter: One who abets; an instigator of an offense or an offender.
Assumption: The act of assuming, or taking to or upon one's self; the act of taking up or adopting.
Anodyne: Any medicine which allays pain, as an opiate or narcotic; anything that soothes disturbed feelings.
Ascaridia: a roundworm having a preanal sucker.
Angriness: The quality of being angry, or of being inclined to anger.
Aviation: The art or science of flying.
Afforest: To convert into a forest; as, to afforest a tract of country.
Acrotarsium: The instep or front of the tarsus.
Annats: The first year's profits of a spiritual preferment, anciently paid by the clergy to the pope; first fruits. In England, they now form a fund for the augmentation of poor livings.
Ametabola: A group of insects which do not undergo any metamorphosis.
\u00c6sthesiometer: An instrument to measure the degree of sensation, by determining at how short a distance two impressions upon the skin can be distinguished, and thus to determine whether the condition of tactile sensibility is normal or altered.
Admonition: Gentle or friendly reproof; counseling against a fault or error; expression of authoritative advice; friendly caution or warning.
Advertence: The act of adverting, of the quality of being advertent; attention; notice; regard; heedfulness.
Altaic: of or pertaining to the Altaic languages.
antineutron: The antiparticle of a neutron. It has the same mass as a neutron, but a spin and magnetic moment opposite that of the neutron.
Antlia: The spiral tubular proboscis of lepidopterous insects. See Lepidoptera.
Amphiaster: The achromatic figure, formed in mitotic cell-division, consisting of two asters connected by a spindle-shaped bundle of rodlike fibers diverging from each aster, and called the spindle.
Ambo: A large pulpit or reading desk, in the early Christian churches.
Anathematization: The act of anathematizing, or denouncing as accursed; imprecation.
Argentation: A coating or overlaying with silver.
Aflaunt: In a flaunting state or position.
American Indian: a red-skinned member of a race of people living in North America when Europeans arrived.
Anabolic steroid: any of a variety of synthetic derivatives or analogs of testosterone, which promote the increase of muscle mass and strength.  The anabolic steroids are sometimes used by athletes to increase muscular strength so as to enhance their performance in competition.  They have serious side effects, and the use of such compounds has been banned by many athletic regulatory committees.
A\u00ebro: An aëroplane, airship, or the like.
Admaxillary: Near to the maxilla or jawbone.
Amelanchier: a genus of North American deciduous trees or shrubs.
Amb-: A prefix meaning about, around; -- used in words derived from the Latin.
Aura: Any subtile, invisible emanation, effluvium, or exhalation from a substance, as the aroma of flowers, the odor of the blood, a supposed fertilizing emanation from the pollen of flowers, etc.
angle-park: to park (a road vehicle) at an angle to the curb; -- contrasted with parallel-park.
Afterpains: The pains which succeed childbirth, as in expelling the afterbirth.
Admired: Regarded with wonder and delight; highly prized; as, an admired poem.
Anacamptically: By reflection; as, echoes are sound produced anacamptically.
Abhal: The berries of a species of cypress in the East Indies.
Awesome: Causing awe; appalling; awful; as, an awesome sight.
Abbot: The superior or head of an abbey.
Admirer: One who admires; one who esteems or loves greatly.
Anguish: To distress with extreme pain or grief.
Arteriosclerosis: a chronic disease characterized by abnormal thickening and hardening of the walls of the arteries, esp. of the intima, occurring mostly in old age.  Subtypes are distinguished, such as arteriolosclerosis and atherosclerosis.
aerial: a pass to a receiver downfield from the passer.
Apex: The tip, top, point, or angular summit of anything; as, the apex of a mountain, spire, or cone; the apex, or tip, of a leaf.
Academicals: The articles of dress prescribed and worn at some colleges and universities.
Araguato: A South American monkey, the ursine howler (Mycetes ursinus). See Howler, n., 2.
Athanor: A digesting furnace, formerly used by alchemists. It was so constructed as to maintain uniform and durable heat.
adrenosterone: a steroid having androgenic activity; obtained from the cortex of the adrenal gland.
Aero: of or pertaining to aeronautics or aircraft.
Aquitanian: Of or pertaining to Aquitania, now called Gascony.
Antialbumid: A body formed from albumin by pancreatic and gastric digestion. It is convertible into antipeptone.
Angulosity: A state of being angulous or angular.
Arachnology: The department of zoölogy which treats of spiders and other Arachnida.
A\u00ebroplanist: One who flies in an aëroplane.
Abbatial: Belonging to an abbey; as, abbatial rights.
algorithm: a precise rule (or set of rules) specifying how to solve some problem; a set of procedures guaranteed to find the solution to a problem.
anorexigenic: causing loss of appetite; as, an anorectic (or anorexigenic) drug.
Am\u0153biform: Resembling an amœba; amœba-shaped; changing in shape like an amœba.
Afterguard: The seaman or seamen stationed on the poop or after part of the ship, to attend the after-sails.
Anglice: In English; in the English manner; as, Livorno, Anglice Leghorn.
Anatreptic: Overthrowing; defeating; -- applied to Plato's refutative dialogues.
Alkalize: To render alkaline; to communicate the properties of an alkali to.
Ardassine: A very fine sort of Persian silk.
Alimentally: So as to serve for nourishment or food; nourishing quality.
Acridity: The quality of being acrid or pungent; irritant bitterness; extreme bitterness; acrimony; as, the acridity of a plant, of a speech.
Albuminate: A substance produced by the action of an alkali upon albumin, and resembling casein in its properties; also, a compound formed by the union of albumin with another substance.
Ambiguity: The quality or state of being ambiguous; doubtfulness or uncertainty, particularly as to the signification of language, arising from its admitting of more than one meaning; an equivocal word or expression.
Anadrom: A fish that leaves the sea and ascends rivers.
Athwart: Across, especially in an oblique direction; sidewise; obliquely.
Aotus: a genus of nocturnal South American monkeys with large eyes; the owl monkeys; the douroucoulis.  See douroucouli.
Alder: Of all; -- used in composition; as, alderbest, best of all, alderwisest, wisest of all.
Agential: Of or pertaining to an agent or an agency.
Absentation: The act of absenting one's self.
Amylobacter: A microörganism (Bacillus amylobacter) which develops in vegetable tissue during putrefaction.
Aniseed: The seed of the anise; also, a cordial prepared from it.
Abaddon: The destroyer, or angel of the bottomless pit; -- the same as Apollyon and Asmodeus.
Ardeidae: a familu of wading birds incuding the herons, egrets, night herons, and bitterns.
Ambassador: A minister of the highest rank sent to a foreign court to represent there his sovereign or country.
\u00c6sculapian: Pertaining to Æsculapius or to the healing art; medical; medicinal.
Amorosity: The quality of being amorous; lovingness.
Alphonsine: Of or relating to Alphonso X., the Wise, King of Castile (1252-1284).
Atomism: The doctrine of atoms. See Atomic philosophy, under Atomic.
Auger: A carpenter's tool for boring holes larger than those bored by a gimlet. It has a handle placed crosswise by which it is turned with both hands. A pod auger is one with a straight channel or groove, like the half of a bean pod. A screw auger has a twisted blade, by the spiral groove of which the chips are discharge.
Auget: A priming tube connecting the charge chamber with the gallery, or place where the slow match is applied.
Atlantes: Figures or half figures of men, used as columns to support an entablature; -- called also telamones.  See Caryatides.
Ancientness: The quality of being ancient; antiquity; existence from old times.
Atomist: One who holds to the atomic philosophy or theory.
Ascendant: Rising toward the zenith; above the horizon.
Assured: One whose life or property is insured.
Architectural: Of or pertaining to the art of building; conformed to the rules of architecture.
Appetence: A longing; a desire; especially an ardent desire; appetite; appetency.
Assurer: One who assures. Specifically: One who insures against loss; an insurer or underwriter.
Alas: An exclamation expressive of sorrow, pity, or apprehension of evil; -- in old writers, sometimes followed by day or white; alas the day, like alack a day, or alas the white.
Ambition: To seek after ambitiously or eagerly; to covet.
Amazement: The condition of being amazed; bewilderment [Obs.]; overwhelming wonder, as from surprise, sudden fear, horror, or admiration.
Animalculism: The theory which seeks to explain certain physiological and pathological phenomena by means of animalcules.
Amsonia: a genus of herbs and subshrubs with milky juice and showy bluish flowers; native from Europe to Asia Minor to Japan and North America.
Angle of incidence: The angle between the chord of an aërocurve and the relative direction of the undisturbed air current.
Antiphone: The response which one side of the choir makes to the other in a chant; alternate chanting or signing.
Augustness: The quality of being august; dignity of mien; grandeur; magnificence.
Antiphony: A musical response; also, antiphonal chanting or signing.
Auden: An English poet in the U. S.   Born 1907, died 1973.
Animalculist: One versed in the knowledge of animalcules.
Alien: To alienate; to estrange; to transfer, as property or ownership.
Assibilation: Change of a non-sibilant letter to a sibilant, as of -tion to -shun, duke to ditch.
Archetypal: Of or pertaining to an archetype; consisting a model (real or ideal) or pattern; original.
A mensa et thoro: A kind of divorce which does not dissolve the marriage bond, but merely authorizes a separate life of the husband and wife.
Annonaceae: a family of chiefly tropical trees or shrubs.
Autokinesis: Spontaneous or voluntary movement; movement due to an internal cause.
Aphetic: Shortened by dropping a letter or a syllable from the beginning of a word; as, an aphetic word or form.
Admissive: Implying an admission; tending to admit.
Arboretum: A place in which a collection of rare trees and shrubs is cultivated for scientific or educational purposes.
Arroba: A Spanish weight used in Mexico and South America = 25.36 lbs. avoir.; also, an old Portuguese weight, used in Brazil = 32.38 lbs. avoir.
Annoy: A feeling of discomfort or vexation caused by what one dislikes; also, whatever causes such a feeling; as, to work annoy.
Assimilatory: Tending to assimilate, or produce assimilation; as, assimilatory organs.
Acronycally: In an acronycal manner as rising at the setting of the sun, and vice versa.
Adscript: One held to service as attached to the glebe or estate; a feudal serf.
Aryanize: To make Aryan (a language, or in language).
Athanasia: The quality of being deathless; immortality.
Albion: An ancient name of England, still retained in poetry.
Appetency: Fixed and strong desire; esp. natural desire; a craving; an eager appetite.
Auroral: Belonging to, or resembling, the aurora (the dawn or the northern lights); rosy.
Abstruse: Concealed or hidden out of the way.
Agrarianize: To distribute according to, or to imbue with, the principles of agrarianism.
Areolet: A small inclosed area; esp. one of the small spaces on the wings of insects, circumscribed by the veins.
Adapa: a demigod or first man: "seed of mankind"; sometimes identified with Adam.
Asphyxia: Apparent death, or suspended animation; the condition which results from interruption of respiration, as in suffocation or drowning, or the inhalation of poisonous or irrespirable gases.
Archibald wheel: A metal-hubbed wheel of great strength and elasticity, esp. adapted for artillery carriages and motor cars.
Adapt: To make suitable; to fit, or suit; to adjust; to alter so as to fit for a new use; -- sometimes followed by to or for.
Anadem: A garland or fillet; a chaplet or wreath.
Ankylostomiasis: A disease due to the presence of the parasites Agchylostoma duodenale, Uncinaria (subgenus Necator) americana, or allied nematodes, in the small intestine. When present in large numbers they produce a severe anæmia by sucking the blood from the intestinal walls.  Called also miner's anæmia, tunnel disease, brickmaker's anæmia, Egyptian chlorosis.
Actinology: The science which treats of rays of light, especially of the actinic or chemical rays.
Assert: To affirm; to declare with assurance, or plainly and strongly; to state positively; to aver; to asseverate.
Agriology: Description or comparative study of the customs of savage or uncivilized tribes.
Acadian: Of or pertaining to Acadia, or Nova Scotia.
Affability: The quality of being affable; readiness to converse; courteousness in receiving others and in conversation; complaisant behavior.
Atmolyze: To subject to atmolysis; to separate by atmolysis.
Anallagmatic: Not changed in form by inversion.
Annulus: A ring; a ringlike part or space.
Aimless: Without aim or purpose; as, an aimless life.
Antiguggler: A crooked tube of metal, to be introduced into the neck of a bottle for drawing out the liquid without disturbing the sediment or causing a gurgling noise.
Adipoceriform: Having the form or appearance of adipocere; as, an adipoceriform tumor.
Alleyed: Furnished with alleys; forming an alley.
Arbor vit\u00e6: An evergreen tree of the cypress tribe, genus Thuja.  The American species is the Thuja occidentalis.
Accipitridae: a family of birds consisting of the hawks; -- this family includes the Old World vultures; kites; harriers; and eagles.
Apple: To grow like an apple; to bear apples.
22nd: coming next after the twenty-first in a series
Anteriority: The state of being anterior or preceding in time or in situation; priority.
Anglicanism: Strong partiality to the principles and rites of the Church of England.
Apply: To suit; to agree; to have some connection, agreement, or analogy; as, this argument applies well to the case.
Astrophotometry: The determination of the brightness of stars, and also of the sun, moon, and planets.
Aye: Always; ever; continually; for an indefinite time.
Ant-bear: An edentate animal of tropical America (the Tamanoir), living on ants. It belongs to the genus Myrmecophaga.
Allomorph: Any one of two or more distinct crystalline forms of the same substance; or the substance having such forms; -- as, carbonate of lime occurs in the allomorphs calcite and aragonite.
Adipoceration: The act or process of changing into adipocere.
Azotometer: An apparatus for measuring or determining the proportion of nitrogen; a nitrometer.
Advocateship: Office or duty of an advocate.
Aquarellist: A painter in thin transparent water colors.
Armoric: Of or pertaining to the northwestern part of France (formerly called Armorica, now Bretagne or Brittany), or to its people.
Antitrochanter: An articular surface on the ilium of birds against which the great trochanter of the femur plays.
Andesine: A kind of triclinic feldspar found in the Andes.
anthropocentrism: an inclination to evaluate reality exclusively in terms of human values.
Araneina: The order of Arachnida that includes the spiders.
Achro\u00f6dextrin: Dextrin not colorable by iodine. See Dextrin.
Apneumona: An order of holothurians in which the internal respiratory organs are wanting; -- called also Apoda or Apodes.
Analogue: That which is analogous to, or corresponds with, some other thing.
Arles: An earnest; earnest money; money paid to bind a bargain.
Aposematic: Having or designating conspicuous or warning colors or structures indicative of special means of defense against enemies, as in the skunk.
Albication: The process of becoming white, or developing white patches, or streaks.
Arbuscle: A dwarf tree, one in size between a shrub and a tree; a treelike shrub.
Anniversary: The annual return of the day on which any notable event took place, or is wont to be celebrated; as, the anniversary of the Declaration of Independence.
Albuminoidal: Of the nature of an albuminoid.
Agamogenesis: Reproduction without the union of parents of distinct sexes: asexual reproduction.
Alecithal: Applied to those ova which segment uniformly, and which have little or no food yelk embedded in their protoplasm.
Amharic: Of or pertaining to Amhara, a division of Abyssinia; as, the Amharic language is closely allied to the Ethiopic.
Army organization: The system by which a country raises, classifies, arranges, and equips its armed land forces. The usual divisions are: (1) A regular or active army, in which soldiers serve continuously with the colors and live in barracks or cantonments when not in the field; (2) the reserves of this army, in which the soldiers, while remaining constantly subject to a call to the colors, live at their homes, being summoned more or less frequently to report for instruction, drill, or maneuvers; and (3) one or more classes of soldiers organized largely for territorial defense, living at home and having only occasional periods of drill and instraction, who are variously called home reserves (as in the table below), second, third, etc., line of defense (the regular army and its reserves ordinarily constituting the first line of defense), territorial forces, or the like. In countries where conscription prevails a soldier is supposed to serve a given number of years.  He is usually enrolled first in the regular army, then passes to its reserve, then into the home reserves, to serve until he reaches the age limit. It for any reason he is not enrolled in the regular army, he may begin his service in the army reserves or even the home reserves, but then serves the full number of years or up to the age limit. In equipment the organization of the army is into the three great arms of infantry, cavalry, and artillery, together with more or less numerous other branches, such as engineers, medical corps, etc., besides the staff organizations such as those of the pay and subsistence departments.
Assessable: Liable to be assessed or taxed; as, assessable property.
Amove: To move or be moved; to excite.
Agreement: State of agreeing; harmony of opinion, statement, action, or character; concurrence; concord; conformity; as, a good agreement subsists among the members of the council.
Alpine: Of or pertaining to the Alps, or to any lofty mountain; as, Alpine snows; Alpine plants.
\u00c6sthetics: The theory or philosophy of taste; the science of the beautiful in nature and art; esp. that which treats of the expression and embodiment of beauty by art.
Anticlastic: Having opposite curvatures, that is, curved longitudinally in one direction and transversely in the opposite direction, as the surface of a saddle.
Alleviator: One who, or that which, alleviates.
Arduous: Steep and lofty, in a literal sense; hard to climb.
Affluent: A stream or river flowing into a larger river or into a lake; a tributary stream.
Argyreia: a genus of woody climbers of tropical Asia to Australia.
Arioso: In the smooth and melodious style of an air; ariose.
Angola: A fabric made from the wool of the Angora goat.
Arsenal: A public establishment for the storage, or for the manufacture and storage, of arms and all military equipments, whether for land or naval service.
Aider: One who, or that which, aids.
Alpenhorn: A curved wooden horn about three feet long, with a cupped mouthpiece and a bell, used by the Swiss to sound the ranz des vaches and other melodies. Its notes are open harmonics of the tube.
Adnation: The adhesion or cohesion of different floral verticils or sets of organs.
all-mains: adaptable to all voltages; -- of a radio receiver.
Anthophilous: Lit., fond of flowers; hence, feeding upon, or living among, flowers.
Ashore: On shore or on land; on the land adjacent to water; to the shore; to the land; aground (when applied to a ship); -- sometimes opposed to aboard or afloat.
Anguillan: of or pertaining to Anguilla; as, Anguillan sea food specialties.
Acceptilation: Gratuitous discharge; a release from debt or obligation without payment; free remission.
Appealable: Capable of being appealed against; that may be removed to a higher tribunal for decision; as, the cause is appealable.
Agrise: To shudder at; to abhor; to dread; to loathe.
Adulate: To flatter in a servile way.
Adult: A person, animal, or plant grown to full size and strength; one who has reached maturity.
Assai: A direction equivalent to very; as, adagio assai, very slow.
Asitia: Want of appetite; loathing of food.
Adelocodonic: Applied to sexual zooids of hydroids, that have a saclike form and do not become free; -- opposed to phanerocodonic.
Adversaria: A miscellaneous collection of notes, remarks, or selections; a commonplace book; also, commentaries or notes.
Araneidan: Of or pertaining to the Araneina or spiders.
Authenticalness: The quality of being authentic; authenticity.
Asclepiadaceous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, plants of the Milkweed family.
Aplysia: A genus of marine mollusks of the order Tectibranchiata; the sea hare. Some of the species when disturbed throw out a deep purple liquor, which colors the water to some distance. See Illust. in Appendix.
Autotrophic: Capable of self-nourishment; requiring only minerals for growth; using carbonate or carbon dioxide as a source of carbon and simple inorganic nitrogen as a nitrogen source; -- said of all plants in which photosynthetic activity takes place, and certain bacteria.  It is opposed to parasitism or saprophytism.
Amianthus: Earth flax, or mountain flax; a soft silky variety of asbestus.
Ascococcus: A form of micrococcus, found in putrid meat infusions, occurring in peculiar masses, each of which is inclosed in a hyaline capsule and contains a large number of spherical micrococci.
Aber-de-vine: The European siskin (Carduelis spinus), a small green and yellow finch, related to the goldfinch.
Ambient: Something that surrounds or invests; as, air . . . being a perpetual ambient.
Aging: the process by which objects or materials acquire desirable qualities by being left undisturbed for some time under specific conditions.  It is used mostly for foods snd beverages, but also for other materials.
Arest: A support for the spear when couched for the attack.
Asportation: The felonious removal of goods from the place where they were deposited.
anomalopteryx: the smallest moa (Anomalopteryx oweni); it is a slender moa about the size of a large turkey.
Ahold: Near the wind; as, to lay a ship ahold.
Actinium: A supposed metal, said by Phipson to be contained in commercial zinc; -- so called because certain of its compounds are darkened by exposure to light.
AAS: an associate degree conferred for successful studies in applied science.
Acanthopteri: A group of teleostean fishes having spiny fins. See Acanthopterygii.
accenting: the act of giving special importance or significance to something.
Ambrosiaceae: in some classifications considered a separate family comprising a subgroup of the Compositae including the ragweeds.
Antiquation: The act of making antiquated, or the state of being antiquated.
Assident: Usually attending a disease, but not always; as, assident signs, or symptoms.
Argonautidae: a family of cephalopods represented solely by the genus Argonauta.
Azurine: The blue roach of Europe (Leuciscus cæruleus); -- so called from its color.
Antipodes: Those who live on the side of the globe diametrically opposite.
Arctotis: a genus of herbs and subshrubs: African daisy.
Askew: Awry; askance; asquint; oblique or obliquely; -- sometimes indicating scorn, or contempt, or entry.
adaptive optics: an optical system used in some telescopes since the 1980's which rapidly changes the shape of the primary reflecting mirror to adjust for distortions of light which are caused by atmospheric turbulence.  By reducing the distortions caused by the atmosphere, telescopes fitted with such optics can achieve a higher resolving power than normal telescopes with static mirrors.
Antiquary: One devoted to the study of ancient times through their relics, as inscriptions, monuments, remains of ancient habitations, statues, coins, manuscripts, etc.; one who searches for and studies the relics of antiquity.
Ambry: In churches, a kind of closet, niche, cupboard, or locker for utensils, vestments, etc.
ascot: a cravat with wide square ends, tied so that the ends are laid flat; the ends are often secured with an ornamental pin; -- called cravat in Britain.
Accelerate: To cause to move faster; to quicken the motion of; to add to the speed of; -- opposed to retard.
Acquaintance: A state of being acquainted, or of having intimate, or more than slight or superficial, knowledge; personal knowledge gained by intercourse short of that of friendship or intimacy; as, I know the man; but have no acquaintance with him.
Ascaris: the type genus of the family Ascaridae: roundworms with a three-lipped mouth.
Affectuous: Full of passion or emotion; earnest.
auto-: A combining form, with the meaning of self, one's self, one's own, itself, its own.
Amnigenous: Born or bred in, of, or near a river.
Aptera: Insects without wings, constituting the seventh Linnæn order of insects, an artificial group, which included Crustacea, spiders, centipeds, and even worms. These animals are now placed in several distinct classes and orders.
acrylonitrile: a colorless liquid compound (H2C:CH.CN); used as raw material for acrylic fibers, and as a solvent.
Almightiness: Omnipotence; infinite or boundless power; unlimited might.
Allopathy: That system of medical practice which aims to combat disease by the use of remedies which produce effects different from those produced by the special disease treated; -- a term invented by Hahnemann to designate the ordinary practice, as opposed to homeopathy.
Aonian: Pertaining to Aonia, in Bœotia, or to the Muses, who were supposed to dwell there.
Applause: The act of applauding; approbation and praise publicly expressed by clapping the hands, stamping or tapping with the feet, acclamation, huzzas, or other means; marked commendation.
Actinost: One of the bones at the base of a paired fin of a fish.
Autoptically: By means of ocular view, or one's own observation.
amorphophallus: any plant of the genus Amorphophallus.
Algaroba: The Carob, a leguminous tree of the Mediterranean region; also, its edible beans or pods, called St. John's bread.
Analogist: One who reasons from analogy, or represent, by analogy.
Asperse: To sprinkle, as water or dust, upon anybody or anything, or to besprinkle any one with a liquid or with dust.
Augite: A variety of pyroxene, usually of a black or dark green color, occurring in igneous rocks, such as basalt; -- also used instead of the general term pyroxene.
Alectorides: A group of birds including the common fowl and the pheasants.
Analogism: an argument from the cause to the effect; an a priori argument.
Anchorless: Without an anchor or stay. Hence: Drifting; unsettled.
Akinesia: Paralysis of the motor nerves; loss of movement.
Admortization: The reducing or lands or tenements to mortmain. See Mortmain.
Afghanistan: a mountainous country in central Asia.
Ascarid: A parasitic nematoid worm, especially the roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides, often occurring in the human intestine, and allied species found in domestic animals; also commonly applied to the pinworm (Oxyuris), often troublesome to children and aged persons.
Abolish: To do away with wholly; to annul; to make void; -- said of laws, customs, institutions, governments, etc.; as, to abolish slavery, to abolish folly.
Adoption: The act of adopting, or state of being adopted; voluntary acceptance of a child of other parents to be the same as one's own child.
Asphyxiated: In a state of asphyxia; suffocated.
Adry: In a dry or thirsty condition.
Analcime: A white or flesh-red mineral, of the zeolite family, occurring in isometric crystals. By friction, it acquires a weak electricity; hence its name.
Apostolicism: The state or quality of being apostolical.
Animalcular: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, animalcules.
Alloyage: The act or art of alloying metals; also, the combination or alloy.
ataractic: drug that reduces nervous tension and gives peace of mind.
Antenuptial: Preceding marriage; as, an antenuptial agreement.
Argillite: Argillaceous schist or slate; clay slate. Its colors is bluish or blackish gray, sometimes greenish gray, brownish red, etc.
Arterialization: The process of converting venous blood into arterial blood during its passage through the lungs, oxygen being absorbed and carbonic acid evolved; -- called also aëration and hematosis.
Asthenic: Characterized by, or pertaining to, debility; weak; debilitating.
Ayah: A native nurse for children; also, a lady's maid.
arugula: an erect European annual (Eruca vesicaria sativa) of the mustard family, often grown as a salad crop to be harvested when young and tender.
Ammonitoidea: An extensive group of fossil cephalopods often very abundant in Mesozoic rocks. See Ammonite.
Alco: A small South American dog, domesticated by the aborigines.
aortal: of or pertaining to the aorta.
Antecessor: One who goes before; a predecessor.
Azureous: Of a fine blue color; azure.
Alembic: An apparatus formerly used in distillation, usually made of glass or metal. It has mostly given place to the retort and worm still.
Abbess: A female superior or governess of a nunnery, or convent of nuns, having the same authority over the nuns which the abbots have over the monks. See Abbey.
Antistrophon: An argument retorted on an opponent.
Apportion: To divide and assign in just proportion; to divide and distribute proportionally; to portion out; to allot; as, to apportion undivided rights; to apportion time among various employments.
airdock: a large building at an airport where aircraft can be stored and maintained.
Align: To form in line; to fall into line.
Androgynous: Uniting both sexes in one, or having the characteristics of both; being in nature both male and female; hermaphroditic.
Achillean: Resembling Achilles, the hero of the Iliad; invincible.
Aggroup: To bring together in a group; to group.
antitussive: a medicament used to suppress or relieve coughing; an antitussive substance.
anastigmat: compound lens or lens system designed to be free of astigmatism and able to form approximately point images.
Anglo-Saxondom: The Anglo-Saxon domain (i. e., Great Britain and the United States, etc.); the Anglo-Saxon race.
Affright: Sudden and great fear; terror. It expresses a stronger impression than fear, or apprehension, perhaps less than terror.
Arcuation: The act of bending or curving; incurvation; the state of being bent; crookedness.
Atomistic: Of or pertaining to atoms; relating to atomism.
Antisacerdotal: Hostile to priests or the priesthood.
Adjoin: To lie or be next, or in contact; to be contiguous; as, the houses adjoin.
Analgen: A crystalline compound used as an antipyretic and analgesic, employed chiefly in rheumatism and neuralgia. It is a complex derivative of quinoline.
Aard-wolf: A carnivorous, striped, quadruped mammal (Proteles cristata, formerly Proteles Lalandii), of South Africa, resembling the fox and hyena. It feeds chiefly on insects. See Proteles.
avant-courier: A person dispatched before another person or company, to give notice of his or their approach.
Adonai: A Hebrew name for God, usually translated in the Old Testament by the word “Lord”.
Assidean: One of a body of devoted Jews who opposed the Hellenistic Jews, and supported the Asmoneans.
astrochemistry: the branch of science involving astronomy and chemistry which studies the chemical composition,  chemical reactions, and evolution of matter in outer space.
Accuse: To charge with, or declare to have committed, a crime or offense
Acetabuliferous: Furnished with fleshy cups for adhering to bodies, as cuttlefish, etc.
Appoint: To ordain; to determine; to arrange.
Actiniform: Having a radiated form, like a sea anemone.
Autostylic: Having the mandibular arch articulated directly to the cranium, as in the skulls of the Amphibia.
Acephalist: One who acknowledges no head or superior.
Asturian: Of or pertaining to Asturias in Spain.
Ankus: An elephant goad with a sharp spike and hook, resembling a short-handled boat hook.
Artiste: One peculiarly dexterous and tasteful in almost any employment, as an opera dancer, a hairdresser, a cook.
Aporosa: A group of corals in which the coral is not porous; -- opposed to Perforata.
Abdominothoracic: Relating to the abdomen and the thorax, or chest.
axiology: the study of values and value judgments.
Avalanche: A large mass or body of snow and ice sliding swiftly down a mountain side, or falling down a precipice.
allographic: of or pertaining to an allograph.
Acrimoniousness: The quality of being acrimonious; asperity; acrimony.
Assumptive: Assumed, or capable of being assumed; characterized by assumption; making unwarranted claims.
Aichs metal: A kind of gun metal, containing copper, zinc, and iron, but no tin.
Archiannelida: A group of Annelida remarkable for having no external segments or distinct ventral nerve ganglions.
Affrightment: Affright; the state of being frightened; sudden fear or alarm.
Access: A coming to, or near approach; admittance; admission; accessibility; as, to gain access to a prince.
Ammodytidae: a family comprising the sand lances.
Aspalathus: A thorny shrub yielding a fragrant oil.
Aching: That aches; continuously painful. See Ache.
Abaser: He who, or that which, abases.
\u00c6sthesia: Perception by the senses; feeling; -- the opposite of anæsthesia.
Alloxantin: A substance produced by acting upon uric with warm and very dilute nitric acid.
Artamidae: a natural family comprising the wood swallows.
Avarice: An excessive or inordinate desire of gain; greediness for wealth; covetousness; cupidity.
Archenteron: The primitive enteron or undifferentiated digestive sac of a gastrula or other embryo. See Illust. under Invagination.
Archchamberlain: A chief chamberlain; -- an officer of the old German empire, whose office was similar to that of the great chamberlain in England.
Annunciable: That may be announced or declared; declarable.
Aluminium: same as aluminum, chiefly British in usage.
Aladinist: One of a sect of freethinkers among the Mohammedans.
Adansonia: A genus of great trees related to the Bombax.  There are two species, Adansonia digitata, the baobab or monkey-bread of Africa and India, and Adansonia Gregorii, the sour gourd or cream-of-tartar tree of Australia.  Both have a trunk of moderate height, but of enormous diameter, and a wide-spreading head.  The fruit is oblong, and filled with pleasantly acid pulp.  The wood is very soft, and the bark is used by the natives for making ropes and cloth.
Amphibology: A phrase, discourse, or proposition, susceptible of two interpretations; and hence, of uncertain meaning. It differs from equivocation, which arises from the twofold sense of a single term.
auriculoventricular: relating to or affecting the atria and ventricles of the heart.
Argentinidae: a family of small marine soft-finned fishes with long silvery bodies; related to salmons and trouts.
Algological: Of or pertaining to algology; as, algological specimens.
Athetize: To set aside or reject as spurious, as by marking with an obelus.
Apocodeine: An alkaloid, C18H19NO2, prepared from codeine. In its effects it resembles apomorphine.
Arrowhead: the pointed head or striking tip of an arrow.
Addition: The act of adding two or more things together; -- opposed to subtraction or diminution.
Actor: One who acts, or takes part in any affair; a doer.
Aiguillette: A point or tag at the end of a fringe or lace; an aglet.
Appointor: The person who selects the appointee. See Appointee, 2.
Antediluvial: Before the flood, or Deluge, in Noah's time.
Antitypical: Of or pertaining to an antitype; explaining the type.
Atabrine: a drug once used to treat malaria (C23H30ClN3O); chemically it is a derivative of the tricyclic structure acridine: 6-chloro-9-[[4-(diethylamino-1-methylbutyl)]amino]-2-methoxyacridine.  It also has some anthelmintic activity against cestodes. Atabrine is a trademark.
Antiphthisic: Relieving or curing phthisis, or consumption.
anguished: suffering anguish; experiencing extreme pain, distress, or anxiety
\u00c6sopian: Of or pertaining to Æsop, or in his manner.
Aventail: The movable front to a helmet; the ventail.
Aleconner: Orig., an officer appointed to look to the goodness of ale and beer; also, one of the officers chosen by the liverymen of London to inspect the measures used in public houses. But the office is a sinecure. [Also called aletaster.]
Amputation: The act of amputating; esp. the operation of cutting off a limb or projecting part of the body.
Allision: The act of dashing against, or striking upon.
Anomural: Irregular in the character of the tail or abdomen; as, the anomural crustaceans.
Astonishing: Very wonderful; of a nature to excite astonishment; as, an astonishing event.
Attestation: The act of attesting; testimony; witness; a solemn or official declaration, verbal or written, in support of a fact; evidence. The truth appears from the attestation of witnesses, or of the proper officer. The subscription of a name to a writing as a witness, is an attestation.
Allegorizer: One who allegorizes, or turns things into allegory; an allegorist.
Apoplexy: Sudden diminution or loss of consciousness, sensation, and voluntary motion, usually caused by pressure on the brain.
Accountable: Liable to be called on to render an account; answerable; as, every man is accountable to God for his conduct.
Anagallis: a genus of chiefly Old World herbs.
Amphirhina: A name applied to the elasmobranch fishes, because the nasal sac is double.
Administratorship: The position or office of an administrator.
A\u00ebrography: A description of the air or atmosphere; aërology.
Ammoniac: The concrete juice (gum resin) of an umbelliferous plant, the Dorema ammoniacum. It is brought chiefly from Persia in the form of yellowish tears, which occur singly, or are aggregated into masses. It has a peculiar smell, and a nauseous, sweet taste, followed by a bitter one. It is inflammable, partially soluble in water and in spirit of wine, and is used in medicine as an expectorant and resolvent, and for the formation of certain plasters.
Acroterium: One of the small pedestals, for statues or other ornaments, placed on the apex and at the basal angles of a pediment. Acroteria are also sometimes placed upon the gables in Gothic architecture.
Aqueduct: A conductor, conduit, or artificial channel for conveying water, especially one for supplying large cities with water.
actualized: changed from potential to actual; as, saw his worst fears actualized.
Aldehyde: A colorless, mobile, and very volatile liquid obtained from alcohol by certain processes of oxidation.
Amicableness: The quality of being amicable; amicability.
Award: A judgment, sentence, or final decision. Specifically: The decision of arbitrators in a case submitted.
Apteryx: A genus of New Zealand birds about the size of a hen, with only short rudiments of wings, armed with a claw and without a tail; the kiwi. It is allied to the gigantic extinct moas of the same country. Five species are known.
Armor: Defensive arms for the body; any clothing or covering worn to protect one's person in battle.
Atterration: The act of filling up with earth, or of forming land with alluvial earth.
Anaplerotic: Filling up; promoting granulation of wounds or ulcers.
Ant-hill: A mound thrown up by ants or by termites in forming their nests.
Ambler: A horse or a person that ambles.
Antilegomena: Certain books of the New Testament which were for a time not universally received, but which are now considered canonical. These are the Epistle to the Hebrews, the Epistles of James and Jude, the second Epistle of Peter, the second and third Epistles of John, and the Revelation. The undisputed books are called the Homologoumena.
acid-wash: to wash (blue jeans) in acid, so as to cause the color to fade.
Amish: Of, pertaining to, or designating, the followers of Jacob Amman, a strict Mennonite of the 17th century, who even proscribed the use of buttons and shaving as “worldly conformity”. There are several branches of Amish Mennonites in the United States.  A branch having particularly strict adherence to the Amish principles are called Old Order Amish
Apprehensiveness: The quality or state of being apprehensive.
Abacist: One who uses an abacus in casting accounts; a calculator.
Allantois: A membranous appendage of the embryos of mammals, birds, and reptiles, -- in mammals serving to connect the fetus with the parent; the urinary vesicle.
Afflatus: A breath or blast of wind.
Archilochian: Of or pertaining to the satiric Greek poet Archilochus; as, Archilochian meter.
Allantoic: Pertaining to, or contained in, the allantois.
Allantoid: Of or pertaining to the allantois.
Abnormity: Departure from the ordinary type; irregularity; monstrosity.
Allantoin: A crystalline, transparent, colorless substance found in the allantoic liquid of the fetal calf; -- formerly called allantoic acid and amniotic acid.
Agglomerative: Having a tendency to gather together, or to make collections.
Argonne: an American operation in World War I (1918); American troops under Pershing drove back the German armies which were saved only by the Armistice on November 11.
Axially: In relation to, or in a line with, an axis; in the axial (magnetic) line.
Attaste: To taste or cause to taste.
Atramentarious: Like ink; suitable for making ink. Sulphate of iron (copperas, green vitriol) is called atramentarious, as being used in making ink.
Adunc: Hooked; as, a parrot has an adunc bill.
Anallantoic: Without, or not developing, an allantois.
Alternativeness: The quality of being alternative, or of offering a choice between two.
Apoplectic: One liable to, or affected with, apoplexy.
actuating: causing motion or action or change
Augean: Of or pertaining to Augeus, king of Elis, whose stable contained 3000 oxen, and had not been cleaned for 30 years. Hercules cleansed it in a single day.
Acquirability: The quality of being acquirable; attainableness.
Anthracnose: Any one of several fungus diseases, caused by parasitic species of the series Melanconiales, attacking the bean, grape, melon, cotton, and other plants. In the case of the grape, brown concave spots are formed on the stem and fruit, and the disease is called bird's-eye rot.
Alcedo: A genus of perching birds, including the European kingfisher (Alcedo ispida). See Halcyon.
Autonomic: Having the power of self-government; autonomous.
Ardennes: a wooded plateau in the Champagne-Ardenne region of France; the site of intense fighting in World Wars I and II.
Azarole: The Neapolitan medlar (Cratægus azarolus), a shrub of southern Europe; also, its fruit.
Ampliative: Enlarging a conception by adding to that which is already known or received.
Aslant: In a slanting direction over; athwart.
Anatine: Of or pertaining to the ducks; ducklike.
Apologizer: One who makes an apology; an apologist.
Alloxanic: Of or pertaining to alloxan; -- applied to an acid obtained by the action of soluble alkalies on alloxan.
australopithecine: of or pertaining to the genus Australopithecus.
Archoplasm: The substance from which attraction spheres develop in mitotic cell division, and of which they consist.
Agile: Having the faculty of quick motion in the limbs; apt or ready to move; nimble; active; as, an agile boy; an agile tongue.
Accumulative: Characterized by accumulation; serving to collect or amass; cumulative; additional.
Acalephoid: Belonging to or resembling the Acalephæ or jellyfishes.
Atavic: Pertaining to a remote ancestor, or to atavism.
Antler: The entire horn, or any branch of the horn, of a cervine animal, as of a stag.
Ambitiousness: The quality of being ambitious; ambition; pretentiousness.
Aftergame: A second game; hence, a subsequent scheme or expedient.
Almadia: A bark canoe used by the Africans.
Astrologer: One who studies the stars; an astronomer.
Attemptable: Capable of being attempted, tried, or attacked.
Assessorial: Of or pertaining to an assessor, or to a court of assessors.
Accolade: A ceremony formerly used in conferring knighthood, consisting of an embrace, and a slight blow on the shoulders with the flat blade of a sword.
Antilogy: A contradiction between any words or passages in an author.
Athermanous: Not transmitting heat; -- opposed to diathermanous.
Automatic: Having an inherent power of action or motion.
afropavo: an African fowl genus; both sexes are brightly colored.
Acidity: The quality of being sour; sourness; tartness; sharpness to the taste; as, the acidity of lemon juice.
Attic: A low story above the main order or orders of a facade, in the classical styles; -- a term introduced in the 17th century. Hence:
Asteriscus: The smaller of the two otoliths found in the inner ear of many fishes.
Arenation: A sand bath; application of hot sand to the body.
Auscultation: The act of listening or hearkening to.
Aclinic: Without inclination or dipping; -- said of the imaginary line near the earth's equator on which the magnetic needle balances itself horizontally, having no dip.  The aclinic line is also termed the magnetic equator.
Areometric: Pertaining to, or measured by, an areometer.
Antiquate: To make old, or obsolete; to make antique; to make old in such a degree as to put out of use; hence, to make void, or abrogate.
asthenosphere: the lower layer of the earth's crust, below the lithosphere.  It is estimated as from fifty to several hundred miles thick. It is less rigid than the lithosphere, but still rigid enough to transmit some transverse seismic waves.
Alphabetism: The expression of spoken sounds by an alphabet.
Astoop: In a stooping or inclined position.
29th: coming next after the twenty-eighth in a series
Amyl nitrite: A yellowish oily volatile liquid, C5H11NO2, used in medicine as a heart stimulant and a vasodilator. The inhalation of its vapor instantly produces flushing of the face.
Avuncular: Of or pertaining to an uncle.
Allineation: Alignment; position in a straight line, as of two planets with the sun.
7th: coming next after the sixth in a series
Attempt: A essay, trial, or endeavor; an undertaking; an attack, or an effort to gain a point; esp. an unsuccessful, as contrasted with a successful, effort.
Available: Having sufficient power, force, or efficacy, for the object; effectual; valid; as, an available plea.
Accidentalness: The quality of being accidental; casualness.
Amazon: One of a fabulous race of female warriors in Scythia; hence, a female warrior.
Armrack: A frame, generally vertical, for holding small arms.
Algonquin: One of a widely spread family of Indians, including many distinct tribes, which formerly occupied most of the northern and eastern part of North America. The name was originally applied to a group of Indian tribes north of the River St. Lawrence.
Abroach: Broached; in a condition for letting out or yielding liquor, as a cask which is tapped.
Aspergilliform: Resembling the aspergillum in form; as, an aspergilliform stigma.
Acrospire: To put forth the first sprout.
Abominate: To turn from as ill-omened; to hate in the highest degree, as if with religious dread; loathe; as, to abominate all impiety.
Abecedary: A primer; the first principle or rudiment of anything.
asterismal: of or pertaining to asterisms or constellations
Apotactite: One of a sect of ancient Christians, who, in supposed imitation of the first believers, renounced all their possessions.
Absolute: In a plane, the two imaginary circular points at infinity; in space of three dimensions, the imaginary circle at infinity.
Anchorwoman: a woman television reporter who coordinates a broadcast to which several correspondents contribute.  Female correlate of anchorman.
Auricularia: A kind of holothurian larva, with soft, blunt appendages. See Illustration in Appendix.
Agkistrodon: a genus of snakes comprising the copperheads.
Atrial: Of or pertaining to an atrium.
alligator: to form shallow cracks in a reticulated pattern on the surface, or in a coating on the surface, of an object.
Autocephalous: Having its own head; independent of episcopal or patriarchal jurisdiction, as certain Greek churches.
Autotransformer: A transformer in which part of the primary winding is used as a secondary winding, or vice versa; -- called also a compensator or balancing coil.
Ache: To suffer pain; to have, or be in, pain, or in continued pain; to be distressed.
Asbestus: A variety of amphibole or of pyroxene, occurring in long and delicate fibers, or in fibrous masses or seams, usually of a white, gray, or green-gray color. The name is also given to a similar variety of serpentine.
allelomorphic: of, pertaining to, or characteristic of an allelomorph.
Adelaster: A provisional name for a plant which has not had its flowers botanically examined, and therefore has not been referred to its proper genus.
Aplodontiidae: a family of mammals comprising the mountain beavers.
Algerine: A native or one of the people of Algiers or Algeria. Also, a pirate.
Atrium: A square hall lighted from above, into which rooms open at one or more levels.
Afield: To, in, or on the field.
Aggrandizement: The act of aggrandizing, or the state of being aggrandized or exalted in power, rank, honor, or wealth; exaltation; enlargement; as, the emperor seeks only the aggrandizement of his own family.
Abb: Among weavers, yarn for the warp. Hence, abb wool is wool for the abb.
acetylcholine: a neurotransmitter released by the transmitting dendron at autononmous synapses and at neuromuscular junctions.  It is a quaternary amine with an obligatory negative counterion.  The nominal formula for the hydroxide form is C7H17NO3.  Structural formula (CH3)3N(+)CH2CH2.O.CO.CH3.OH(-).
airstrip: an airfield without normal airport facilities.
Alveoliform: Having the form of alveoli, or little sockets, cells, or cavities.
Aby: To pay for; to suffer for; to atone for; to make amends for; to give satisfaction.
Acutely: In an acute manner; sharply; keenly; with nice discrimination.
aerated: treated by having air passed or bubbled through it for purification; -- of a liquid
Animalization: The act of animalizing; the giving of animal life, or endowing with animal properties.
Axiomatic: Of or pertaining to an axiom; having the nature of an axiom; self-evident; characterized by axioms.
Apatite: Native phosphate of lime, occurring usually in six-sided prisms, color often pale green, transparent or translucent.
Agar-agar: A fucus or seaweed much used in the East for soups and jellies; Ceylon moss (Gracilaria lichenoides).
Aftermath: A second moving; the grass which grows after the first crop of hay in the same season; rowen.
airbrake: a small parachute or articulated flap to reduce the speed of an aircraft.
Anisostemonous: Having unequal stamens; having stamens different in number from the petals.
ashcan: a bin that holds rubbish until it is collected.
Arch\u00e6ologic: Relating to archæology, or antiquities; as, archæological researches.
Ab-: A prefix in many words of Latin origin. It signifies from, away , separating, or departure, as in abduct, abstract, abscond. See A-(6).
Alias: A second or further writ which is issued after a first writ has expired without effect.
Autocatalysis: Self-catalysis; catalysis of a substance by one of its own products, as of silver oxide by the silver formed by reduction of a small portion of it.
Allowance: To put upon a fixed allowance (esp. of provisions and drink); to supply in a fixed and limited quantity; as, the captain was obliged to allowance his crew; our provisions were allowanced.
Arch\u00e6ostomatous: Applied to a gastrula when the blastopore does not entirely close up.
Apothecary: One who prepares and sells drugs or compounds for medicinal purposes.
Absorber: One who, or that which, absorbs.
Alburnum: The white and softer part of wood, between the inner bark and the hard wood or duramen; sapwood.
Amphicome: A kind of figured stone, rugged and beset with eminences, anciently used in divination.
Accessary: One who, not being present, contributes as an assistant or instigator to the commission of an offense.
Acetimeter: An instrument for estimating the amount of acetic acid in vinegar or in any liquid containing acetic acid.
ascomycete: any fungus of the class Ascomycetes (or subdivision Ascomycota) in which the spores are formed inside an ascus.
Argentinian: a native or inhabitant of Argentina.
Appellate: A person or prosecuted for a crime. [Obs.] See Appellee.
Apologist: One who makes an apology; one who speaks or writes in defense of a faith, a cause, or an institution; especially, one who argues in defense of Christianity.
Analysis: A resolution of anything, whether an object of the senses or of the intellect, into its constituent or original elements; an examination of the component parts of a subject, each separately, as the words which compose a sentence, the tones of a tune, or the simple propositions which enter into an argument. It is opposed to synthesis.
Arrow: A missile weapon of offense, slender, pointed, and usually feathered and barbed, to be shot from a bow.
Arraignment: The act of arraigning, or the state of being arraigned; the act of calling and setting a prisoner before a court to answer to an indictment or complaint.
Autogenetic topography: A system of land forms produced by the free action of rain and streams on rocks of uniform texture.
Amniota: That group of vertebrates which develops in its embryonic life the envelope called the amnion. It comprises the reptiles, the birds, and the mammals.
Apocryphalness: The quality or state of being apocryphal; doubtfulness of credit or genuineness.
Anhimidae: a family of aquatic birds of South America.  They are called screamers due to their harsh trumpeting call.
alpha particle: a particle emitted at high velocity from certain radioactive substances.  It is identical to the helium nucleus, consisting of two protons and two neutrons.  Rays of such particles are called alpha rays.
A B C: The first three letters of the alphabet, used for the whole alphabet.
Andrenidae: a large family of solitary short-tongued bees most of which burrow in the ground.
Aspersorium: The stoup, basin, or other vessel for holy water in Roman Catholic churches.
Armada: A fleet of armed ships; a squadron. Specifically, the Spanish fleet which was sent to assail England, a. d. 1558.
Agriculture: The art or science of cultivating the ground, including the harvesting of crops, and the rearing and management of live stock; tillage; husbandry; farming.
Anticoherer: A device, one form of which consists of a scratched deposit of silver on glass, used in connection with the receiving apparatus for reading wireless signals.
