The electric waves falling on this contrivance increase its resistance several times. The anticoherer can be used in conjunction with a telephone.
Anaphora: A repetition of a word or of words at the beginning of two or more successive clauses.
Aboral: Situated opposite to, or away from, the mouth.
Amphoteric: Partly one and partly the other; neither acid nor alkaline; neutral.
aerodynamics: The science which treats of the air and other gaseous bodies under the action of force, and of their mechanical effects.
Anathema: A ban or curse pronounced with religious solemnity by ecclesiastical authority, and accompanied by excommunication. Hence: Denunciation of anything as accursed.
Antimere: One of the two halves of bilaterally symmetrical animals; one of any opposite symmetrical or homotypic parts in animals and plants.
Assumpt: That which is assumed; an assumption.
Antihelix: The curved elevation of the cartilage of the ear, within or in front of the helix. See Ear.
Auxometer: An instrument for measuring the magnifying power of a lens or system of lenses.
Asterolepis: A genus of fishes, some of which were eighteen or twenty feet long, found in a fossil state in the Old Red Sandstone.
Agger: An earthwork; a mound; a raised work.
Abiogenist: One who believes that life can be produced independently of antecedent.
alkane: a non-aromatic saturated acyclic hydrocarbon with the general formula CnH(2n+2).  A member of the alkane series.
Acarus: A genus including many species of small mites.
Anthrax vaccine: A fluid vaccine obtained by growing a bacterium (Bacillus anthracis, formerly Bacterium anthracis) in beef broth. It is used to immunize animals, esp. cattle.
Actino-chemistry: Chemistry in its relations to actinism.
agnise: be fully aware or cognizant of.
Associateship: The state of an associate, as in Academy or an office.
Ancon: The corner or quoin of a wall, cross-beam, or rafter.
Arraign: To appeal to; to demand; as, to arraign an assize of novel disseizin.
Appreciativeness: The quality of being appreciative; quick recognition of excellence.
Anemometry: The act or process of ascertaining the force or velocity of the wind.
Anno Domini: In the year of the Christian era; as, a. d. 1887.
Achromatopsy: Color blindness; inability to distinguish colors; Daltonism.
Answerably: In an answerable manner; in due proportion or correspondence; suitably.
Antilogous: Of the contrary name or character; -- opposed to analogous.
Azimuthal: Of or pertaining to the azimuth; in a horizontal circle.
austenite: a solid solution of ferric carbide or carbon in iron; -- it cools to form pearlite or martensite.
Anthropomorphism: The representation of the Deity, or of a polytheistic deity, under a human form, or with human attributes and affections.
Antilithic: Tending to prevent the formation of urinary calculi, or to destroy them when formed.
airt: to point out the way; to direct or guide.
Anthropomorphist: One who attributes the human form or other human attributes to the Deity or to anything not human.
Aizoaceae: a natural family of succulent herbs or small shrubs mostly of South Africa but also New Zealand and North America: carpetweeds; fig marigolds.
40th: coming next after the thirty-ninth in position
Atheroma: An encysted tumor containing curdy matter.
Androdi\u0153cious: Having perfect and staminate flowers on different plants.
Audiometer: An instrument by which the power of hearing can be gauged and recorded on a scale.
ack-ack: Artillery designed to shoot upward at airplanes; antiaircraft artillery.
Ablation: A carrying or taking away; removal.
Aurichalcite: A hydrous carbonate of copper and zinc, found in pale green or blue crystalline aggregations. It yields a kind of brass on reduction.
Anthophore: The stipe when developed into an internode between calyx and corolla, as in the Pink family.
Advisory: Having power to advise; containing advice; as, an advisory council; their opinion is merely advisory.
Abominably: In an abominable manner; very odiously; detestably.
Allotropism: The property of existing in two or more conditions which are distinct in their physical or chemical relations.
Acetanilide: An amide formed from aniline and an acetyl group (C6H5.NH.CO.CH3); it is a white crystalline compound used as an analgesic and also as an antipyretic. It has molecular weight 135.16.
Allah: The name of the Supreme Being, in use among the Arabs and the Mohammedans generally.
Awhape: To confound; to terrify; to amaze.
Alphabetarian: A learner of the alphabet; an abecedarian.
Allay: To mix (metals); to mix with a baser metal; to alloy; to deteriorate.
Abaculus: A small tile of glass, marble, or other substance, of various colors, used in making ornamental patterns in mosaic pavements.
A posteriori: Characterizing that kind of reasoning which derives propositions from the observation of facts, or by generalizations from facts arrives at principles and definitions, or infers causes from effects. This is the reverse of a priori reasoning.
Actual: Something actually received; real, as distinct from estimated, receipts.
Amort: As if dead; lifeless; spiritless; dejected; depressed.
Adept: Well skilled; completely versed; thoroughly proficient.
Albigenses: A sect of reformers opposed to the church of Rome in the 12th centuries.
Aurigraphy: The art of writing with or in gold.
Assignable: Capable of being assigned, allotted, specified, or designated; as, an assignable note or bill; an assignable reason; an assignable quantity.
Ante mortem: Before death; -- generally used adjectively; as, an ante-mortem statement; ante-mortem examination.
Areometer: An instrument for measuring the specific gravity of fluids; a form hydrometer.
Artist: One who practices some mechanic art or craft; an artisan.
Asterope: One of the Pleiades; -- called also Sterope.
affiance: To betroth; to pledge one's faith to for marriage, or solemnly promise (one's self or another) in marriage.
Allwork: Domestic or other work of all kinds; as, a maid of allwork, that is, a general servant.
Azimuth: The quadrant of an azimuth circle.
Anorthoclase: A feldspar closely related to orthoclase, but triclinic. It is chiefly a silicate of sodium, potassium, and aluminium. Sp. gr., 2.57 -- 2.60.
A\u00ebrobies: Microörganisms which live in contact with the air and need oxygen for their growth; as the microbacteria which form on the surface of putrefactive fluids; aerobes.
Arteriography: A systematic description of the arteries.
Anilide: One of a class of compounds which may be regarded as amides in which more or less of the hydrogen has been replaced by phenyl.
Apace: With a quick pace; quick; fast; speedily.
Amboyna button: A chronic contagious affection of the skin, prevalent in the tropics.
Achromatous: Lacking, or deficient in, color; as, achromatous blood.
ajour: of or pertaining to objects which are pierced or decorated with an openwork pattern.
Appetize: To make hungry; to whet the appetite of.
Anna: An East Indian money of account, the sixteenth of a rupee, or about 2&unr_; cents.
Atrocha: A kind of chætopod larva in which no circles of cilia are developed.
Acerbate: To sour; to imbitter; to irritate.
Ascariasis: A disease, usually accompanied by colicky pains and diarrhea, caused by the presence of ascarids in the gastrointestinal canal.
Apehood: The state of being an ape.
Aventurine: A kind of glass, containing gold-colored spangles. It was produced in the first place by the accidental (par aventure) dropping of some brass filings into a pot of melted glass.
Accumulator: One who, or that which, accumulates, collects, or amasses.
Averseness: The quality of being averse; opposition of mind; unwillingness.
Assibilate: To make sibilant; to change to a sibilant.
Aphanipterous: Of or pertaining to the Aphaniptera.
Appurtenant: Something which belongs or appertains to another thing; an appurtenance.
Araneiform: Having the form of a spider.
Albuminuria: A morbid condition in which albumin is present in the urine.
Alum schist: A variety of shale or clay slate, containing iron pyrites, the decomposition of which leads to the formation of alum, which often effloresces on the rock.
Atilt: In the manner of a tilter; in the position, or with the action, of one making a thrust.
Actuarial: Of or pertaining to actuaries; as, the actuarial value of an annuity.
Agent: One who exerts power, or has the power to act; an actor.
A cappella: In church or chapel style; -- said of compositions sung in the old church style, without instrumental accompaniment; as, a mass a capella, i. e., a mass purely vocal.
Abominableness: The quality or state of being abominable; odiousness.
Aberrant: Wandering; straying from the right way.
Acquaint: To furnish or give experimental knowledge of; to make (one) to know; to make familiar; -- followed by with.
Aruspex: One of the class of diviners among the Etruscans and Romans, who foretold events by the inspection of the entrails of victims offered on the altars of the gods.
Azerbaidzhan: a country in the Caucuses, formerly an Asian Soviet.
Aquiline: Belonging to or like an eagle.
Acuity: Sharpness or acuteness, as of a needle, wit, etc.
Acnode: An isolated point not upon a curve, but whose coördinates satisfy the equation of the curve so that it is considered as belonging to the curve.
Archduchess: The consort of an archduke; also, a princess of the imperial family of Austria. See Archduke.
Articulation: A joint or juncture between bones in the skeleton.
Amuck: In a frenzied and reckless manner.
Apish: Having the qualities of an ape; prone to imitate in a servile manner. Hence: Apelike; fantastically silly; foppish; affected; trifling.
Augury: The art or practice of foretelling events by observing the actions of birds, etc.; divination.
Argus: A fabulous being of antiquity, said to have had a hundred eyes, who has placed by Juno to guard Io.  His eyes were transplanted to the peacock's tail.
Antibrachium: That part of the fore limb between the brachium and the carpus; the forearm.
Aphonic: Without voice; voiceless; nonvocal; incapable of all but whispered speech.
Ampleness: The state or quality of being ample; largeness; fullness; completeness.
Appertain: To belong or pertain, whether by right, nature, appointment, or custom; to relate.
Argue: To debate or discuss; to treat by reasoning; as, the counsel argued the cause before a full court; the cause was well argued.
Algoid: Of the nature of, or resembling, an alga.
Attachable: Capable of being attached; esp., liable to be taken by writ or precept.
Avocate: To call off or away; to withdraw; to transfer to another tribunal.
Abb\u00e9: The French word answering to the English abbot, the head of an abbey; but commonly a title of respect given in France to every one vested with the ecclesiastical habit or dress.
Angle: To try to gain by some insinuating artifice; to allure.
Acetal: A limpid, colorless, inflammable liquid from the slow oxidation of alcohol under the influence of platinum black.
Axletree: A bar or beam of wood or iron, connecting the opposite wheels of a carriage, on the ends of which the wheels revolve.
Azollaceae: a family designation used in some classifications for the genus Azolla.
Agglutinate: United with glue or as with glue; cemented together.
astrocytoma: a tumor of nervous tissue derived from interstitial cells, in which the cells are relatively well-differentiated and resemble astrocytes.  The occur primarily in the crebrum and cerebellum.
Anglesite: A native sulphate of lead. It occurs in white or yellowish transparent, prismatic crystals.
Ancillary administration: An administration subordinate to, and in aid of, the primary or principal administration of an estate.
90th: coming next after the eighty-ninth in a series
Arbitrary: Depending on will or discretion; not governed by any fixed rules; as, an arbitrary decision; an arbitrary punishment.
ageism: discrimination against middle-aged and elderly people.
Accuser: One who accuses; one who brings a charge of crime or fault.
Accused: Charged with offense; as, an accused person.
Arousal: The act of arousing, or the state of being aroused.
Apostemate: To form an abscess; to swell and fill with pus.
Alternateness: The quality of being alternate, or of following by turns.
Ammite: Oölite or roestone; -- written also hammite.
autarkic: not relying on imports; -- of countries.
Around: On all sides of; encircling; encompassing; so as to make the circuit of; about.
authorise: grant authorization or clearance for.  Same as authorize.
Ar\u00eate: An acute and rugged crest of a mountain range or a subsidiary ridge between two mountain gorges.
Asmonean: One of the Asmonean family.  The Asmoneans were leaders and rulers of the Jews from 168 to 35 b. c.
An\u00e6mia: A morbid condition in which the blood is deficient in quality or in quantity.
Appeasement: The act of appeasing, or the state of being appeased; pacification.
aquilege: a plant of the genus Aquilegia having irregular showy spurred flowers; N temperate regions esp. mountains.
Amidin: Start modified by heat so as to become a transparent mass, like horn. It is soluble in cold water.
Ajouan: The fruit of Ammi Copticum, syn. Carum Ajowan, used both as a medicine and as a condiment. An oil containing thymol is extracted from it. Called also Javanee seed, Javanese seed, and ajava.
Able: To make able; to enable; to strengthen.
Ably: In an able manner; with great ability; as, ably done, planned, said.
Amygdaline: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, almonds.
Artillerist: A person skilled in artillery or gunnery; a gunner; an artilleryman.
Albacore: A name applied to several large fishes of the Mackerel family (Scombridae), esp. Thunnus alalunga (formerly Orcynus alalonga); it is a type of tuna or tunny.  The name has been also applied to a larger related species, Thunnus thynnus (formerly Orcynus thynnus), common in the Mediterranean and Atlantic, which is called in New England the horse mackerel.
Agility: The quality of being agile; the power of moving the limbs quickly and easily; nimbleness; activity; quickness of motion; as, strength and agility of body.
aneurismatic: of or pertaining to an aneurysm.
27th: coming next after the twenty-sixth in a series
Aeolic: the dialect of Ancient Greek spoken in Thessaly and Boeotia and Aeolis.
Antichronical: Deviating from the proper order of time.
Anight: In the night time; at night.
Arbored: Furnished with an arbor; lined with trees.
Athlete: One who contended for a prize in the public games of ancient Greece or Rome.
Affiancer: One who makes a contract of marriage between two persons.
Art: The employment of means to accomplish some desired end; the adaptation of things in the natural world to the uses of life; the application of knowledge or power to practical purposes.
\u00c6cidium: A form of fruit in the cycle of development of the Rusts or Brands, an order of fungi, formerly considered independent plants.
audiotape: magnetic tape for use in recording sound.
Alth\u00e6a: A genus of plants of the Mallow family. It includes the officinal marsh mallow, and the garden hollyhocks.
Amplexicaul: Clasping or embracing a stem, as the base of some leaves.
Axillaries: Feathers connecting the under surface of the wing and the body, and concealed by the closed wing.
Abstention: The act of abstaining; a holding aloof.
Arrack: A name in the East Indies and the Indian islands for all ardent spirits. Arrack is often distilled from a fermented mixture of rice, molasses, and palm wine of the cocoanut tree or the date palm, etc.
Amp\u00e8re: The unit of electric current; -- defined by the International Electrical Congress in 1893 and by U. S. Statute as, one tenth of the unit of current of the C. G. S. system of electro-magnetic units, or the practical equivalent of the unvarying current which, when passed through a standard solution of nitrate of silver in water, deposits silver at the rate of 0.001118 grams per second. Called also the international ampère.
Alethiology: The science which treats of the nature of truth and evidence.
Amphibrach: A foot of three syllables, the middle one long, the first and last short (˘ -- ˘); as, hăbēr&ebreve_;. In modern prosody the accented syllable takes the place of the long and the unaccented of the short; as, pro-phet"ic.
Aitchbone: The bone of the rump; also, the cut of beef surrounding this bone.
Antiqueness: The quality of being antique; an appearance of ancient origin and workmanship.
Appoggiatura: A passing tone preceding an essential tone, and borrowing the time it occupies from that; a short auxiliary or grace note one degree above or below the principal note unless it be of the same harmony; -- generally indicated by a note of smaller size, as in the illustration above. It forms no essential part of the harmony.
Aspiration: The act of aspirating; the pronunciation of a letter with a full or strong emission of breath; an aspirated sound.
Anthorism: A description or definition contrary to that which is given by the adverse party.
Arachnoidal: Pertaining to the arachnoid membrane; arachnoid.
Abudefduf: a genus comprising the damsel fishes.
Appellatively: After the manner of nouns appellative; in a manner to express whole classes or species; as, Hercules is sometimes used appellatively, that is, as a common name, to signify a strong man.
Afterings: The last milk drawn in milking; strokings.
Apteryges: An order of birds, including the genus Apteryx.
Axle guard: The part of the framing of a railway car or truck, by which an axle box is held laterally, and in which it may move vertically; -- also called a jaw in the United States, and a housing in England.
Argental: Of or pertaining to silver; resembling, containing, or combined with, silver.
A-sea: On the sea; at sea; toward the sea.
Azoleic: Pertaining to an acid produced by treating oleic with nitric acid.
accretive: Relating to accretion; increasing, or adding to, by growth.
Anastrophe: An inversion of the natural order of words; as, echoed the hills, for, the hills echoed.
Amassette: An instrument of horn used for collecting painters' colors on the stone in the process of grinding.
Alpinia: a genus of perennial rhizomatous herbs of Asia and Australia and Polynesia having ginger-scented rhizomes.
Albino: A person, whether negro, Indian, or white, in whom by some defect of organization the substance which gives color to the skin, hair, and eyes is deficient or in a morbid state. An albino has a skin of a milky hue, with hair of the same color, and eyes with deep red pupil and pink or blue iris. The term is also used of the lower animals, as white mice, elephants, etc.; and of plants in a whitish condition from the absence of chlorophyll.
Accentual: Of or pertaining to accent; characterized or formed by accent.
Abies: A genus of coniferous trees, properly called Fir, as the balsam fir and the silver fir. The spruces are sometimes also referred to this genus.
Aqua: Water; -- a word much used in pharmacy and the old chemistry, in various signification, determined by the word or words annexed.
Armhole: The cavity under the shoulder; the armpit.
Articular: A bone in the base of the lower jaw of many birds, reptiles, amphibians, and fishes.
Amphiscii: The inhabitants of the tropic, whose shadows in one part of the year are cast to the north, and in the other to the south, according as the sun is south or north of their zenith.
Abradant: A material used for grinding, as emery, sand, powdered glass, etc.
Away-going: Sown during the last years of a tenancy, but not ripe until after its expiration; -- said of crops.
Actinidiaceae: tropical trees or shrubs or woody vines.
Adjutory: Serving to help or assist; helping.
Assort: To agree; to be in accordance; to be adapted; to suit; to fall into a class or place.
Arthromere: One of the body segments of Arthropods. See Arthrostraca.
Amphigonic: Pertaining to amphigony; sexual; as, amphigonic propagation.
Actinia: An animal of the class Anthozoa, and family Actinidæ.  From a resemblance to flowers in form and color, they are often called animal flowers and sea anemones. [See Polyp.].
Anacanthini: A group of teleostean fishes destitute of spiny fin-rays, as the cod.
Actinic: Of or pertaining to actinism; as, actinic rays.
Ascidioidea: A group of Tunicata, often shaped like a two-necked bottle. The group includes, social, and compound species. The gill is a netlike structure within the oral aperture. The integument is usually leathery in texture. See Illustration in Appendix.
Asseverate: To affirm or aver positively, or with solemnity.
Antilogarithm: The number corresponding to a logarithm. The word has been sometimes, though rarely, used to denote the complement of a given logarithm; also the logarithmic cosine corresponding to a given logarithmic sine.
Asteroidal: Of or pertaining to an asteroid, or to the asteroids.
Automobilism: The use of automobiles, or the practices, methods, or the like, of those who use them.
Andesite: An eruptive rock allied to trachyte, consisting essentially of a triclinic feldspar, with pyroxene, hornblende, or hypersthene.
Adderwort: The common bistort or snakeweed (Polygonum bistorta).
albizzia: any of numerous trees or shrubs of the genus Albizia, of the legume family.
Afflux: A flowing towards; that which flows to; as, an afflux of blood to the head.
Anchor light: The lantern shown at night by a vessel at anchor. International rules of the road require vessels at anchor to carry from sunset to sunrise a single white light forward if under 150 feet in length, and if longer, two such lights, one near the stern and one forward.
Anticyclone: A movement of the atmosphere opposite in character, as regards direction of the wind and distribution of barometric pressure, to that of a cyclone.
Accentor: One who sings the leading part; the director or leader.
Alopecist: A practitioner who tries to prevent or cure baldness.
Arcubalister: A crossbowman; one who used the arcubalist.
Authenticity: The quality of being authentic or of established authority for truth and correctness.
Arbitration: The hearing and determination of a cause between parties in controversy, by a person or persons chosen by the parties.
Antepredicament: A prerequisite to a clear understanding of the predicaments and categories, such as definitions of common terms.
Aragonite: A mineral identical in composition with calcite or carbonate of lime, but differing from it in its crystalline form and some of its physical characters.
Ascomycetes: A large class of higher fungi distinguished by septate hyphæ, and by having their spores formed in asci, or spore sacs; the sac fungi. It comprises many orders, among which are the yeasts, molds, mildews, truffles, morels, etc.  The class is coextensive with the phylum Ascomycota.
Atrichornis: the type genus of the Atrichornithidae.
\u00c6stheticism: The doctrine of æsthetics; æsthetic principles; devotion to the beautiful in nature and art.
Acetonuria: Excess of acetone in the urine, as in starvation or diabetes; -- a form of ketonuria.
Abnodation: The act of cutting away the knots of trees.
Analyzation: The act of analyzing, or separating into constituent parts; analysis.
\u00c6thogen: A compound of nitrogen and boro&unr_;, which, when heated before the blowpipe, gives a brilliant phosphorescent; boric nitride.
Artistic: Of or pertaining to art or to artists; made in the manner of an artist; conformable to art; characterized by art; showing taste or skill.
Amenableness: The quality or state of being amenable; liability to answer charges; answerableness.
12th: coming next after the eleventh in a series
Attainability: The quality of being attainable; attainableness.
alligatored: having cracks in a reticulated pattern, giving an appearance reminiscent of alligator hide; -- said of a surface coating, e.g., of paint, varnish, or glazing
Antipope: One who is elected, or claims to be, pope in opposition to the pope canonically chosen; esp. applied to those popes who resided at Avignon during the Great Schism.
Allotrophic: Changed or modified in nutritive power by the process of digestion.
Attemper: To reduce, modify, or moderate, by mixture; to temper; to regulate, as temperature.
Absterge: To make clean by wiping; to wipe away; to cleanse; hence, to purge.
Avener: An officer of the king's stables whose duty it was to provide oats for the horses.
Assyrian: Of or pertaining to Assyria, or to its inhabitants.
Alcove: A recessed portion of a room, or a small room opening into a larger one; especially, a recess to contain a bed; a lateral recess in a library.
Abater: One who, or that which, abates.
Amoroso: In a soft, tender, amatory style.
Abanga: A West Indian palm; also the fruit of this palm, the seeds of which are used as a remedy for diseases of the chest.
Alkekengi: An herbaceous plant of the nightshade family (Physalis alkekengi) and its fruit, which is a well flavored berry, the size of a cherry, loosely inclosed in a enlarged leafy calyx; -- also called winter cherry, ground cherry, and strawberry tomato.
Algorism: The art of calculating by nine figures and zero; computation with Arabic figures.
Adenotomy: Dissection of, or incision into, a gland or glands.
Accrument: The process of accruing, or that which has accrued; increase.
Acinus: One of the small grains or drupelets which make up some kinds of fruit, as the blackberry, raspberry, etc.
astrophysicist: an astronomer who studies the physical properties of celestial bodies.
Aurist: One skilled in treating and curing disorders of the ear.
Andreaea: a genus of brown or blackish Alpine mosses having a dehiscent capsule with 4 longitudinal slits.
Accouter: To furnish with dress, or equipments, esp. those for military service; to equip; to attire; to array.
Aculeate: Having a sting; covered with prickles; sharp like a prickle.
Adhesiveness: The quality of sticking or adhering; stickiness; tenacity of union.
Arundinaceous: Of or pertaining to a reed; resembling the reed or cane.
A\u00ebroclub: A club or association of persons interested in aëronautics.
Aquarelle: A design or painting in thin transparent water colors; also, the mode of painting in such colors.
Aconitum: The poisonous herb aconite; also, an extract from it.
Anabaptist: A name sometimes applied to a member of any sect holding that rebaptism is necessary for those baptized in infancy.
Adiabatic: Not giving out or receiving heat.
Affiliate: To connect or associate one's self; -- followed by with; as, they affiliate with no party.
Agora: An assembly; hence, the place of assembly, especially the market place, in an ancient Greek city.
ampere-turn: A unit of magnetomotive force equal to the product of one complete convolution (of a coiled conductor) into one ampère of current; thus, a conductor having five convolutions and carrying a current of half an ampère is said to have 21/2 ampère turns. The magnetizing effect of a coil is proportional to the number of its ampère turns.
all-devouring: both plant- and flesh-eating; -- said of animals.
Apocynin: A bitter principle obtained from the dogbane (Apocynum cannabinum).
Anglicization: The act of anglicizing, or making English in character.
Awakening: The act of awaking, or ceasing to sleep. Specifically: A revival of religion, or more general attention to religious matters than usual.
Ambrosiac: Having the qualities of ambrosia; delicious.
Ambrosian: Of or pertaining to St. Ambrose; as, the Ambrosian office, or ritual, a formula of worship in the church of Milan, instituted by St. Ambrose.
Ambrosial: Consisting of, or partaking of the nature of, ambrosia; delighting the taste or smell; delicious.
Alienee: One to whom the title of property is transferred; -- opposed to alienor.
Angelus: A form of devotion in which three Ave Marias are repeated.  It is said at morning, noon, and evening, at the sound of a bell.
Autoptic: Seen with one's own eyes; belonging to, or connected with, personal observation; as, autoptic testimony or experience.
Althorn: An instrument of the saxhorn family, used exclusively in military music, often replacing the French horn.
Alebench: A bench in or before an alehouse.
Araneose: Of the aspect of a spider's web; arachnoid.
Aureola: A celestial crown or accidental glory added to the bliss of heaven, as a reward to those (as virgins, martyrs, preachers, etc.) who have overcome the world, the flesh, and the devil.
Acorn: The fruit of the oak, being an oval nut growing in a woody cup or cupule.
Account book: A book in which accounts are kept.
Apollinaris water: An effervescing alkaline mineral water used as a table beverage. It is obtained from a spring in Apollinarisburg, near Bonn.
Always: At all times; ever; perpetually; throughout all time; continually; as, God is always the same.
Amercement: The infliction of a penalty at the discretion of the court; also, a mulct or penalty thus imposed. It differs from a fine, in that the latter is, or was originally, a fixed and certain sum prescribed by statute for an offense; but an amercement is arbitrary. Hence, the act or practice of affeering. [See Affeer.]
Aphorismatic: Pertaining to aphorisms, or having the form of an aphorism.
Avenious: Being without veins or nerves, as the leaves of certain plants.
Annunciatory: Pertaining to, or containing, announcement; making known.
Anamorphosis: A distorted or monstrous projection or representation of an image on a plane or curved surface, which, when viewed from a certain point, or as reflected from a curved mirror or through a polyhedron, appears regular and in proportion; a deformation of an image.
A\u00ebrodonetics: The science of gliding and soaring flight.
Anisopoda: A division of Crustacea, which, in some its characteristics, is intermediate between Amphipoda and Isopoda.
Air brake: A railway brake powered by compressed air.
akee: a tree (Blighia sapida) widely cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions for its fragrant flowers and colorful fruits; introduced in Jamaica by Captain Bligh of the HMS Bounty.
Acquiesce: To rest satisfied, or apparently satisfied, or to rest without opposition and discontent (usually implying previous opposition or discontent); to accept or consent by silence or by omitting to object; -- followed by in, formerly also by with and to.
Anachorism: An error in regard to the place of an event or a thing; a referring something to a wrong place.
acknowledge: To own or admit the knowledge of; to recognize as a fact or truth; to declare one's belief in; as, to acknowledge the being of a God.
Averment: The act of averring, or that which is averred; affirmation; positive assertion.
Ant egg: One of the small white egg-shaped pupæ or cocoons of the ant, often seen in or about ant-hills, and popularly supposed to be eggs.
Armful: As much as the arm can hold.
Ambary: A valuable East Indian fiber plant (Hibiscus cannabinus), or its fiber, which is used throughout India for making ropes, cordage, and a coarse canvas and sackcloth; -- called also brown Indian hemp.
Augitic: Pertaining to, or like, augite; containing augite as a principal constituent; as, augitic rocks.
Assistantly: In a manner to give aid.
Annulose: Furnished with, or composed of, rings or ringlike segments; ringed.
Armored cruiser: A man-of-war carrying a large coal supply, and more or less protected from the enemy's shot by iron or steel armor. There is no distinct and accepted classification distinguishing armored and protected cruisers from each other, except that the first have more or heavier armor than the second.
Annulosa: A division of the Invertebrata, nearly equivalent to the Articulata. It includes the Arthoropoda and Anarthropoda. By some zoölogists it is applied to the former only.
Alamire: The lowest note but one in Guido Aretino's scale of music.
Affirmative: That which affirms as opposed to that which denies; an affirmative proposition; that side of question which affirms or maintains the proposition stated; -- opposed to negative; as, there were forty votes in the affirmative, and ten in the negative.
Agricultural: Of or pertaining to agriculture; connected with, or engaged in, tillage; as, the agricultural class; agricultural implements, wages, etc.
Additive: Proper to be added; positive; -- opposed to subtractive.
Allodium: Freehold estate; land which is the absolute property of the owner; real estate held in absolute independence, without being subject to any rent, service, or acknowledgment to a superior. It is thus opposed to feud.
Acoumetry: The measuring of the power or extent of hearing.
Abra: A narrow pass or defile; a break in a mesa; the mouth of a cañon.
Aft: Near or towards the stern of a vessel; astern; abaft.
Austere: Sour and astringent; rough to the state; having acerbity; as, an austere crab apple; austere wine.
Acervate: Heaped, or growing in heaps, or closely compacted clusters.
Ascus: A small membranous bladder or tube in which are inclosed the seedlike reproductive particles or sporules of lichens and certain fungi.
Athecata: A division of Hydroidea in which the zooids are naked, or not inclosed in a capsule. See Tubularian.
Archidiaconal: Of or pertaining to an archdeacon.
Aerodynamic: Pertaining to the force of air in motion.
Antiseptic: a substance which kills or retards the growth of microorganisms, especially when used for protection against infection; a substance which prevents or retards putrefaction, or destroys, or protects from, putrefactive organisms; as, carbolic acid, alcohol, cinchona, and many other agents sold commercially.
Aspect ratio: The ratio of the long to the short side of an aëroplane, aërocurve, or wing.
Anthokyan: The blue coloring matter of certain flowers. Same as Cyanin.
Anchusin: A resinoid coloring matter obtained from alkanet root.
Angiostomous: With a narrow mouth, as the shell of certain gastropods.
Anchoretic: Pertaining to an anchoret or hermit; after the manner of an anchoret.
Abstainer: One who abstains; esp., one who abstains from the use of intoxicating liquors.
Anglian: Of or pertaining to the Angles.
Albuginaceae: a family of fungi that produce white blisterlike sori on certain flowering plants.
Aristotles lantern: The five united jaws and accessory ossicles of certain sea urchins.
A\u00ebtheogamous: Propagated in an unusual way; cryptogamous.
Aguish: Having the qualities of an ague; somewhat cold or shivering; chilly; shaky.
Aguise: To dress; to attire; to adorn.
Antiscriptural: Opposed to, or not in accordance with, the Holy Scriptures.
Astounding: Of a nature to astound; astonishing; amazing; as, an astounding force, statement, or fact.
Appetizer: Something which creates or whets an appetite.
Archaeozoic: the time from 1.5 billion to 5 billion years ago; the time when the earth's crust formed; a time when only unicellular organisms and the earliest forms of life are present.
Approachableness: The quality or state of being approachable; accessibility.
Ambulant: Walking; moving from place to place.
Astronomize: To study or to talk astronomy.
Aquarial: Of or pertaining to an aquarium.
Aquarian: One of a sect of Christian in the primitive church who used water instead of wine in the Lord's Supper.
Aristolochiaceae: a family comprising the birthworts; wild ginger.
Associative: Having the quality of associating; tending or leading to association; as, the associative faculty.
Air-built: Erected in the air; having no solid foundation; chimerical; as, an air-built castle.
Arborescence: The state of being arborescent; the resemblance to a tree in minerals, or crystallizations, or groups of crystals in that form; as, the arborescence produced by precipitating silver.
Adumbration: The act of adumbrating, or shadowing forth.
Archencephala: The division that includes man alone.
Aristocrat: One of the aristocracy or people of rank in a community; one of a ruling class; a noble.
Air chamber: A chamber or cavity filled with air, in an animal or plant.
Arch-: A prefix signifying chief, as in archbuilder, archfiend.
Arara: The palm (or great black) cockatoo, of Australia (Microglossus aterrimus).
antidisestablishmentarianism: the doctrine or political position that opposes the withdrawal of state recognition of an established church; -- used especially concerning the Anglican Church in England.  Opposed to disestablishmentarianism.
Archenteric: Relating to the archenteron; as, archenteric invagination.
Affirmable: Capable of being affirmed, asserted, or declared; -- followed by of; as, an attribute affirmable of every just man.
13th: coming next after the twelfth in a series
Acidification: The act or process of acidifying, or changing into an acid.
Antecede: To go before in time or place; to precede; to surpass.
Adherent: One who adheres; one who adheres; one who follows a leader, party, or profession; a follower, or partisan; a believer in a particular faith or church.
Antagonism: Opposition of action; counteraction or contrariety of things or principles.
Armor-plated: Covered with defensive plates of metal, as a ship of war; steel-clad.
Adequation: The act of equalizing; act or result of making adequate; an equivalent.
Antagonist: Antagonistic; opposing; counteracting; as, antagonist schools of philosophy.
Abdal: A religious devotee or dervish in Persia.
Antestomach: A cavity which leads into the stomach, as in birds.
Ahem: An exclamation to call one's attention; hem.
Averruncator: An instrument for pruning trees, having two blades, or a blade and a hook, fixed on a long rod and operated by a string or wire; a tree pruner.
Affidavit: A sworn statement in writing; a declaration in writing, signed and made upon oath before an authorized magistrate.
Amitosis: Cell division in which there is first a simple cleavage of the nucleus without change in its structure (such as the formation of chromosomes), followed by the division of the cytoplasm; direct cell division; -- opposed to mitosis. It is not the usual mode of division, and is believed by many to occur chiefly in highly specialized cells which are incapable of long-continued multiplication, in transitory structures, and in those in early stages of degeneration.
Akin: Of the same kin; related by blood; -- used of persons; as, the two families are near akin.
Alliteration: The repetition of the same letter at the beginning of two or more words immediately succeeding each other, or at short intervals; as in the following lines: -
Annwn: the other world; land of fairies.
Arch brick: A wedge-shaped brick used in the building of an arch.
Abdominoscopy: Examination of the abdomen to detect abdominal disease.
Adolescency: The quality of being adolescent; youthfulness.
Antimonsoon: The upper, contrary-moving current of the atmosphere over a monsoon.
Aoristic: Indefinite; pertaining to the aorist tense.
Affix: That which is affixed; an appendage; esp. one or more letters or syllables added at the end of a word; a suffix; a postfix.
Arquebus: A sort of hand gun or firearm a contrivance answering to a trigger, by which the burning match was applied. The musket was a later invention.
Apoda: A group of cirripeds, destitute of footlike organs.
Adolescence: The state of growing up from childhood to manhood or womanhood; youth, or the period of life between puberty and maturity, generally considered to be, in the male sex, from fourteen to twenty-one. Sometimes used with reference to the lower animals.
Amphibious: Having the ability to live both on land and in water, as frogs, crocodiles, beavers, and some plants.
Anemonic: An acrid, poisonous, crystallizable substance, obtained from, the anemone, or from anemonin.
Apple pie: A pie made of apples (usually sliced or stewed) with spice and sugar.
Anemonin: An acrid, poisonous, crystallizable substance, obtained from some species of anemone.
2-hitter: a game in which a pitcher allows the opposing team only 2 hits.
Antrustion: A vassal or voluntary follower of Frankish princes in their enterprises
Acheta: a genus of Orthopteran insects consisting of common house and field crickets.
Awake: Not sleeping or lethargic; roused from sleep; in a state of vigilance or action.
Azymite: One who administered the Eucharist with unleavened bread; -- a name of reproach given by those of the Greek church to the Latins.
Arboreous: Having the form, constitution, or habits, of a proper tree, in distinction from a shrub.
Astrut: Sticking out, or puffed out; swelling; in a swelling manner.
Agronomic: Pertaining to agronomy, of the management of farms.
Argillaceous: Of the nature of clay; consisting of, or containing, argil or clay; clayey.
Arbustive: Containing copses of trees or shrubs; covered with shrubs.
Ascidiozooid: One of the individual members of a compound ascidian. See Ascidioidea.
Assay pound: A small standard weight used in assaying bullion, etc., sometimes equaling 0.5 gram, but varying with the assayer.
Alimental: Supplying food; having the quality of nourishing; furnishing the materials for natural growth; as, alimental sap.
Asparagine: A white, nitrogenous, crystallizable substance, C4H8N2O3+H2O, found in many plants, and first obtained from asparagus.  It is believed to aid in the disposition of nitrogenous matter throughout the plant; -- called also altheine.
Allusively: Figuratively [Obs.]; by way of allusion; by implication, suggestion, or insinuation.
Accidence: The accidents, of inflections of words; the rudiments of grammar.
Acetyl: A complex, hypothetical radical, composed of two parts of carbon to three of hydrogen and one of oxygen. Its hydroxide is acetic acid.
Arhat: a Buddhist who has attained nirvana.
Anticipation: The act of anticipating, taking up, placing, or considering something beforehand, or before the proper time in natural order.
Aurigal: Of or pertaining to a chariot.
Aristolochiales: an order of plants distinguished by tubular petaloid perianth and inferior ovary.  It includes the Aristolochiaceae, Rafflesiaceae, and Hydnoraceae.
Appulsive: Striking against; impinging; as, the appulsive influence of the planets.
3: one more than two; denoting a quantity consisting of three items or units; -- representing the number three as an Arabic numeral
Animadvert: To take notice; to observe; -- commonly followed by that.
Anethol: A substance obtained from the volatile oils of anise, fennel, etc., in the form of soft shining scales; -- called also anise camphor.
Academian: A member of an academy, university, or college.
Apodeictically: So as to be evident beyond contradiction.
Agonist: One who contends for the prize in public games.
Arna: The wild buffalo of India (Bos, or Bubalus, arni), larger than the domestic buffalo and having enormous horns.
Aurochloride: The trichloride of gold combination with the chloride of another metal, forming a double chloride; -- called also chloraurate.
Apodyterium: The apartment at the entrance of the baths, or in the palestra, where one stripped; a dressing room.
astronavigation: navigating according to the positions of the stars.
Albescent: Becoming white or whitish; moderately white.
Archer fish: A small fish (Toxotes jaculator), of the East Indies; -- so called from its ejecting drops of water from its mouth at its prey. The name is also applied to Chætodon rostratus.
ameliorating: causing improvement in or reducing the bad effects of an unfavorable condition.
Asynchronous: Not simultaneous; not concurrent in time; -- opposed to synchronous.
Arsenic: Pertaining to, or derived from, arsenic; -- said of those compounds of arsenic in which this element has its highest equivalence; as, arsenic acid.
Agouara: The crab-eating raccoon (Procyon cancrivorus), found in the tropical parts of America.
Anthracometric: Of or pertaining to an anthracometer.
Anabas: A genus of fishes, remarkable for their power of living long out of water, and of making their way on land for considerable distances, and for climbing trees; the climbing fishes.
Albolith: A kind of plastic cement, or artificial stone, consisting chiefly of magnesia and silica; -- called also albolite.
Atomicity: Degree of atomic attraction; equivalence; valence; also (a later use) the number of atoms in an elementary molecule. See Valence.
Angiosporous: Having spores contained in cells or thecæ, as in the case of some fungi.
Amorous: Inclined to love; having a propensity to love, or to sexual enjoyment; loving; fond; affectionate; as, an amorous disposition.
Aposiopesis: A figure of speech in which the speaker breaks off suddenly, as if unwilling or unable to state what was in his mind; as, “I declare to you that his conduct -- but I can not speak of that, here.”
Attorneyship: The office or profession of an attorney; agency for another.
Aquiferous: Consisting or conveying water or a watery fluid; as, aquiferous vessels; the aquiferous system.
Abstinence: The act or practice of abstaining; voluntary forbearance of any action, especially the refraining from an indulgence of appetite, or from customary gratifications of animal or sensual propensities. Specifically, the practice of abstaining from intoxicating beverages, -- called also total abstinence.
Ambiparous: Characterized by containing the rudiments of both flowers and leaves; -- applied to a bud.
Arthropleura: The side or limb-bearing portion of an arthromere.
Arterial: Of or pertaining to an artery, or the arteries; as, arterial action; the arterial system.
Arteriac: Of or pertaining to the windpipe.
Americanize: To render American; to assimilate to the Americans in customs, ideas, etc.; to stamp with American characteristics.
Apostolate: The dignity, office, or mission, of an apostle; apostleship.
100th: coming next after the ninety-ninth in a series
Asaphus: A genus of trilobites found in the Lower Silurian formation. See Illust. in Append.
Abruptly pinnate: pinnate with a pair of leaflets at the apex, i.e. without an odd leaflet, or other appendage, at the end; -- said of a leaf shape
Allumette: A match for lighting candles, lamps, etc.
archepiscopal: of or pertaining to an archbishop.
apraxia: inability to make purposeful movements, but without paralysis or loss of sensory function.
apraxic: having uncoordinated muscular movements, symptomatic of a CNS disorder.
Acetamide: A white crystalline solid, from ammonia by replacement of an equivalent of hydrogen by acetyl.
Associability: The quality of being associable, or capable of association; associableness.
Amauropelta: a genus of epiphytic or terrestrial ferns of America and Africa and Polynesia.
Amygdalic: Of or pertaining to almonds; derived from amygdalin; as, amygdalic acid.
Acyl: An acid radical, as acetyl, malonyl, or benzoyl.  An acyl radical can be depicted as R-CO-, where -CO- is the carbonyl group, and R is the group that characterizes the acyl moiety.
Astromantic: Of or pertaining to divination by means of the stars; astrologic.
Absorbedly: In a manner as if wholly engrossed or engaged.
Amygdalin: A glucoside extracted from bitter almonds as a white, crystalline substance.
Attributable: Capable of being attributed; ascribable; imputable.
Autopneumatic: Acting or moving automatically by means of compressed air.
Athiorhodaceae: a family of small motile sulphur bacteria.
Appointive: Subject to appointment; as, an appointive office.
Acherontic: Of or pertaining to Acheron; infernal; hence, dismal, gloomy; moribund.
agreeing: in agreement; of the same mind; having the same opinion.
Alloy steel: Any steel containing a notable quantity of some other metal alloyed with the iron, usually chromium, nickel, manganese, tungsten, or vanadium.
Annoyance: The act of annoying, or the state of being annoyed; molestation; vexation; annoy.
assembly language: an artificial computer language with mnemonic codes representing the basic machine-language instructions of a computer, which can be interpreted by an assembler to produce a computer program in machine language.  Also informally referred to as assembler.
aeration: Exposure to the free action of the air; airing; as, aëration of soil, of spawn, etc.
Alveolar: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, alveoli or little cells, sacs, or sockets.
Asseveration: The act of asseverating, or that which is asseverated; positive affirmation or assertion; solemn declaration.
Adriatic: Of or pertaining to a sea so named, the northwestern part of which is known as the Gulf of Venice.
Adarce: A saltish concretion on reeds and grass in marshy grounds in Galatia. It is soft and porous, and was formerly used for cleansing the skin from freckles and tetters, and also in leprosy.
Adamant: A stone imagined by some to be of impenetrable hardness; a name given to the diamond and other substances of extreme hardness; but in modern mineralogy it has no technical signification. It is now a rhetorical or poetical name for the embodiment of impenetrable hardness.
Araneous: Cobweblike; extremely thin and delicate, like a cobweb; as, the araneous membrane of the eye. See Arachnoid.
Analyst: One who analyzes; formerly, one skilled in algebraical geometry; now commonly, one skilled in chemical analysis.
allophone: any one of two or more speech sounds that considered variants of the same phoneme.  For example, the p sounds of pin and spin are allophones of p; and the t sounds of toe stop and catnip  are allophones of t.
Ambigu: An entertainment at which a medley of dishes is set on at the same time.
Antiquarianism: Character of an antiquary; study or love of antiquities.
Amphitrocha: A kind of annelid larva having both a dorsal and a ventral circle of special cilia.
Ascetic: In the early church, one who devoted himself to a solitary and contemplative life, characterized by devotion, extreme self-denial, and self-mortification; a hermit; a recluse; hence, one who practices extreme rigor and self-denial in religious things.
Azorian: Of or pertaining to the Azores.
Actinomere: One of the radial segments composing the body of one of the Cœlenterata.
Arrowheaded: Shaped like the head of an arrow; cuneiform.
1st-class: a class mail comprising letters, postcards, and other mail sealed against inspection, having a higher priority than second, third, or fourth-class mail; -- it is the highest class of mail not handled in a special manner, as is registered or priority mail.
autotomy: spontaneous removal or casting off of a body part (as the tail of a lizard or claw or a lobster) especially when the organism is injured or under attack.
Arcade: A series of arches with the columns or piers which support them, the spandrels above, and other necessary appurtenances; sometimes open, serving as an entrance or to give light; sometimes closed at the back (as in the cut) and forming a decorative feature.
Amyss: Same as Amice, a hood or cape.
Ableness: Ability of body or mind; force; vigor.
Acne: A pustular affection of the skin, due to changes in the sebaceous glands.
Acquisitiveness: The quality of being acquisitive; propensity to acquire property; desire of possession.
Acropodium: The entire upper surface of the foot.
Atwite: To speak reproachfully of; to twit; to upbraid.
ACTH: a growth hormone produced by the anterior pituitary gland; stimulates the adrenal cortex.
Ambrosia: The fabled food of the gods (as nectar was their drink), which conferred immortality upon those who partook of it.
Auxesis: A figure by which a grave and magnificent word is put for the proper word; amplification; hyperbole.
Attainable: Capable of being attained or reached by efforts of the mind or body; capable of being compassed or accomplished by efforts directed to the object.
Appaum\u00e9: A hand open and extended so as to show the palm.
altricial: born naked and blind and dependent on parents for food; -- of hatchlings.  Opposite of precocial.
Appropriable: Capable of being appropriated, set apart, sequestered, or assigned exclusively to a particular use.
Apiece: Each by itself; by the single one; to each; as the share of each; as, these melons cost a shilling apiece.
anaphase: the stage of meiosis or mitosis when chromosomes move toward opposite ends of the nuclear spindle.
aeon: A period of immeasurable duration. See Eon.
agrology: the science of soils in relation to crops.
Armored division: a division of a land army which is equipped with armored vehicles such as tanks or armored personnel carriers.
Antimonic: Pertaining to, or derived from, antimony; -- said of those compounds of antimony in which this element has its highest equivalence; as, antimonic acid.
Adhibition: The act of adhibiting; application; use.
Alnager: A measure by the ell; formerly a sworn officer in England, whose duty was to inspect and measure woolen cloth, and fix upon it a seal.
Appositive: Of or relating to apposition; in apposition.
Accipitriformes: in some classifications an alternative name for the Falconiformes.
Autostability: Automatic stability; also, inherent stability. An aëroplane is inherently stable if it keeps in steady poise by virtue of its shape and proportions alone; it is automatically stable if it keeps in steady poise by means of self-operative mechanism.
Accloy: To fill to satiety; to stuff full; to clog; to overload; to burden. See Cloy.
Arteriotomy: The opening of an artery, esp. for bloodletting.
Affiance: Plighted faith; marriage contract or promise.
Add: To make an addition. To add to, to augment; to increase; as, it adds to our anxiety.
Ado: To do; in doing; as, there is nothing ado.
Algarovilla: The agglutinated seeds and husks of the legumes of a South American tree (Inga Marthæ). It is valuable for tanning leather, and as a dye.
Antrum: A cavern or cavity, esp. an anatomical cavity or sinus
Attractable: Capable of being attracted; subject to attraction.
Ambrose: A sweet-scented herb; ambrosia. See Ambrosia, 3.
Arpentator: The Anglicized form of the French arpenteur, a land surveyor.
Armlet: A small arm; as, an armlet of the sea.
Absolve: To set free, or release, as from some obligation, debt, or responsibility, or from the consequences of guilt or such ties as it would be sin or guilt to violate; to pronounce free; as, to absolve a subject from his allegiance; to absolve an offender, which amounts to an acquittal and remission of his punishment.
Absinthate: A combination of absinthic acid with a base or positive radical.
Astatic: Having little or no tendency to take a fixed or definite position or direction: thus, a suspended magnetic needle, when rendered astatic, loses its polarity, or tendency to point in a given direction.
Ascertain: To render (a person) certain; to cause to feel certain; to make confident; to assure; to apprise.
Ad-: As a prefix ad- assumes the forms ac-, af-, ag-, al-, an-, ap-, ar-, as-, at-, assimilating the d with the first letter of the word to which ad- is prefixed. It remains unchanged before vowels, and before d, h, j, m, v. Examples: adduce, adhere, adjacent, admit, advent, accord, affect, aggregate, allude, annex, appear, etc. It becomes ac- before qu, as in acquiesce.
Armisonant: Rustling in arms; resounding with arms.
Assemblyman: A member of an assembly, especially of the lower branch of a state legislature.
Actionable: That may be the subject of an action or suit at law; as, to call a man a thief is actionable.
Aortic: Of or pertaining to the aorta.
Arthrodia: A form of diarthrodial articulation in which the articular surfaces are nearly flat, so that they form only an imperfect ball and socket.
Amortizable: Capable of being cleared off, as a debt.
Aulic: The ceremony observed in conferring the degree of doctor of divinity in some European universities. It begins by a harangue of the chancellor addressed to the young doctor, who then receives the cap, and presides at the disputation (also called the aulic).
aneurysm: a sac-like widening of a blood vessel.
Adaptation: The act or process of adapting, or fitting; or the state of being adapted or fitted; fitness.
asexuality: having no evident sex or sex organs.
Arrogation: The act of arrogating, or making exorbitant claims; the act of taking more than one is justly entitled to.
Announcement: The act of announcing, or giving notice; that which announces; proclamation; publication.
Avenage: A quantity of oats paid by a tenant to a landlord in lieu of rent.
Adduction: The act of adducing or bringing forward.
3-D: a movie with images having three dimensional form or appearance.
Angelophany: The actual appearance of an angel to man.
Abirritate: To diminish the sensibility of; to debilitate.
Abderite: An inhabitant of Abdera, in Thrace.
Annex: Something annexed or appended; as, an additional stipulation to a writing, a subsidiary building to a main building; a wing.
Aruspicy: Prognostication by inspection of the entrails of victims slain sacrifice.
Acrita: The lowest groups of animals, in which no nervous system has been observed.
Adonis: A youth beloved by Venus for his beauty. He was killed in the chase by a wild boar.
Accessory: That which belongs to something else deemed the principal; something additional and subordinate.
Awless: Wanting reverence; void of respectful fear.
Antinomianism: The tenets or practice of Antinomians.
Aruspice: A soothsayer of ancient Rome. Same as Aruspex.
Annexation: The act of annexing; process of attaching, adding, or appending; the act of connecting; union; as, the annexation of Texas to the United States, or of chattels to the freehold.
Astrotheology: Theology founded on observation or knowledge of the celestial bodies.
Adonic: Relating to Adonis, famed for his beauty.
Ambergris: A substance of the consistence of wax, found floating in the Indian Ocean and other parts of the tropics, and also as a morbid secretion in the intestines of the sperm whale (Physeter macrocephalus), which is believed to be in all cases its true origin. In color it is white, ash-gray, yellow, or black, and often variegated like marble. The floating masses are sometimes from sixty to two hundred and twenty-five pounds in weight. It is wholly volatilized as a white vapor at 212° Fahrenheit, and is highly valued in perfumery.
Asepsis: State of being aseptic; the methods or processes of asepticizing.
Apodes: An order of fishes without ventral fins, including the eels.
Attitudinarian: One who attitudinizes; a posture maker.
Antecedently: Previously; before in time; at a time preceding; as, antecedently to conversion.
Anonym: One who is anonymous; also sometimes used for “pseudonym.”
Abraum: A red ocher used to darken mahogany and for making chloride of potassium.
Auction pitch: A game of cards in which the players bid for the privilege of determining or “pitching” the trump suit.
Audacity: Daring spirit, resolution, or confidence; venturesomeness.
Addressee: One to whom anything is addressed.
Areola: An interstice or small space, as between the cracks of the surface in certain crustaceous lichens; or as between the fibers composing organs or vessels that interlace; or as between the nervures of an insect's wing.
Ancony: A piece of malleable iron, wrought into the shape of a bar in the middle, but unwrought at the ends.
Albescence: The act of becoming white; whitishness.
Asperation: The act of asperating; a making or becoming rough.
Autoharp: A zitherlike musical instrument, provided with dampers which, when depressed, deaden some strings, leaving free others that form a chord.
Albumin: A thick, viscous nitrogenous substance, which is the chief and characteristic constituent of white of eggs and of the serum of blood, and is found in other animal substances, both fluid and solid, also in many plants. It is soluble in water and is coagulated by heat and by certain chemical reagents.
Abreaction: the purging of emotional tensions.  See Catharsis, below.
anaesthetized: rendered insensible by means of anesthesia.
Anchoretism: The practice or mode of life of an anchoret.
Anamese: Of or pertaining to Anam, to southeastern Asia.
Apodeictic: Self-evident; intuitively true; evident beyond contradiction.
Apricot: A fruit allied to the plum, of an orange color, oval shape, and delicious taste; also, the tree (Prunus Armeniaca of Linnæus) which bears this fruit. By cultivation it has been introduced throughout the temperate zone.
Amount: The sum total of two or more sums or quantities; the aggregate; the whole quantity; a totality; as, the amount of 7 and 9 is 16; the amount of a bill; the amount of this year's revenue.
Argentite: Sulphide of silver; -- also called vitreous silver, or silver glance. It has a metallic luster, a lead-gray color, and is sectile like lead.
Abietinic: Of or pertaining to abietin; as, abietinic acid.
Anunnaki: any of a group of powerful earth spirits or genii; servitors of the gods.
Auriform: Having the form of the human ear; ear-shaped.
aerides: any orchid of the genus Aerides.
amnesiac: Having lost memories, especially due to brain injury or mental shock; suffering from amnesia.
Arthrogastra: A division of the Arachnida, having the abdomen annulated, including the scorpions, harvestmen, etc.; pedipalpi.
Authoritative: Having, or proceeding from, due authority; entitled to obedience, credit, or acceptance; determinate; commanding.
Abloom: In or into bloom; in a blooming state.
Adject: To add or annex; to join.
Arachnida: One of the classes of Arthropoda. See Illustration in Appendix.
Artilleryman: A man who manages, or assists in managing, a large gun in firing.
Adytum: The innermost sanctuary or shrine in ancient temples, whence oracles were given. Hence: A private chamber; a sanctum.
Await: A waiting for; ambush; watch; watching; heed.
Acromonogrammatic: Having each verse begin with the same letter as that with which the preceding verse ends.
Affirmatively: In an affirmative manner; on the affirmative side of a question; in the affirmative; -- opposed to negatively.
Autopsy: Personal observation or examination; seeing with one's own eyes; ocular view.
Apishness: The quality of being apish; mimicry; foppery.
Aliethmoid: Pertaining to expansions of the ethmoid bone or cartilage.
Ataxic: Characterized by ataxy, that is, (a) by great irregularity of functions or symptoms, or (b) by a lack of coordinating power in movements.
Antheridium: The male reproductive apparatus in the lower plants, consisting of a cell or other cavity in which spermatozoids are produced; -- called also spermary.
Aldermanity: Aldermen collectively; the body of aldermen.
advertising: a communication publicly promoting some product or service.
Adjunctive: One who, or that which, is joined.
Alleghenian: Pertaining to or designating the humid division of the Transition zone extending across the northern United States from New England to eastern Dakota, and including also most of Pennsylvania and the mountainous region as far south as northern Georgia.
Anakim: A race of giants living in Palestine.
Animal: Of or relating to animals; as, animal functions.
Anamorphoscope: An instrument for restoring a picture or image distorted by anamorphosis to its normal proportions. It usually consists of a cylindrical mirror.
Aggeneration: The act of producing in addition.
Ageless: Without old age limits of duration; as, fountains of ageless youth.
Albert ware: A soft ornamental terra-cotta pottery, sold in the biscuit state for decorating.
Auriculars: A circle of feathers surrounding the opening of the ear of birds.
Abundance: An overflowing fullness; ample sufficiency; great plenty; profusion; copious supply; superfluity; wealth: -- strictly applicable to quantity only, but sometimes used of number.
abridged: shortened by condensing or rewriting; -- said of texts
Acinose: Consisting of acini, or minute granular concretions; as, acinose or acinous glands.
Azoturia: Excess of urea or other nitrogenous substances in the urine.
Anticor: A dangerous inflammatory swelling of a horse's breast, just opposite the heart.
Abolitionize: To imbue with the principles of abolitionism.
Agon: A contest for a prize at the public games.
Afterwards: At a later or succeeding time.
Accessorial: Of or pertaining to an accessory; as, accessorial agency, accessorial guilt.
Agelaius: A genus of birds including the red-winged blackbirds.
Alum root: A North American herb (Heuchera Americana) of the Saxifrage family, whose root has astringent properties.
Arbitrator: A person, or one of two or more persons, chosen by parties who have a controversy, to determine their differences. See Arbitration.
Aponeurotic: Of or pertaining to an aponeurosis.
Apiculture: Rearing of bees for their honey and wax.
Alcyonaria: One of the orders of Anthozoa. It includes the Alcyonacea, Pennatulacea, and Gorgonacea.
Areng: A palm tree (Saguerus saccharifer) which furnishes sago, wine, and fibers for ropes; the gomuti palm.
Angusticlave: A narrow stripe of purple worn by the equites on each side of the tunic as a sign of rank.
Amanuensis: A person whose employment is to write what another dictates, or to copy what another has written.
Arrestee: The person in whose hands is the property attached by arrestment.
Anaseismic: Moving up and down; -- said of earthquake shocks.
aliveness: the condition of living or the state of being alive.
Abactinal: Pertaining to the surface or end opposite to the mouth in a radiate animal; -- opposed to actinal.
After-sails: The sails on the mizzenmast, or on the stays between the mainmast and mizzenmast.
Adviso: Advice; counsel; suggestion; also, a dispatch or advice boat.
Adhesion: The action of sticking; the state of being attached; intimate union; as, the adhesion of glue, or of parts united by growth, cement, or the like.
Absinthial: Of or pertaining to wormwood; absinthian.
Atlas: A rich kind of satin manufactured in India.
Aconitine: An intensely poisonous alkaloid, extracted from aconite.
Accordant: Agreeing; consonant; harmonious; corresponding; conformable; -- followed by with or to.
Acritan: Of or pertaining to the Acrita.
Apsidal: Of or pertaining to the apsides of an orbit.
Ampelite: An earth abounding in pyrites, used by the ancients to kill insects, etc., on vines; -- applied by Brongniart to a carbonaceous alum schist.
&Verbar;Apophasis: A figure by which a speaker formally declines to take notice of a favorable point, but in such a manner as to produce the effect desired. [For example, see Mark Antony's oration. Shak., Julius Cæsar, iii. 2.]
Agaty: Of the nature of agate, or containing agate.
Alegge: To allay or alleviate; to lighten.
Acropetal: Developing from below towards the apex, or from the circumference towards the center; centripetal; -- said of certain inflorescence.
anticipated: expected; opposite of unanticipated and unexpected.
Andr\u0153cium: The stamens of a flower taken collectively.
Actinograph: An instrument for measuring and recording the variations in the actinic or chemical force of rays of light.
Arch stone: A wedge-shaped stone used in an arch; a voussoir.
Agate: A semipellucid, uncrystallized variety of quartz, presenting various tints in the same specimen. Its colors are delicately arranged in stripes or bands, or blended in clouds.
Aquosity: The condition of being wet or watery; wateriness.
Amble: A peculiar gait of a horse, in which both legs on the same side are moved at the same time, alternating with the legs on the other side.
Ailuroidea: A group of the Carnivora, which includes the cats, civets, and hyenas.
Acetable: An acetabulum; or about one eighth of a pint.
Abbreviation: The act of shortening, or reducing.
Allemande: A dance in moderate twofold time, invented by the French in the reign of Louis XIV.; -- now mostly found in suites of pieces, like those of Bach and Handel.
Alopiidae: a family of fish comprising the thresher sharks.
Amphitheatric: Of, pertaining to, exhibited in, or resembling, an amphitheater.
Aliene: To alien or alienate; to transfer, as title or property; as, to aliene an estate.
Ambrosin: An early coin struck by the dukes of Milan, and bearing the figure of St. Ambrose on horseback.
assertable: capable of being affirmed or asserted.
Adequacy: The state or quality of being adequate, proportionate, or sufficient; a sufficiency for a particular purpose; as, the adequacy of supply to the expenditure.
Afghani: a native or inhabitant of Afghanistan.
Allfours: A game at cards, called “High, Low, Jack, and the Game.”
Amylogen: That part of the starch granule or granulose which is soluble in water.
Andranatomy: The dissection of a human body, especially of a male; androtomy.
7: One more than six; constituting or denoting a quantity consisting of seven items or units; -- representing the number seven as an Arabic numeral
Awaken: To rouse from sleep or torpor; to awake; to wake.
Aphakia: An anomalous state of refraction caused by the absence of the crystalline lens, as after operations for cataract. The remedy is the use of powerful convex lenses.
Anthracene: A solid hydrocarbon, C6H4.C2H2.C6H4, which accompanies naphthalene in the last stages of the distillation of coal tar. Its chief use is in the artificial production of alizarin.
Auxiliary: A helper; an assistant; a confederate in some action or enterprise.
Anisopleura: A primary division of gastropods, including those having spiral shells. The two sides of the body are unequally developed.
Archway: A way or passage under an arch.
Acclimate: To habituate to a climate not native; to acclimatize.
Aspirant: One who aspires; one who eagerly seeks some high position or object of attainment.
Antisocialist: One opposed to the doctrines and practices of socialists or socialism.
Accession: A coming to; the act of acceding and becoming joined; as, a king's accession to a confederacy.
A\u00ebrodrome: A shed for housing an airship or aëroplane.
anglophile: an admirer of England and things English.
An\u00e6sthetic: That which produces insensibility to pain, as chloroform, ether, etc.
Apostle: Literally: One sent forth; a messenger. Specifically: One of the twelve disciples of Christ, specially chosen as his companions and witnesses, and sent forth to preach the gospel.
Acciaccatura: A short grace note, one semitone below the note to which it is prefixed; -- used especially in organ music. Now used as equivalent to the short appoggiatura.
Amelcorn: A variety of wheat from which starch is produced; -- called also French rice.
Alhambra: The palace of the Moorish kings at Granada.
airborne: conveyed by or through air, as dust or pollen; as, a clean room is needed to avoid airborne contaminants.
arteriolar: of or pertaining to an arteriole.
Aurigation: The act of driving a chariot or a carriage.
A\u00ebrohydrodynamic: Acting by the force of air and water; as, an aërohydrodynamic wheel.
Arefaction: The act of drying, or the state of growing dry.
Albertype: A picture printed from a kind of gelatine plate produced by means of a photographic negative.
acidophilic: growing well in an acid medium; said of some bacteria
Algol: A fixed star, in Medusa's head, in the constellation Perseus, remarkable for its periodic variation in brightness.
Agnus Dei: A figure of a lamb bearing a cross or flag.
Anemometer: An instrument for measuring the force or velocity of the wind; a wind gauge.
anaphylactic shock: a severe form of physiological shock, often having a fatal outcome, caused by an extreme immunological reaction to antigens.  It is a severe form of anaphylaxis{2}, and is characterized by smooth muscle contraction and capillary dilation throughout the body, initiated by antibodies of the IgE class.  It is usually seen when an antigen to which a person has become hypersensitized is injected intravenously or subcutaneously.  It is also called generalyzed anaphylaxis or systemic anaphylaxis, and sometimes anaphylaxis.
Arris: The sharp edge or salient angle formed by two surfaces meeting each other, whether plane or curved; -- applied particularly to the edges in moldings, and to the raised edges which separate the flutings in a Doric column.
Appertainment: That which appertains to a person; an appurtenance.
Ampulla: A narrow-necked vessel having two handles and bellying out like a jug.
Archetype: The original pattern or model of a work; or the model from which a thing is made or formed.
Alembroth: The salt of wisdom of the alchemists, a double salt composed of the chlorides of ammonium and mercury. It was formerly used as a stimulant.
Alum: To steep in, or otherwise impregnate with, a solution of alum; to treat with alum.
Auchenium: The part of the neck nearest the back.
\u00c6stival: Of or belonging to the summer; as, æstival diseases.
Ancillary: Subservient or subordinate, like a handmaid; auxiliary.
Anneal: To subject to great heat, and then cool slowly, as glass, cast iron, steel, or other metal, for the purpose of rendering it less brittle; to temper; to toughen.
ascolichen: a lichen in which the fungus component is an ascomycete.
Alto-rilievo: High relief; sculptured work in which the figures project more than half their thickness; as, this figure is an alto-rilievo or in alto-rilievo.
A\u00ebromechanics: The science of equilibrium and motion of air or an aëriform fluid, including aërodynamics and aërostatics.
Anatomism: The application of the principles of anatomy, as in art.
Adenology: The part of physiology that treats of the glands.
Arborator: One who plants or who prunes trees.
Arson: The malicious burning of a dwelling house or outhouse of another man, which by the common law is felony; the malicious and voluntary firing of a building or ship.
Admissible: Entitled to be admitted, or worthy of being admitted; that may be allowed or conceded; allowable; as, the supposition is hardly admissible.
Andropetalous: Produced by the conversion of the stamens into petals, as double flowers, like the garden ranunculus.
Appraise: To set a value; to estimate the worth of, particularly by persons appointed for the purpose; as, to appraise goods and chattels.
audio: the part of a transmitted signal which conveys the sound of the event represented by the signal, such as that of a television program.
Abortionist: One who performs or procures abortion; among medical personnel, also called an abortion provider.
Affectingly: In an affecting manner; is a manner to excite emotions.
Alumnus: A pupil; especially, a graduate of a college or other seminary of learning.
acidosis: abnormally high acidity of the blood and other body fluids.
Acetary: An acid pulp in certain fruits, as the pear.
A\u00ebro-: The combining form of the Greek word meaning air.
\u00c6gilops: An ulcer or fistula in the inner corner of the eye.
adsorb: to attract and bind (molecules of a substance in a fluid) so as to form a thin layer on the surface, by non-electrostatic forces; to bind by adsorption.  Distinguished from absorb, in which the foreign substance penetrates the body of the absorbing material.
Attainder: The act of attainting, or the state of being attainted; the extinction of the civil rights and capacities of a person, consequent upon sentence of death or outlawry; as, an act of attainder.
Ampullaceous: Like a bottle or inflated bladder; bottle-shaped; swelling.
Aurelia: The chrysalis, or pupa of an insect, esp. when reflecting a brilliant golden color, as that of some of the butterflies.
Austral: Southern; lying or being in the south; as, austral land; austral ocean.
Antero-: A combining form meaning anterior, front; as, antero-posterior, front and back; antero-lateral, front side, anterior and at the side.
adipic acid: an aliphatic dicarboxylic acid (HO.CO.(CH2)4.CO.OH), containing six carbon atoms in a linear chain.  It is found in beet juice.  It is used in the manufacture of synthetic plastics such as Nylon, as well as other products.
axerophthol: a vitamin essential for normal vision (C20H30O); it prevents night blindness or inflammation or dryness of the eyes; same as vitamin A.  One U.S.P. unit of vitamin A is equivalent to 0.30 micrograms of pure vitamin A alcohol.
Antibacterial: a chemical substance which kills or inhibits the growth of bacteria.
anesthetist: a specialist who administers an anesthetic to a patient before the patient is treated.
Arborization: The appearance or figure of a tree or plant, as in minerals or fossils; a dendrite.
Autokinetic system: In fire-alarm telegraphy, a system so arranged that when one alarm is being transmitted, no other alarm, sent in from another point, will be transmitted until after the first alarm has been disposed of.
Agreeingly: In an agreeing manner (to); correspondingly; agreeably.
Ashlaring: The act of bedding ashlar in mortar.
ammonoid: one of the coiled chambered fossil shells of extinct mollusks; same as ammonite.
Attrap: To adorn with trapping; to array.
Antispastic: Believed to cause a revulsion of fluids or of humors from one part to another.
Assecure: To make sure or safe; to assure.
Auntie: A familiar name for an aunt. In the southern United States a familiar term applied to aged negro women.
Andron: The apartment appropriated for the males. This was in the lower part of the house.
Apery: A place where apes are kept.
Anandrous: Destitute of stamens, as certain female flowers.
Antimephitic: Good against mephitic or deleterious gases.
Agamic: Produced without sexual union; as, agamic or unfertilized eggs.
Aptotic: Pertaining to, or characterized by, aptotes; uninflected; as, aptotic languages.
antheridiophore: a gametophore bearing antheridia as in certain mosses and liverworts.
Arshine: A Russian measure of length = 2 ft. 4.246 inches.
Achromatin: Tissue which is not stained by fluid dyes.
Achromatic: Free from color; transmitting light without decomposing it into its primary colors.
Alertness: The quality of being alert or on the alert; briskness; nimbleness; activity.
Approvement: Improvement of common lands, by inclosing and converting them to the uses of husbandry for the advantage of the lord of the manor.
Annular: Pertaining to, or having the form of, a ring; forming a ring; ringed; ring-shaped; as, annular fibers.
Aubaine: Succession to the goods of a stranger not naturalized.
Affectibility: The quality or state of being affectible.
acid-loving: thriving in a relatively acid environment; -- especially of plants requiring a pH well below 7
Audient: A hearer; especially a catechumen in the early church.
Assailment: The act or power of assailing; attack; assault.
Affreighter: One who hires or charters a ship to convey goods.
Actinotrocha: A peculiar larval form of Phoronis, a genus of marine worms, having a circle of ciliated tentacles.
Anomia: A genus of bivalve shells, allied to the oyster, so called from their unequal valves, of which the lower is perforated for attachment.
Angularly: In an angular manner; with of at angles or corners.
Aurited: Having lobes like the ear; auriculate.
Admirable: Fitted to excite wonder; wonderful; marvelous.
aminoalkane: a compound derived from ammonia by replacing hydrogen atoms by univalent hydrocarbon radicals.
Assigner: One who assigns, appoints, allots, or apportions.
\u00c6sir: In the old Norse mythology, the gods Odin, Thor, Loki, Balder, Frigg, and the others. Their home was called Asgard.
Alimentariness: The quality of being alimentary; nourishing quality.
Accompliceship: The state of being an accomplice.
Alure: A walk or passage; -- applied to passages of various kinds.
A\u00ebrognosy: The science which treats of the properties of the air, and of the part it plays in nature.
Anthrenus: A genus of small beetles, several of which, in the larval state, are very destructive to woolen goods, fur, etc.  The common “museum pest” is Anthrenus varius; the carpet beetle is Anthrenus scrophulariæ. The larvæ are commonly confounded with moths.
Acephalocyst: A larval entozoön in the form of a subglobular or oval vesicle, or hydatid, filled with fluid, sometimes found in the tissues of man and the lower animals; -- so called from the absence of a head or visible organs on the vesicle. These cysts are the immature stages of certain tapeworms. Also applied to similar cysts of different origin.
Araujia: small genus of South American evergreen vines.
Allied: United; joined; leagued; akin; related. See Ally.
